ns0:div.ns0:head: 16.6.1880 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ems. Diary Sun rises 3,44 set 816 16 June 1880"Sun rises 3,44 set 816" wurde nachträglich mit Tinte ergänzt.

This morning we have arrived at Ems we are staying at the villa Monrepos which is situated on the Lahn. We travelled in sleeping cars Baby Brion, Wilma , Mamma, Marie and Sophie in one car and Papa and I in another We arrived here at a quarter to twelve.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 17.6.1880 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ems 17 June 1880 Sun rises 3,44 sets 8,17

This morning I took a long walk with Papa by the Concordiathurm. Toilette seems not to be in the étiquette here, (pour le moment, at least,) judging by this morning, a more awfull profusion, diffusion, infusion and confusion of colours it is difficult to imagine (it is a regular tower of Babel of them,) the Britishers especially excell in this art and their colours are put together as they might be on the dirty palette of an inexperienced painter. The sensation of having your teeth set on edge must be very agreeable in Ems, at least telling by the colours, for they are certainly chosen to that purpose. The French also bring their contingent of paint by hoisting the colours of the emperor Wilhelm I. (evidently to honour him) red, white, and black on their faces The dresses are even more awfull than the colours, the promenade is a crowd of dresses so short and tight one might take them for underpetticoats or so long and loose you could mistake them for dressinggowns, of cloaks most certainly copied from the assyrian bas reliefs or from the cloaks found with the mummies in the pyramyds (with which they have a strong resemblance,) of exceedingly short and four cornerd waists, of injecting chests, of projecting stomacks, of very flatt and long feet, of red faces and other accomplishments. All at once this colourous and antidiluvian mass begans to move towards the bridge: the music has stopped and flatt-feet, red-faces and anti Crete'antidiluvian' meint vorsintflutlich und 'anti-Crete' vor der Kreidezeit. dresses are going home.
Nota: In coming to Ems we had 19 trunks and 18 parcels in the whole 37 things, Rien que çà!

ns0:div.ns0:head: 28.6.1880 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ems 28 June 1880

Today the emperor invites papa to diner for this evening. This afternoon Baby, nursevermutl. Sophie , Marie’s mother and I go to the kinderfest at the Lindenbach where I dance with Baby and others. Then all the children taking part to the kinderfest where photographed; we had topfschlagen which I won and other amusements

ns0:div.ns0:head: 1.5.1881 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris. 1. May. 1881. Sunday. S. rises 4.33. sets 7.21.

Full moon 13. M r Cook and M r Scudamore came to fetch me this morning for Versailles . We started by the 10.30 train in which we could hardly get a places. When we got to Versailles we took the buss and drove to the Museum; but this not yet being open we strolled into the grounds. At twelve we went into the Museum where we saw the pictures of the admirals, constables, Marshals and great warriors of France, pictures illustrating the history of France. Marie Antoinettes Private apartments and the „salle des glaces“, the hall in which the King of Prussia Wilhelm I. was crowned Emperor of Germany. We came out of the Museum a little past one and went to the little and the big Trianon where we saw the state carriages and the appartments occupied by Madame de Maintenon, Marie Antoinette, Napoleon 1 st
, Louis Philippe and Queen Victoria Victoria I. , and the hall in which Bazaine was tried in 1873. After that we went to have breakfast at the Hotel de France on salmon, cutlets and potatoes and Coffee at 15.fr.75. for three of us. Then we went to see the Band and „Grandes-Eaux.“ We took seats at the basin de Neptune, at 4.25. and watched the swelling ant-like crowd, getting greater and greater roaring and rushing. Twice it started up on false alarm and sat down and twice that buzz grew and fell till at last the continual roar shewed the basin de Neptune was playing; we just looked at it and then walked sharply to the station where I took 1st class tickets. But once on the platform I saw the hard reality: the choice between stopping at Versailles or being buried with dust on the imperial: we chose the latter. At first we were very comfortable but at Ville d’Avray A lot of of People got in and made it nearly impossible for other people to get in but at Suresne ... O dear! the carriages in which there was one seat left were directly stormed by about 20 people, screaming and howling and swearing, and pushing and fighting and treading on corns – and the the carriages in which there were no seats left were no better off We were directly invaded by a whole army of human-beings who could not even get in and who had to hold on by the sides, (or passerelle). Then the screaming of the people left behind and the howling and the cheering of the people who had places mixed in one long yell which died by degrees but was always invariably taken up again by the people in the train every time we went through a tunnel or passed any habitation or any living creature. In Paris all made a rush and consequently nobody could move. and We came home very tired. At the gare S t Lazare we found M r Scudamore who had got into carriage and not onto the Imperial. M eurs Cook and Scudamore made me accept 8.50. as giving back.Am Schluß dieses Eintrages ist eine Passage durch zwei X markiert. Da keine Einweisungszeichen vorhanden sind, wurde die Passage an der Stelle belassen. Nachträgliche Eintragungen erfolgten mit schwarzer Tinte und sind so deutlich zu erkennen.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 15.5.1881 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: London Monday 15 of May

I arrived in London after a pretty rough passage Baby Brion, Wilma when I kissed her this morning said „please let me kiss you on your face“ she had got up very early and looked very sweet in her little white flannel night shirt I arrived at 7 instead of 5.55. and so I have to stay with Bonnemaman Lynch, Caroline for the night instead of going on to Ascot. It is very bad weather

ns0:div.ns0:head: 23.5.1881 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot Monday 23 May 1881

It is my birthday today. I was born in Paris at the corner of the rue de Luxembourg and the rue du Mont Thabor at the 3 etage in 1868 but soon after went to Hamburg When 4 I went to America and stopped there till I was five then I came to England and Mamma and Papa soon after (about 2 years after) settled in Paris where I was during the remarkably cold winter of 1879-1880 In which the cold amounted to 24 degrees Cent. I saw the Seine frozen. Papa came to see me today and brought me a barometer and Microscope.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 26.5.1881 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot Thursday 26 May 1881

Ascension day. We went for an expedition in which we were to go by railway to Brookwood, walk across Chobham common to Virginia Waters from where we were to go by railway home but we only got as far as Brookwood and the camp at Chobham where we had to go into a „Cantine“ on account of the rain and where as Uffington went in a soldier seized him and saying he was not wrapped in a cloak to Mortimer mi. cap and another asked me wether I would have a glass of Beer with him; they all made la haie as we came in. We had ginger beer near the railway and had an electric shock at the signal box and made a fog signal go off by the porters pushing a truck over it we came home by train from Brookwood the necropolis (city of the dead) of London; whole holiday

ns0:div.ns0:head: 30.5.1881 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot 30 May 1881 Monday

Today at dinner the Head Sneyd-Kynnersley after grace said „Stop please. I am very grieved to hear that all the boys are not truthful here. Blundell stand up. I find you have gone through a long course of deceit. ........ I have written to you father about it and asked him to come and see you. I can’t have such a boy here. of course you shall be flogged but that is not the worse .... Thomson ma. and Olliver bring Blundell up to my room“ Probably he will be expeled. The head also spoke of certain half crowns which Blundell had been anxious should be given to Annie who was last term in charge of the cottage

ns0:div.ns0:head: 4.7.1881 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot July 4 1881

This morning we drove away at 9 and started for the Devils Punch bowl which is about 22 miles off; there was one big brake in which I was and 2 smaller ones but as all the boys could not get in M rs Kynnersley and 6 boys had to go in another carriage. It was very hot being 92 Farh. in the shade and 120 in the sun. It took us rather more than 4 hours to get to the place as none of the drivers knew the way and we were hardly rewarded for the squash by 2 or 3 fine views into Surrey. When we got there we had a picnick. G! but what a picnick! without a bit of shade there we sat in the broiling sun drinking dirty tepid water which had been brought from the next inn which was a mile off in an old tin kettle which had come from Ascot with us trailing on the ground without a lid and which was consequently full of dust. However it was better than nothing and so we were quite content with that as it was quite a relief from the boiling ginger beer and ale which we had had before. We had tea at an inn as our diner experiences had not been very pleasant..There was a murder committed at the Punch bowl there is a cross to mark the place, a mound to mark the gallons and a stone and inscription to mark the spot was thrown into the punch bowl. I had the courage to go to the bottom of it and was rewarded by finding some pummistone. We saw the comet which was very bright while coming home and rejoiced our ears by having „Grandfather’s clock“ Work and ghost stories bawled into them

ns0:div.ns0:head: 9.7.1881 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot July 9 Saturday 1881

Went to a review of 62000 thousand volunteers but the most interesting of the thing was the queen’s Victoria I. procession In the first carriage was the Queen in black the Princesse of Wales Alexandra, Königin von Großbritannien in dark blue and the Crown princesse of Germany Viktoria, Deutsche Kaiserin und Königin von Preußen in white In the same carriage but behind the Queen sat John Browne the Queens favourite servant in black and silver. Then followed some huntsmen next came another carriage with the duchesses of Teck and Connaught and 2 other ladies then some more huntsmen and the two princesses of Hesse-Darmstadtmöglich wären: Battenberg, Viktoria, Elisabeth, Großfürstin von Russland, Irene, Prinzessin von Preußen, Alexandra, Zarin von Russland in blue then the officers of police and last but not least the king of the Sandwich islands Kalakaua I., König von Hawaii in another carriage. After these carriages came a royal huntsman in gold and dark crimson then came the Prince of Wales Eduard VII. in some dark colour with the badge of the order of the Garter (blue), riding next to the Crown prince of Germany Friedrich III. in a white uniform, then came the dukes of Teck, Connaught and Cambridge and the duke of Hesse-Darmstadt Ludwig IV. the husband of the late unfortunate princess Alice. a lot of others of their staff closing the procession

ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot July 15. Friday 1881.
98 degrees farhenheit in the shade. Went out for a drive with M rs Kynnersley, M rs Macdonald and Blackwood in the cool of the evening

ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot July 17. 1881. Sunday
Great heat but not so hot as on Friday. Dear Mamma’s birthday

ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot. July 19. 1881 Tuesday
Papa came this afternoon and brought me the summer number of the Graphic.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 21.7.1881 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot July 21 1881. Thursday

I was sitting in the Library reading this morning when I heard a terrific crash I looked up and beheld the ceiling coming down on Hill’s and Bowring minor’s head. I gave a bound an rushed away thinking that the house was coming down.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 24.7.1881 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot July 24 Sunday. 1881
Dreadful rain today. In chapel we could hardly hear what the Head Sneyd-Kynnersley said on account of the rain clattering on the roof

ns0:div.ns0:head: 26.7.1881 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot July 26 Tuesday 1881
Lightning very bad a frightful storm on. Fork lightning very bright an large. Raining very hard. Rain in sheets bending the trees down

ns0:div.ns0:head: 1.8.1881 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot August 1 rst 1881 Monday

The prizes were given today few people came and those who did come were almost all from the neighbourhood. I got an extra Scripture prize for only being 3 marks of Oliver who got the first Scripture prize. I also got a French prize. Thomson ma. got 1 rs div total work prize very fine Shakespeare

ns0:p.ns0:note: Hier ist wieder der Bericht des Examinators eingeklebt. Es folgt die Abschrift. Formatierungen wurden nicht alle übernommen. Auf dem Blatt steht in Kesslers Hand: „Report read by M r Macdonald at the prizes“.

ns0:div.ns0:p: S. George’s School, Ascot
--- TRIALS, JULY, 1881. ---
Report of the Examiner, Rev. F. W. Macdonald, M.A., Queen’s College, Oxford.

On this my second Examination of this School, I am glad to find that the Standard of Work has in no respect deteriorated, while improvement has been made in those subjects which I considered last Trials to be weaker than the rest.
I have again been impressed with the level character of the work, and the great neatness with which the papers have been answered.

With regard to English: – in the Scripture which was a difficult paper. Olliver, Count Kessler, Lord Uffington, and Palk were particularly good, Bald, on the other hand has not improved in this respect. In History and Geography, Thomson, ma., Thomson, mi., and Sellon deserve high praise; dates however must be in the future more carefully got up. I was also struck with the improvement in Essay Writing particularly noticeable in Divisions 2 and 4.

In Classical Work, Division I. show a distinct improvement in Greek Translation and Greek Grammar, Thomson, ma. in the latter gaining within 7 of the full marks: the Prepositions are the weak point in this subject.
In Latin Grammar, Thomson, ma. again distinguishes himself, closely followed by Tomlin, whose general neatness in paper work is to be specially commended.
The Latin Translation was fairly done by all. Waterhouse’s paper showing that he had taken great pains.
The Latin Composition was really well done throughout. Olliver being preeminent.
The Unseen Translation was perhaps a little too easy; it was mastered by all the boys.
In Greek Composition, the papers were better than I expected. ThomsonUnklar welcher, Thomson, ma. oder Thomson, mi. , Olliver and Waterhouse pleased me much by their accuracy in the Grammar.
The Latin Verses throughout the School were better than those of last Trials, but there is still great room for improvement, and Division III. must pay more attention to Prosody rules.
Division II. did well in Latin Translation, notably Count Kessler, but I was more struck by the excellent way in which this Division managed their Greek Translation, a subject difficult to beginners.

In Latin Prose, more attention must be paid to the use of Prepositions. The Latin Grammar is very much improved. The Greek Grammar paper was accurately done, though weakness was shown in the declension of nouns, Bald and Scott are here some way behind the rest. In this Division Jay, Schuster and Count Kessler show great promise.
In Division III. the best work was done in the Latin Grammar Paper, which was remarkably well answered throughout, particularly by Sellon.
In the Greek Grammar, more attention must be paid to the Comparison of Adjectives. Palk distinguished himself in this paper.
The Latin Prose was poor. In the Latin Translation, the Unseen Passages were rather too difficult.

In Mathematics and French, the standard of the work is high, above the average. In the former subject Whittaker and Wormald in their respective Sets did excellent papers, while Speer, ma.., and Mortimer, ma. must pay more attention. Tomlin must be commended for his Euclid and Algebra.
In French, Waterhouse (Set.1) and Count Kessler and Pilcher (Set 2) deserve great praise.
I cannot speak too highly of these two departments, so important in these days of Modern Education.

On the whole I, consider this Examination to have evinced almost greater evenness as to the work than last Trials, there being no real failures; this is a great desideratum in a School of this size, and a sign of the pains taken with each individual boy.
(Signed)
F. W. MACDONALD, M.A., Oxon, Vicar of Stapleford and Berwick, Wilts.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 2.8.1881 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p:
London Aug 2 nd
1881
Came up by the 7.40. train in the same carriage with Tomlin, Schuster, Wormald, Uffington who were very boisterous. Went out in the park in the afternoon.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 6.8.1881 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Etrétat August 6 th 1881.

We started off from London yesterday at 5.p.m. I bought a good lot of Illustrateds, Punches and David Copperfield and Pickwick Papers
Dickens . Got to Southampton about 8. Could not help remembring how papa went to see the Degners off to America here and how the ship went away with him on board and how he had to come back in the pilot’s boat and we missed the train – about 7 years ago. Went on board at 8 and steamer did not start till 12.15. p. m. Stopped on deck till it started wrapped in a shawl. Very smooth. Before going off we had some supper. We were sitting opposite an old maid and her attendant. The old lady ordered some stout so the steward brought it and made it fizz so when the steward brought the second bottle she ejaculated in a great excitement „O steward, steward dont throw the stout over me“. Steward was a regular cure; told uncle Edmund Craigie that if he cut some beef it would spoil the look of the joint. Another time my uncle told him not to shake the beer so he said it would have to be shaken when the ship moved. Arrived at Havre at 9.30 a. m. when we saw aunt Rose on the pier Mab directly made faces at her. Had a snack at Tortonis and arrived at Etrétat at 2. Weewee Brion, Wilma was highly delighted at seeing me.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 3.7.1880 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ems 3 July 1880

This morning it pelts and the promenade looks like a very crowded sea and all sails up, it is nothing but umbrellas colours have disappeared, nothing but umbrellas one has to fight to get through pulling one hat off, taring the other’s umbrella. It is sure if in the east an umbrella is a sign of distinction an oriental coming here would think us all kings

ns0:div.ns0:head: 7.8.1881 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Etretat. Villa Orphée 7 th August 1881. Sunday
Went down to the beach this morning. Bathed in the afternoon in the sea. Fair going on here which makes a dreadful row

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 8.8.1881 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Etretat. 8 th August 1881 Monday.

Aunt Rose and I walked to the chambre des demoiselles and from there down a winding path and some steps to a kind of beach. On the way we noticed a very good „mirage“ of the sea and a lot of boats, in the sky. From the beach we hailed a fishermans boat which took us to Etretat through the porte d’Aval. Aunt Rose bought 3 macrels. We went out for a drive in the afternoon to „Les Loges“ which is a very nice looking little „hameau“. Coming back we met the exqueen of Spain Isabella II. in a charaband harnessed with four mules and the coachman in the Spanish dress the footman also wore this. The queen had a blue dress on she was with the marchioness of Altavilla, they are both very fat indeed.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 9.8.1881 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Etretat 9th August 1881 Tuesday

Dreadful blow in the night. When we went down to the beach this morning we found some of the waves coming up so high as the bathing cabins. I found a lot of agotes and seaweed and shells. Saw the ex-queen of Spain Isabella II. and the Altavilla. Our fair friend, the ugly old crow as Mable calls her, who declared yesterday that I was hurting her when I moved my chair without touching her, kept aloof of us today and sat in an uncomfortable place so as not to be near us who were comfortably sitting in a stranded boat. We (Bonnemaman Lynch, Caroline , Aunt Rose and I) drove to Yport this afternoon where I and aunt Rose helped to catch some crabs which we had boiled for dinner. Some boys which we met there told us that 3 men had been drowned last night and that they were getting up a subscription for their relations. One of these boys was a relation of Alma-Tadéma the painter

ns0:div.ns0:head: 10.8.1881 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Etretat 10 th August 1881. Wednesday

Went down to the beach in the morning. Sea still very rough and wind high. Old sailors told grandmama Lynch, Caroline yesterday that this weather would last till the next quarter of the moon that is to say for 9 days for it was full moon yesterday. We found some wild mushrooms on the cliff to the left of the bay. Uncle Edmund Craigie went away

ns0:div.ns0:head: 11.8.1881 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Etretat 11 th August Thursday

Bathed in the afternoon. Brought a little girl, the friend of Mab and Weewee home for tea. We played ghost after tea. I dressed up in an old red shawl of Mab’s put seaweed and an old white shawl on my head and got uncle Edmund’s Craigie stick and made dreadful grimaces. Afterwards we had „I spy“. Sea still rough

ns0:div.ns0:head: 12.8.1881 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Etretat 12th August Friday 1881
Went up on the cliff after mushrooms but did not find any. Sea still very rough. Went to Bruneval in the afternoon.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 13.8.1881 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Etretat 13 th August. 1881. Saturday

Went on the cliff in the morning. In the afternoon we drove to Fecamp where we saw the old cathedral. There are some raised wax pictures of the Passion and some fine old chapels but the church wants the glow and colouring of the Paris churches although there is a beautifully coloured altar. The beauty of this cathedral principally consists in its size and the height of the columns and purity of the architecture.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 14.8.1881 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Etretat 14 th August Sunday 1881

Stopped at home and read this morning. One of our old hens ran away in the afternoon and we had to run after her. When she came back into our garden we had to put sentinels near the hen house so as to make her go in. We saw the new comet in the evening it is the second we have had this year it is now only very faint. We also saw a beautiful shooting star I never have seen such a bright one before it was like a rocket

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 15.8.1881 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Etretat 15 th of August 1881. Monday

Bathed this morning and while doing so lost one of my bathing shoes. After dinner went to see the procession at the church because it was the catholic feast of the Assumption. Afterwards we drove to Vaucotte-sur-mer where we saw and talked to some douaniers. The drive was very pretty but when we came back it poured with rain. It is still raining. Mabel went to tea at her friends miss Beals. The pope Leo XIII. will probably have to go to Malta so he has been ill used at Rome and has had stones thrown at him. The mob also tried to throw Pius IX’s bones and coffin into the Tiber

ns0:div.ns0:head: 18.8.1881 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Etretat 18 August 1881

Went to Havre; the drive took 2 hours and a half; Havre is not a pretty town by any means. The drive there is not exactly what you might call beautiful either. We again noticed the funny circumstance of all the Normans losing their top front teeth no matter how old they are.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 4.7.1880 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ems 4 July 1880

Today there is a Regatta here and the Glynkas come to our house to see it. There was a good bit of cheating about it one boat (my favourite) crushed the other boat against the wall, and broke the steer of it on purpose, and allmost upset it so as to win, which it did. This evening we assist to a firework in a shower which does not prevent the firework being beautiful A firework under umbrellas!

ns0:div.ns0:p: Etretat 19 th August 1881
Drive to Vaucotte. Very pretty drive over the hills

ns0:div.ns0:p: Etretat 20 th August 1881 Saturday
Went to Les Ifs to fetch Papa and Mamma nice drive

Drove to the Belle Ernestine (a very ugly woman Aubourg who is supposed to be pretty) where we met Papa and aunt Rose who had come on foot. Afterwards went on to Bruneval.

ns0:div.ns0:p: Etretat 22nd August 1881 Monday
Drove Papa to Les Ifs. He is going to Paris. I have rather bad bowel complaint

ns0:div.ns0:p: Etretat August 24. 1881 Wednesday
Baby’s Brion, Wilma birthday; she is not in a very good temper Papa not yet come back

ns0:div.ns0:head: 29.8.1881 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Etretat August 29 1881. Monday
Mamma and I drove out with M r von Blowitz in the carriage. We went to the top of the falaise.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 8.9.1881 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Etretat September 8. 1881 Thursday.
Italian mistress came. Went to fetch uncle Edmund Craigie at the café Terreux which is the half way house between here and Havre. Lebas the wine merchant gave me two coins

ns0:div.ns0:head: 18.9.1881 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Etretat September 18. 1881. Sunday

Dreadful storm going on this evening. The lightning is the finest I have ever seen, red, green, purple, sky blue, and reminds one of that described by Bulwer Lytton in his „Last days of Pompei“ It is also raining hard and although it is calm till about 10 or 11 and till then there is not a breath of wind and the thunder is the only noise the wind rises in the night and blows with great fury

ns0:div.ns0:head: 19.9.1881 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Etretat September 19. 1881 Monday
Rain still continues and wind blowing hard and moaning as if it’s last day had come

ns0:div.ns0:head: 22.9.1881 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot September 22. 1881 Thursday
I arrived here today from Etretat. I travelled with a young lady called Stromeyer I came by Southampton and Havre.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 6.7.1880 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ems 6 July 1880

Today Papa and I take a carriage and had ourselves driven to Millen at the entry of the Schweizerthal There we got out and walked. When we came in to it the beginning of the Schweizerthal was two high rocks on each side the road only being about 2 yards wide and a torrent with cascades at allmost every half yard crashing down from the mountain we have to ascend. The rocks on each side were allmost nude with only here and there a birchtree, and of a yellowy colour probably coming from the sulfur settled here since centurys. Little by little the pass widens itself on a clapp-clapp noise like that coming from a mill reached our ears. We reached the mill and then went on a little path to the righ. The scenery allways gets grander as we mount. On our way up we met a postman that had been to Frücht and was coming back again Poor man; he has to go to Frücht twice a day on foot rain or no rain, and rain is no joke in this thal for there are times where one has water up to one knees and these occasions are not rare. When we got up to Frücht we wanted to go and see Steins, the great german minister’s, grave
Schwanthaler only we could not get in. In coming back Papa allmost broke his leg in falling down the mountain

ns0:div.ns0:head: 24.9.1881 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot 24 September 1881. Saturday
Tried for the choir I, Wormald mi, Bald mi, and Long got in. I am also in the 1st devision

ns0:div.ns0:head: 26.9.1881 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot 26 September 1881 Monday
Played cricket today it is very fine weather. I laughed in the second hour over Jay, and Schuster saying their lessons

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 29.9.1881 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot 29 September 1881 Thursday

Today being Michaelmas we walked to Caesar’s camp which is about 6 miles from here. There is a treble moat around it but it is now mostly overgrown by trees, ferns and underwood and the third moat is not very visible. We played at storming the third moat one side (Waterhouse’s) dressed in stripes and our side (Olliver’s) had black and the cross we had to take a flag which was in the middle of the camp. Some boys picked some Michaelmas daisies. I got my coin. M rs Kynnersley’s fine horsemanship very nearly ended tragically in driving round a corner and smashed her splashboard throwing a cushion out of the chaise I was very tired when I got home. Some Eton-fellows came too

ns0:div.ns0:head: 5.10.1881 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot Oct. 5. 1881. Wednesday
We played our first game of football today. The „Terrapin pool“ a well is getting very deep and the water is coming in fast.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 11.10.1881 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot Oct 11. Tuesday

Aestheticum in aesthetico! The essence of aestheticism has arrived here in the person of a M r Cust. He is a small, measly looking man who wears a great big bunch of yellow everlastings bursting out of his coat looking as if it meant to hide the rest of his chest; in the left hand pocket of his coat he wears a faded cerise coloured little handkerchief; around his neck under a tiny bit of a collar is an old gold tie which takes it in turns to go round his neck with the cerise coloured one. His hair is rather long and curled and his whole person is flabby and faded. In fact according to his own words he is quite too utter.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 14.10.1881 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot Oct 14. 1881

A dreadful wind has blown in the night and lots of branches have been blown off the trees it has also rained hard. Parnell has been arrested. He was in bed. The Irish papers are all inflamed at the cowardice of the english nation towards their martyred leader as they say.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 15.10.1881 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot. 15 October. 1881 Saturday

We were to go to Hampton court, where we were to lunch with M r Hodgekin today but as it hailed and rained we went to London instead. In the train we thought we would have our dinner so just as we had taken out our things we arrived at a station and heard the guard crying „All change for London“ so out we had to get holding our bread in our hands but we managed to finish our dinner in the other carriage. We got to Waterloo at 2 o’clock whence we drove to the Savoy theatre in a bus to see Patience
Sullivan a most intensely utter play in the aesthetic line. It is chiefly written in an incomprehensibly tatoo language. There were some good jokes as when Bunthorne says „Then a sentimental passion of a vegetable fashion must excite your languid spleen. An attachment à la Plato for a bashful young potato“ „By hook and crook you try to look both angular and flat“ But the best is when the Mayor says in a most agonizing fashion after standing in a very intensely aesthetic attitude „I wonder what the inner Brotherhood usually recommend for cramp“ The colonel also sharply remarked that to be aesthetic was to be angular and flat After the theatre we walked down Piccadily without a poppy or a lily as the people in the play did. We had chocolat Grange not mango and got home at about 7½. I am growing intense

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 16.10.1881 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot October 16. 1881. Sunday
I am utterly consummately intense wearing sun flowers and poppies and dahlias in my button hole.

ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot. 24 October 1881. Monday
We went for a short paperchase preparatory to the one on Wednesday. The hares were caught by Watson

ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot 25 October 1881 Tuesday
We dug in the afternoon. The covering over Old Terrapin pool is very nearly finished. The new Terrapin pool is getting on very well

ns0:div.ns0:p: Ems 10 July 1880
Today Marie’s mother went back to Winsen where she lives and is from there going to Hamburg

ns0:div.ns0:head: 26.10.1881 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot 26 October 1881. Wednesday
Went for the real paperchase. It was about 6 miles. The hounds were again caught by Watson who also came in first. I came in 8 th .

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 28.10.1881 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot 28 th October. 1881. Friday. S t Simons and S t Jules

We walked to Windsor where we had tea at ayton’s the confectioners. At the castle I adressed a sentinel in broken French and english „Monsieur, la chapelle when çà openait. In walking home we sung „κρειττον σιωπαν εστιν η λαλειν ματην“"Zu Schweigen ist besser als unnütz zu reden." Sprichwort aus einer griechischen Komödie, überliefert bei Stobaios. and „Instant ardentes Tyrii pars ducere muros
Vergil, Aeneis, 1. Buch, Vers 423: "Mit Feuereifer gehen die Tyrier ans Werk: teils Mauern zu ziehen.".“ We got home very tired. I bought some luminous paint at Eton

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 29.10.1881 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot 29 October 1881.
Waterhouses uncle came to day his name is M r Hodgekin

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 1.11.1881 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot Tuesday 1 November 1881

We went to Guildford today. We started from here by the 11.15 train. We had to change at Woking where we had to wait a quarter of an hour and arrived at Guildford at 1. On the way the Head Sneyd-Kynnersley read Chryssies Heros
Lyster which is rather a good book. At Guildford we had dinner at the White lion inn over the door of which a great big whitewashed plaster lion was stuck up. It is rather a picturesque town especially as the street goes rather uphill and as a large clock projects into it. There is an old grammar school of the time of Edward VI. I bought some photographs of the town at Guildford. after dinner we walked to the chalk pits to find fossils but as there was more stone than chalk in the pits there were no fossils.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 2.11.1881 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot 2 Nov 1881. Wednesday.

There was a paperchase today the Head Snyd-Kynnersley , Wormald ma. and Hichens ma. being hares. We first went down the lane at the back of the cottage; but we soon lost scent and it took us some time to find it back after that the scent went over some fields into a small forest. Then near a rat trap we again lost scent and this time it took us a very long time to find it after this one did not again lose it. I came in 7 th 4 min. after the 1st hound

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 5.11.1881 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot 5th November 1881. Saturday.

Fireworks this evening on account of Guy Fawkes. Hurrah for Guy Fawkes! However we did not burn Guy Fawkes but rather Parnell and Guiteau who exploded very well; well we (the 1st div.) let off the fireworks; we each had some fireworks which we sent off to the best of our powers which were not great. The cads threw stones and squibs at us which however did not hurt us. By the by they (the fireworks not the cads) began by a shell which went off beautifully. After this we had supper and games.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 9.11.1881 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Went to Surbiton today where we had dinner with M r Hodgkin After that we went on the Thames I also rowed and towed. At Hampton Court we saw a lot of pictures. After that we tried to see the vine which was shut;Im Garten des Hampton Court Palace befindet sich der „Great Vine“, ein Weinstock, der 1768 gepflanzt wurde und der größte in ganz England ist. after that we went into the gardens and walked about; We came home at 7. 30.

ns0:p.ns0:note: Ende des Heftes.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 12.11.1881 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot . 12. November. 1881. Saturday.

This morning we started for the choir expedition. We went down to London by the 8.45 train and got there about 9. We directly took 2 busses and drove to the Houses of Parliament but finding that they were not yet open we went in to Westminster Abbey where we heard the beginning of the morning service. Then we went back to the houses of Parliament and were let in by the Victoria tower. The rooms were splendid, decorated with frescos, gilding, woodcarving and other ornaments. We first came to the queens Victoria I. robing room in which there is a very fine throne. We then went through various smaller rooms and at last came to the where we saw another very fine throne. All the seats are covered with red leather. then we were taken through various passages decorated with beautiful frescoes to the house of Commons which looks very mean after the house of Lords. We there saw the bar by which Bradlaugh had been stopped the last time he tried to enter the house by force. Then we went into a law court where Lord Coleridge was sitting. Bradlaugh was also there. He looked very fat and mean and altogether disgusting. We afterwards went into some more law courts and into the court of exchequers where rather an amusing case. about forgeing a signature, was going on. Westminster hall struck me as being a very fine place. We afterwards went down the Thames to London-bridge in the same boat as Gladstone. We then saw a chrysanthemum show said to be the finest in the world; some of the chrysanthemum were very pretty. We also bought some tortoises and other reptiles at Greens in Covent Garden. We had a very good dinner a 2/ a head at the Horse Shoe hotel. Then we walked to the Prince of Wales’ theatre and saw the „Colonel“ Burnand which takes the aesthetes off beautifully. After the Colonel we went to Madame Tussauds and saw the wax works. I was quite taken in by a wax policeman. We then drove for to a chemists where we ordered some Sodium and some potash for experiments; then we drove to Waterloo station and took the train to Ascot where we arrived at about 10.30. Those of the choir who are in the first div. (I included) went down to the terrapyn pool house and put the animals we had bought at Green’s into and round about it and afterwards had some „negus“ and went to bed. We posted a letter, to Mackenzie, signed Eliza WicksVon den Schülern erfundene Person. who is supposed to be an old friend of his mothers. He firmly believes in her.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 13.11.1881 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot November 13. 1881. Sunday

The hot water pipes being ready this morning we had chapel. We went for a walk with the Head Sneyd-Kynnersley to see M r Holness this afternoon but did not find him at home. Mackenzie still believes in M rs Wicks.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 16.11.1881 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot. November. 16. 1881. Wednesday.

Went for a paperchase this afternoon. It was rather windy so that it was difficult to find the scent. When we got near Standishes the scent was quite blown away so that we had great difficulty in finding it again. After that there were but few more good checks. I came in 3d but the hares were not caught.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 11.7.1880 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: In the train 11 July 1880

In coming out of Ems we passed Nassau with it’s Castle and the Stein denkmal
Pfuhl , Balduinstein a big castle in the renaissance style, Schaumburg and burg Schwalbach. At Diez Sophie who went home was met by her cousin who allways appears at all possible and impossible occasions to see her. After Diez we came to Limburg with its six towerd Dom. The scenery was lovely something like the australian gold mines and darling downs.Then we come to Marburg where the scenery changes. Marburg is a pretty little town with it’s Elisabethencirche and it’s castle: It is lainDas Wort "lain" ist mit Bleistift durchgestrichen, dafür wurde "situated" gesetzt. on a hill like a crown. From Marburg we pass by great plains with allmost nothing growing on them but pines, poplars and grass. Just before Treysa we have to stop before station because there is something on the line We then saw the Fulda and Wilhelmshöhe, which one can perfectly well see from the train, and directly after Cassel where we have 1 hour and 29 minutes stoppage. Papa, Mamma and I go in to town at Cassel and see the promenade with it’s Bellevue and the barracks of the Husaaren with „Wilhelmus elector condidit“Vom Kurfürsten Wilhelm I. von Hessen erbaut. written on their door. We had a luggagecarrier to take us through the town. As a remark the streets are paved with pointed stones instead of being paved with asphalt which luxury the promenade alone enjoys. Poor Mamma got a sore foot in walking in the streets. We then pass by forests and over the Egge gebirge. We in our whole journey had to change 3 times at Cassel, at Warburg and at Altenbeken We whereDas h ist nachträglich mit Bleistift gestrichen. two minutes late.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 20.11.1881 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot November 20. 1881. Sunday

Very fine weather. M r May the dentist came to examine our teeth in the afternoon. I did not have mine examined. Later on we went and sat in a railway carriage where the Head Sneyd-Kynnersley read us „Chrysie’s Hero
Lyster .“ M r Tahourdin White, John came to preach this evening.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 25.11.1881 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot 25 Nov. 1881. Friday

It has rained hard all the night and it is still pouring. There were .42 of an inch of rain in the night. Mackenzie has got a second letter from M rs WickeVon den Schülern erfundene Person; vgl. den Eintrag vom 12.11.1881. and quite believes in her. Mortimer mi. has been turned out of the choir for telling lies and cheeting

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 27.11.1881 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot 27 November 1881. Sunday

There was a dreadful gale of wind and .30 inches of rain in the night by our new rain gauge. The rain is very curious; it begins down by the railway arch and comes rushing up towards the house like a whirlwind and soon it is raining over the whole country

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 29.11.1881 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot. 29 November. 1881. Tuesday
Walked to Windsor today or rather we drove there and thence to Slough where we saw Aldin house. We walked home and got there about 9. We pretended to be burglars attacking the cottage

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 3.12.1881 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot 3 December 1881. Saturday

Again drove to Eton where we were again photographed. We walked home; it was a beautiful moonlight night. At Windsor we saw a cheap Jack from whom we bought a carving knife and fork and knife sharpener for 1 s the lot. We told Mackenzie about M rs WickeVon den Schülern erfundene Person. and had a good laugh. We walked home crying out „goodnight“ with a loud voice to all who passed us.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 4.12.1881 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot. 4 December 1881. Sunday.
This morning we were told that another rat had been caught so we went down to terrapin house and drowned him and afterwards buried the poor thing.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 5.12.1881 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot 5 December 1881
There was an eclipse of the moon which was almost total in London but which we went out too late to see for it was over before 8.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 6.12.1881 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot 6 December 1881
We played Prisoners Base this afternoon. M rs Kynnersley came back today.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 9.12.1881 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot. December 9. 1881 Friday

The printed Gazettes came today just in time for the concert; there was a tremendous sale of them and 50 more have been ordered. My march went off allright I am glad to say. Lots of people came. There was a great muddle in the accounts of the Gazette in the evening they began by being about 15 shillings and ended by going up to 16 something like 18./.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 10.12.1881 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot December 10. 1881

Today we had a regular good snowstorm. It is golly; it looks like Christmas. Some more Gazettes were sold. In the afternoon as it was too snowy to go out and too sloshy to snowball we cooked in the carpenters shop

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 18.6.1880 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ems 18 June 1880 Sun rises 3,44, sets 8,17

Papa and I this morning go up the Malberg without taking the way up but by climbing straight up the mountain, the heat is torrid and we are soon as if we had been dipped in a bath; from the tower which is situated on the top of the mountain the vew is lovely on the first plan Ems, the Lahn and the Concordiathurm on which we were yesterday, on the second the silverworks and mines, Chemna Kemmenau , and the road to Nassau and lost in the far horizont the Rheinthal, castel Stolzenfels, a ruin and the Taunus itself. This afternoon there has been a storm with thunder, lightening rain and every thing to complete it as if the weather before setting to „Kaiserwetter“ which means emperorsweather because the emperor allways has fine weather when he arrives; wanted to have one more good rage.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 12.7.1880 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Pyrmont 12 July 1880

We (Papa and I) visit the palace of the princes of Waldeck this morning. This palace is lain Das Wort "lain" ist mit Bleistift durchgestrichen, dafür wurde "situated" gesetzt. in the Anlagen and surrounded by a wide ditch We crossed the bridge and arrived at the great iron gate which a man opened; this man told us that the prince of Waldeck did not live here and only very rarely came even in the summer, and that he had been here the last year, but not yet this year and that his residence was Arolsten. This palace was built in 1562 and rebuilt in 1706, it sufferd many sieges in the 30 years war He then took us on the walls who’s date of erection one does not know but which one thinks to be very old. On these walls there is a beautyfull allee Kessler hat nachträglich mit Bleistift zu "beautiful alley" verbessert. of old trees and at it’s extremity there is an old tree which is supposed to be 700 years old and who’s branches are kept together with chains which are supposed to have been put on a hundred years ago. This tree has six meters round and its roots go right in to the water and have made a regular mountain of the earth. It’s branches touch the ground and spring up again like new trees so that when you are under the tree you are in a regular little forest The man then shewed us the bed of the count of Gleichen and his two wivesSeine wirkliche Frau, Gräfin von Orlamunde, und die sarazenische Prinzessin Melechsala, die ihm das Leben gerettet haben soll., which is immensly high and big and all sculpted; at each corner there is a little angel looking in to it and at one of the ends there are three heads and two casks
Kessler hat nachträglich mit Bleistift statt "casks" das Wort "helms" gesetzt.. It is all full of worms the wall of the room in which it is is all painted with views of different places and there is one picture by Tischbein representing the Count of Gleichen and his two wives All the rest of the furniture is made of common unpealed wood like you find on the ground in the forest. Our man then shewed us an underground passage which is said to go right under the waterworks; we then returned and in the afternoon went to the Jägerbuche a tree somewhat like the one in the castle but only smaller. From this beach there is a lovely view and one is supposed to see the Hermannsdenkmal
Bandel but we did not see the least scrap of it

ns0:div.ns0:head: 11.12.1881 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot December 11. 1881
It is thawing although the pond is a little frozen. M r Edwards minor canon of S t Georges chapel came for two services today.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 12.12.1881 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot December 12. 1881.
Trials began today; we had Scripture, Arithmetic, Latin Prose and History. I dug in the afternoon and brought stones to the Head Sneyd-Kynnersley in a barrow.

ns0:p.ns0:note: Zwischen den Seiten ist das Chorprogramm vom 9. Dezember 1881 eingeklebt.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 13.12.1881 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot Dec 13. 1881

This evening Mackenzie got so bewildered between Algebra and Euclid and the accounts of the St Georges school Gazette that he began writing down something about alternate angles in the account book instead of M rs Schusters adress.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 14.12.1881 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot Dec 14. 1881
We played prisoner’s base this afternoon. We also had some trial papers.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 16.12.1881 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot Dec. 16. 1881. Friday

We finished trials today to my great satisfaction; although they ended with a horrid paper which was not to my satisfaction. The Gazette came. We drove to Windsor in the afternoon where we went to Liuff’s the Publishers, and drove home at about 5 o clock.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 17.12.1881 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot Dec. 17. 1881.

We spent part of the morning in ordering books and burning old ones that were no more good. It was delightful to burn the old Latin Grammars. But we made such a mess that the Head Sneyd-Kynnersley told Kylfoyle to burn them instead of us. The prizes came. We played charades in the afternoon the first word was „incapable“. The first scene of the play was a robber pickpocketing two travellers in an inn. In the second the cap is brought as evidence against the robber and in the third his accomplice the waiter informs him that he is able to give him up to the police The second word was „cardinal“ but this play was not as good.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 19.12.1881 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot December. 19. 1881

Had a game of Prisoners base and Rounders in the morning. There was Reading over in the afternoon Papa and aunt Rose Lynch came. I got the French Prize „The Source of the Nile“ by Speke. The following was the Report

ns0:p.ns0:note: Hier ist der Bericht eingeklebt. Es folgt die Abschrift, wobei nicht alle Formatierungen übernommen wurden.

ns0:div.ns0:p: S. George’s School, Ascot.
TRIALS, CHRISTMAS, 1881.
Report of the Examiner, Rev. F. W. Macdonald, M.A., Queen’s College, Oxford.

To begin with the English Subjects, the Scripture which required considerable thought, was fairly done throughout: In Div. I., Olliver’s paper was a long way the best. I was much pleased with the neatness and good writing of Div. II.
The History was satisfactorily answered, but the knowledge of important dates is still weak. Blundell must pay more attention to History.
In Geography, Div. III. was weak.

The Mathematical papers were not done quite as well as last time, there not being the same evenness in work: I think the maximum standard too high, and that it would be best to fix a lower standard for each set, and to work all the boys up to it; the elementary work was good: progress has been made in Euclid and Algebra.

In French, Set I. did well, but unevenly, some boys being far ahead of others. To Set II. the same remark applies. The Grammar was excellent, but the Translation weak. The Pronunciation of those boys whom I examined vivâ voce is very good.

With regard to Classical Subjects: - In Grammar, the papers were throughout the School well answered: Div. I. showed a marked advance in critical knowledge: Div. II failed to give the English of the different examples; their parsing was very good. Olliver in Div. I., Thomson in Div. II., and Tottenham in Div. III., were particularly good in Greek Grammar.

In Latin Translation, all Divisions did well. In Div. I., Mackenzie must be more careful. In Div. II., Bowring, Thomson, Watson, and Hichens. made good attempts at Unseen. Palk spoiled a capital paper by omitting this. In Div. III., Pilcher is to be particularly commended.
In Greek Translation, Div. I. A. did satisfactorily; Mackenzie showed great improvement and Waterhouse did a good paper. Div. II. have made progress.
The Unseen Translation paper in Div. I., was done much better than last time. Olliver’s paper was remarkably good.
The Latin Verses were poor. Div. III. has has improved in Prosody rules.

The Latin Prose, throughout all Divisions, shows marked improvement. Olliver, in Div. I., did a capital piece, as did Thomson, in Div. II., and Pilcher, in Div. III. More progress has been made in this subject than in any other.
The Greek Prose of Div. I. quite came up to my expectations, and showed improvement, the competition being very close.
I have been struck by the good work done throughout the examination by Olliver, and with the progress made since last Trials by Palk and Pearse.

To sum up, there has been the same neatness and correct spelling displayed as on former occasions; the Standard has been as high, but the work, generally, has not been so level as at last Trials, when the evenness was particularly noticeable. It would be well not to raise the standard of work to suit any particular boys, but having fixed a maximum for the Term to work each individual boy up to it. The standard of work now, is quite high enough for boys of this age, and the Head and his Staff have reason to congratulate themselves on the result of their teaching,
(Signed)
F. W. Macdonald, M.A., Oxon,
Vicar of Stapleford and Berwick, Wilts.

ns0:p.ns0:note: Zwischen den Seiten, nach dem letzten Eintrag, liegt eine Beilage: In die Umschlagseiten eines Cahierheftes sind zwei Programme des Schulchores eingeklebt. Vorne steht in Kesslers Hand: „Memoires de Harry de Kessler“. Auf die Innenseite sind zwei Wappen eingeklebt. Das erste zeigt das Schulwappen, darunter von Kessler: „Arms of the school“. Das zweite ein Piktogramm von einem Umschlag, darunter: „little fantaisie crest Mamma sends me on a letter“.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 20.12.1881 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris December 20. 1881. Tuesday
Arrived here after a pretty rough passage. Got Home at about 7 o’clock. Had some breakfeast went to bed and rested for about one hour

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 24.12.1881 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris December 24 1881. Saturday

Went to uncle Willie’s Auffm' Ordt, Wilhelm
Christmas tree. He gave me a cravat pin and uncle Clement Auffm' Ordt a Shakspeare which will have to be exchanged as I have already got one. Had a bad headache

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 25.12.1881 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris December 25. 1881. Sunday

Had our own Christmas tree. I got a lovely coin cabinet with Vernis Martin plaques from Grandmamma Lynch, Caroline . Thiers History of the Revolution and a lot of Roman coins (all those from Caesar to Constantine the Great Konstantin I. ) from Papa and Mamma. Little Siefert came and got Lesage’s „Gil Blas“ and „Diable Boiteux“ from Papa. Had a very nice dinner and went to bed rather tired.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 13.7.1880 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Pyrmont 13 Juli 1880

This morning the band brought us a Stänchen which was composed of the following peaces"Peaces" wurde nachträglich mit Bleistift zu "pieces" verbessert. „Einleitung and Brautchor“ of Lohengrin „Le Bouquet“ „ Wer weisz ob wir uns wiedersehn? “ Waldmann „Boccacio walze“ Strauß „ Blau Veilchen “ This afternoon Mamma and I brought Papa to the station. We came back in the hôtel omnibus with some tiny Jews who’s noses seemed like a house hung on to a balloon. Many an eagles beak must have envied them! This afternoon we had an awfullDas zweite "l" ist nachträglich mit Bleistift gestrichen. thunder storm the bouquet of which was a knockDas Wort "knock" wurde nachträglich mit Bleistift gestrichen und stattdessen "bang" gesetzt. like that when a racket goes up. Poor Baby Brion, Wilma who’s criminality was endeavouring to throw her bricks at me as a pass time instead of shiyng them jumped over the bricks and ran away

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 31.12.1881 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris December 31. 1881

Papa and I went to the Châtelet in the evening to see the „Mille et une nuits“ Artus
which was very pretty; at the end of the 1st act there were a lot of women, dresses in silver cloth, which looked like a mass of diamants in the light hung up in the air going about as if they were swimming right up at the top of the stage for we were supposed to be under water; this is how it is managed: the woman is hung to the bottom of a cart which goes about on rails above the curtain and as the thread by which she is tied up is invisible it looks as if she was swimming or flying. The whole of the piece was very pretty. The smile of Cleopatra. and the infernal hunt after Aladins lamp were specially well got up. I came home in 1882.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 1.1.1882 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris January 1. 1882. Sunday

I and Alroine went to the Porte S t Martin to see the „Biche au bois“ Cogniard this afternoon. It was not as good as „Les Mille et une Nuits“ which I saw yesterday but still it was very good. In the last scene 8 live lions come on the stage. I bought one of Callot’s picture books in coming home, and had ices at the „Café Napolitain“. Last year was an eventful year and what I quite forgot to mention in my diary: we were made counts.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 4.1.1882 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris January 4 1882 Wednesday

drove to the cirque Fernando after dinner. It began very late in fact not till 8 ½. We bought some oranges which we threw to or rather at the performers. A thing that was quite new was that a boy dressed in a waterproof got on to a stag and a rain of fire was showered down upon him and the stag. I have now got to the 4th volume in Thier’s Revolution and I like it infinitely better than Guizot’s

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 8.1.1882 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris January 8. 1882 Sunday

Went to the Gaite’
Théâtre de la Gaîté-Montparnasse , where they are acting „Quatre-vingt-treize“ Meurice , with Sophie. It is a war piece and there are some fine scenes in it, the best of which are when Gawain is comdemned to death and when he is beheaded. In coming home we were astonished to see a great crowd of „badauds“ assembled on the boulevards before a watchmakers shop above whose door was painted a huge clock. In my astonishment and my inquisitiveness I went up to one of the gravest looking people of the crowd to find out the reason of it; he quite seriously answered that that clock, pointing to the one above the door, was going to change the colour of it’s face. I laughed and went away! and this was the reason for a large crowd for I know the man told me the truth because everybody was talking and wondering what colour the clock would turn.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 12.1.1882 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris January 12. 1882. Thursday

The little Siefert came to breakfast. We afterwards amused ourselves by playing chess and driving to the bois where we took off our hats to everybody whom we did not kow, and they took off theirs. We afterwards had tea or rather chocolate at home.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 14.1.1882 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris January 14. 1882. Saturday

Drove to the Bouffes-Parisiennes after dinner where they are acting „La Mascotte“ Audran . It is now about the 400th night of it. There are some pretty airs in it. I did not go to bed till about 1 o’clock in the morning.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 15.1.1882 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris January 15. 1882 Sunday
Little Siefert came today. Drove to to the bois with him, Mamma and Papa and walked down the champs Elysées the carriage following us. Papa took a turkish bath.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 16.1.1882 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris January 16. 1882 Monday

Went to the Opera tonight with Papa where we saw the „comte d’Ory“ Rossini and the „Korrigane“ Widor . The latter was very pretty. The building is splendid with its staircases and its agat railings, its foyer and its balcony.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 17.1.1882 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris January 17. 1882 Tuesday.
We got some tickets for the chambre des députés but could not get in there not being any today.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 18.1.1882 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris January 18. 1882
Went to the photographers in the morning. I very nearly fainted there and had to be brought home in a cab lying down. Went to bed directly I got home and dozed a little

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 17.7.1880 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Pyrmont The 17 July 1880

Today is the 17 of July and Mamma’s birthday and poor Bee Brion, Wilma is not at all well she has had a very bad night We have to go away from the Badehôtel where our rooms are let and go to Ockel to add to the confusion. Baron von Weida (po-n) is coming. I have to go to the station to fetch him.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 19.1.1882 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris January 19. 1882
Great crash at the bourse. All the shares going down to almost nothing. Mamma lost almost all her money. We gave a ball. I had to sleep in another room.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 22.1.1882 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: London January 22. 1882 Sunday
Started from Paris by the 9.30 a.m. train for London. Got a deck cabin and had a lovely crossing. Gee got up early to see me before I went.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 23.1.1882 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: London January 23. 1882.

Went to the pantomime at Drury Lane. Saw „Robinson Crusoe" Defoe in which there were a great many jokes about the liberal government such as: a policeman asked a clown if he knew what they did with people who bribed „Yes“ answered the clown „they make members of parliament of them.“

ns0:div.ns0:head: 24.1.1882 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot January 24. 1882
Arrived at Ascot. Uncle Craigie notwithstanding his bad leg came to see me at Grandmamma’s Lynch house before I went away.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 27.1.1882 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot January 27. 1882
Played Mortimer ma. in the chess tournament; had a very exciting game and beat Mortimer in the end.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 1.2.1882 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot February 1. 1882. Wednesday

We went to play flags in M r Pearse’s Kerr-Pearse grounds this afternoon. When we first went there Mortimer ma. unfortunately shied a stone at one of the cad’s so they consequently shied an avalanche of stone’s at us. I was on the black’s (Whittaker’s) side. The black’s won once by Whittaker conquering the flag alone against six fellows.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 3.2.1882 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot February 3. 1882

M r Cornish swallowed a fishbone at tea. He immediately ran out in a great fright. He had to read the service in chapel. I feared something appalling when I saw him arrive in chapel at the first sound of the bell but nothing as appalling as what did really happen. When he came in the first thing he did was to give out the hymn which was to be sung in the middle of the service before service had begun. The consequence was that when we came to the part where the hymn had to be sung there was no hymn to be sung. But this was not all; he was so „distrait“ that he read the first collect for Grace but quite forgot to read the two others and directly went on to the prayers for all conditions of men. I laughed so much that I was every moment afraid that I should burst out. and make an awful noise. Of what misfortunes an inocent fish bone can be the cause!

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 11.2.1882 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot February 11. 1882. Saturday
We ran a paper chase today. Some fellows almost got lost. The hares were not caught

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 14.2.1882 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot February 14. Tuesday 1882

Had a row in the boat on the pond in the morning with Thomson mi. Bald mi. and Littleton. The weather is lovely. Ran round the goals and cricket pith 36 times, without even stopping to walk once, for exercise; 8 times round is equal to a mile.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 15.2.1882 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot February 15. Wednesday. 1882
It was very wet today and rained the whole morning so that we could not go out.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 18.7.1880 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Pyrmont 18 July 1880

A word that has often been repeated this summer is today repeated again „Rain!“ I am writing at this very moment in my room with my umbrella open over my head for if I had it not, there would be very few traces of my writing or rather bigger ones than any one could wish to make without upsetting the inkstand. I have to stop for my umbrella is allready dripping all over the paper perfectly fulfilling its functions of a gutter which has been erected to wet you and instead of turning the rain off it is conducting it on
