ns0:div.ns0:head: 19.2.1882 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot February 19. 1882, Sunday
Sent a letter signed by all the conservative members of the school (me included) 24 in number to Lord Salisbury. The Liberals sent one to Gladstone but only got ten people to sign it.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 20.2.1882 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot. February 20. 1882. Monday
We went out for a walk with the Head Sneyd-Kynnersley and gathered moss which he means to plant in the rockery.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 21.2.1882 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot February 21. 1882
There are some cases of mumps here and the following circular has been sent round to all the people

ns0:p.ns0:note: Zwischen die Seiten ist das Zirkular (Länge 20,2 cm, Breite 12,6 cm) eingeklebt. Handschriftlich, hektografiert.

ns0:div.ns0:p: February 21st 1882
I have to inform you that four cases of Mumps, of a mild type, have appeared in the School.
The cases have been removed to the Lodge.
Should your boy catch the complaint you will be at once informed.
H. W. Sneyd Kynnersley.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 22.2.1882 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot February 22. 1882.

2 more fellows have caught the mumps. This afternoon Jay, Schuster and I went in the boat on the pond. When Jay and Schuster wanted to get out Schuster jumped out with one oar and Jay tried to get out with the other but he slipped and the boat drifted quickly away from the shore with the impulse he gave it; Jay tried to hang onto the shore by a tuft of grass but as the boat went out he was left suspended over the water with his hands clutching the grass and the tips of his feet in the boat; the only thing that remained for him to do was to jump into the pond if he didnot want to go in headforemost so he luckily did jump in and waded up to the shore.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 25.2.1882 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot. February 25. 1882. Saturday
We were to have run a paper chase this afternoon but as it was raining hard and the wind was high we did not go.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 8.3.1882 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot March. 8. 1882

M r Wood came today and gave his lecture on insects which was extremely interesting and which he illustrated by sketches with coloured crayons on a piece of black canvas on a frame. I wrote the account of it in the Gazette
St. George´s Gazette .

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 11.3.1882 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot March 11. 1882.
We went for a paperchase. I and some fellows with M r Scudamore soon lost the scent after getting over some pointed wood palings on which we tore our hands and clothes horribly, and walked home.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 13.3.1882 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot March 13. 1882

We made a bonfire of the weeds down by the rockery. At first it would not catch fire but at last we managed to light it by putting a great deal of hay under the weeds and faggots. We had a halfhour more play in the afternoon on account of the fine weather.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 18.3.1882 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot March 18. 1882 Saturday.

We started up to London by the 8.35 up train. We arrived at Waterloo at about 9.30. The Head Sneyd-Kynnersley had hired some S. W railway busses by the day, for 15/-15 Schilllings each to drive about in. We first had ourselves jolted to the Baker street bazaar where we arrived in rather the worse for wear or rather shaking, for the coachman, a cadaverous looking person, seemed to take great pleasure in driving up all „impasses“ and into all the rocks he could possibly think of or find. I suppose he was the conductor of a funeral car and was perhaps in hopes that the shaking might be fatal to one of the more delicate of our party and that he might be the driver of the funeral car. However we did arrive at Baker street without being quite turned upside down. After that we jolted on to the Zoo where we saw Jumbo. He eat a great many buns but ungratefully rejected the sack which we gave him. We saw the others fed and and went into a small house where we saw some „armadilloes.“ We then drove to M r Bald’s to have dinner. We sat over dinner till so late that we got to the theatre 20 minutes too late. We saw two pieces: „Dearer than life“ Byron and „Domestic economy“ Lemon . In the latter a labourer who was keeping his shop while his wife was out was very rude to his customers: he sent herrings and tallow candles after them and told one who complained how sticky the brandyballs were that it was because his son sucked them and put them back into the box. We afterwards drove to the South-Kensington Victoria and Albert Museum ; we saw the „Rocket“ the first steam engine ever made and the same which ran over Huskisson there. We did not get back to Ascot till a quarter to ten.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 19.3.1882 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot. March 19. 1882. Sunday
We went to the cross this afternoon where we burried a threepenny piece; the Head Sneyd-Kynnersley afterwards read the „Black Donkey“ Steele to us in a saloon carriage near Ascot station.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 23.7.1880 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Pyrmont 23 July 1880

Today Mamma and I went to the Erdfälle. These are two ponds (anciently three, only two or three years ago the separation between the two first one crumbeld) which were formed in 1645 by the crumbling of the earth the scenery around them is very pretty and rugged. This evening the prince of Waldeck arrived and dined at Goethe’s

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 20.3.1882 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot March 20. 1882. Monday.

A cow jumped into the field over the palings this afternoon while we were playing. It broke part of the palings and had to be driven out with sticks. M r Cook and M r Cornish quarrelled this afternoon; this will probably result in the departure of one of the two

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 21.3.1882 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot March 21. 1882. Tuesday

We went to the Crystal Palace electric exhibition. The electric lights were very fine. We began by trying the telephone but the man at the other end would not connect us so we shouted abusive language down it. We had dinner with M r Sellon in the Crystal Palace dining room. I sat between Miss Sellon and Jay. The finest thing we saw was the great brush light (which, by the way, is said to have hissed Gladstone when he was here, yesterday); it has a power of 150000 candles; the Alhambra court is also prettily lighted. I wrote an account of this in the Gazette
St. George´s Gazette

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 25.3.1882 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot March 25. 1882.

Being a Saints day we had the „set“ hours off this morning. In the afternoon we went for a walk with M r Kynnersley. We first went to Cranbourne tower and then had tea at Egham. A hexameter was made up about this: For eggs and ham at Egham we walked ten miles without stopping.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 27.3.1882 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot March 27. 1882.
Had a half holiday so as to be able to practice for the athletics

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 29.3.1882 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot March 29. 1882
Athletic sports today; the resul was as follows:
Senior Broad Jump, Watson 14 f. 7 in
Junior High Jump, Hichens mi 3 f. 9½
Pole Jump, Palk, 6f. 2 in
Senior 200 Yards, Bald mi, 33 sec
Senior High Jump, Watson 4 f. 1
Junior Broad „ Littleton 13 f. 3 in
Senior 100 Yards Sellon ma. 13 sec
Junior 100 „ Mortimer mi. 15½ sec
Throw. Cricketball. Watson 62. y 9 in
Senior Hurdles Bald ma
Junior „ Mortimer mi
150 Yards Handicap Menzies 24 sec
3 Legged race Hichens ma. Wormald ma.
Sack race Rowley 60 sec
Steeple chase Watson
Consolation 1 Thomson major oder minor . 2 Kessler. 3 Wormald major oder minor
I got a little gilt pencil for this last thing

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 2.4.1882 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot. April 2. 1882

I must have put my left foot out of bed first this morning. I began the day by upsetting my bath: in my endeavours to mop up the water I let down my bedclothes into the mess; I jumped up and hurried to this new scene of action and in my endeavours to put the bedclothes out of danger mixed up socks, boots, drawers, trousers, shirt, tie, jacket etc. with the bedclothes on the top of my bed, when I got to that stage of dressing in which it becomes urgent to put on some sort of clothes I tried to get my vest out of the general confusion but Alas! I was not to finish dressing quietly my bran new boots which I have never yet put on and which I meant to wear today fell into the dirty water which I had by this time elaborately mopped up with my sponge. The worst part of the whole matter was that being nude I could not call any of the maids into my room. My clean shirt was irretrievably lost in the bedclothes so I had to come down in a dirty one.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 3.4.1882 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot April 3. 1882.

Quite bewildered. Received a letter from Papa contradicting all his former statements; rushed off to Abbey with telegrams and received an answer from Papa in the afternoon. Reading over at 12.30. Did not get any prizes. Watched Richards cleaning out the pond

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 4.4.1882 Mittwoch

ns0:p.ns0:note: Kessler verschreibt sich beim Datum. Aus dem weiteren Verlauf ergibt sich, dass es sich um Dienstag, den 4. April, handelt.

ns0:div.ns0:p: London April 5. 1882. Tuesday.
Arrived at Waterloo at 9.50 and found out that I am not going to Paris this evening. Went to see „Tiny“ with Mabel who came to lunch. My luminous „Danger“ has not arrived.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 5.4.1882 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: London April 5. 1882
Carriage came at 11. Grandmamma Lynch, Caroline went to me to Bumpus’ and gave me a beautiful Macaulay in 8 volumes which cost 6 Guineas. Went to the Doré and Grosvenor Galleries after lunch.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 6.4.1882 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: London April 6. 1882 Thursday
Drove to Richmond with uncle Stephen Lynch ; there went on the launch as far as Hampton court. Grandmamma Lynch, Caroline gave a dinner party.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 24.7.1880 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Pyrmont 24 July 1880

We went to the „Dunsthöhle“ this morning It is a hole in the earth of the form of a we went down to the bottom by a staircase, at the bottom the keeper opened a little gate and we again went down a few steps to the bottom of the pit here the keeper told us to stoop a little which we did; a strong smell of carbonic acide pervaded us and we were almost suffocated for the gas was then at a heighth of about 3 feet and any living thing or person who’s respiratory organ is under that heighth would have been suffocated; in the time of the roulette lots of people used to come and lie down here to commit suicide. The keeper then took some straw lit it and plunged it in the gas at the very minute the flame went out and when he held it over the gas again it began to burn; the same thing happens to any human or living being that inhales this gas in the acid it faints and out of it it revives. The gas sometimes in less than five minutes mounts to the heighth of the second gate and higher so that one can not even get to this gate, it comes out of a cave which the man shewed us, this grotto is like the grotto of Capri in Naples with the only differences of being much smaller and there being no water here and there being some at Capri and the gas being non visible here and being visible at Naples. There are only two such places in the whole world here and at Naples. This pit here was discovered in 1724 by doctor Philippe Seife Seip, Johann and an inscription relating the fact was put there in 1740. This afternoon the were races at one of which three running two were thrown. When the labourers raced one of them fell and broke his head at the donky race the boys all fought.Hier am Ende ist ein Stück Papier eingeklebt: ca. 1,5 cm breit und 3,7 cm lang. Es sieht aus, als sei das größte Stück davon abgerissen. Es steht darauf: "N. B. Fr or"

ns0:div.ns0:head: 7.4.1882 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: London April 7. 1882 Good-Friday
Drove down to Wanstead to see Unclevermutlich Lynch, Stephen . Had dinner there at 6 and got home at a little past 10

ns0:div.ns0:head: 8.4.1882 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris April 8. 1882. Saturday
Arrived here at about 8 o’clock. M r Siefert met us. Had a pretty good crossing

ns0:div.ns0:head: 9.4.1882 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris April 9. 1882
Went to the Jardin d’Acclimatation with Papa. Rode on a great many animals

ns0:div.ns0:head: 10.4.1882 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris April 10. 1882

Went to a fancy dress ball at Madame Corchèrs; Baby Brion, Wilma dressed as a Marquise in pink with powdered hair and I as Charles Quint Karl V. in black with a gold collier. Baby was greatly admired and looked sweet.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 15.4.1882 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris April 15. 1882. Saturday

Went to a concert this evening. The first piece which was played by the author (Chaminade) who has got hair like a nigger and ought to be locked up as a malefactrice of mankind was something awful; there was no pretence at melody or harmony in it or if there was it is no flattery to the author: to begin with the „accords“ were discordant in themselves and were not connected with the next note in any way whatsoever; then the violin the base and the piano seemed to be, no not seemed to be but were playing utterly different pieces which clashed together dreadfully at times. Every particularly discordant accord was played or rather thumped louder than the rest of the piece as much as to say „There now; there is something pretty for you“ When she had finished the authoress got up looked very pleased with herself and her piece and majestically swept out of the room.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 17.4.1882 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris. April 17. 1882. Monday
Went to Cirque d’Hiver. There were some pretty good gymnasts there. It rained when we came out of the circus and we had some trouble in getting the carriage

ns0:div.ns0:head: 21.4.1882 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris April 21. 1882. Friday

Drove out with Baby Brion, Wilma in the afternoon. In the evening Papa and I went to the Opera where we saw the new opera of A. Thomas „Françoise de Rimini.“ It was only the fourth night. The story is taken out of Dante’s „Inferno“ La Divina Commedia . There are some very fine decors especially two representing different parts of the „Inferno“. But the music does by no means come up to them.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 22.4.1882 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris April 22. 1882 Saturday

M r Fichter came to dinner. After dinner we drove to the Opera comique where we saw the new play „Galante aventure.“ Guiraud It fell very short of our expectations. Neither the music nor the words are anything wonderful

ns0:div.ns0:head: 23.4.1882 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris April 23. 1882
Took Weewee Brion, Wilma to the Hippodrome. There is a very strong man there. He lifts enormous weights.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 25.4.1882 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris. April 25. 1882
Drove with papa after lunch to the rue de Turenne where he ordered a box for my coins. It will be ready in three weeks.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 7.8.1880 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: London Saturday the 7 th of August

Today we have arrived at London. We travelled on double boats they are like two steamers joined into one by a bridge and do not shake as much as the other boats. Poor Bee Brion, Wilma was sick and I think it did her good for her head seems better.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 26.4.1882 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris April 26. 1882
Went to see „Boccace“ Suppé at the „Folies Dramatiques“; the music was very pretty.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 27.4.1882 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris . April 27. 1882

Drove to the Luxembourg and St Etienne-du-mont with the little Siefert. Came back to dinner at his house. There was a meridional and his wife who dined with us. It was the first time they had been in Paris. He was quite offended when we hinted that Paris was a finer town than Marseille. He did nothing but make himself ridiculous with his „trrrs“ and his „brrrs“ and with saying that he had driven up the whole boulevard without passing the Opera and upholding it till everybody assured him that he must have passed it.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 28.4.1882 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris April 28. 1882. Friday.
Went to the Opera this evening. „Hamlet“ Thomas was given. The music was very pretty. Maurel acted beautifully. The burial scene in the last act was very touching.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 29.4.1882 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris April 29. 1882.
Papa drove to the coin merchants with me today. He bought four valuable gold coins besides some other less valuable silver ones.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 30.4.1882 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris April 30. 1882
Went to the Hippodrome this afternoon with Baby Brion, Wilma .

ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris May 1. 1882
Drove out in the morning. Started for London by 7.45 train

ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot. May 2. 1882
Arrived in London at about 6.19. Drove out with Grandmamma Lynch, Caroline in the morning. Came here by the 4.45 train

ns0:div.ns0:head: 6.5.1882 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot. May 6. 1882.
We are going to have theatricals at the end of this term

ns0:div.ns0:head: 7.5.1882 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot May 7. 1882

There was great excitement here this evening. Lord F Cavendish and Burke his secretary were murdered in Phoenix park yesterday in broad daylight in sight of a great many people among whom Lord Spencer the Lord Deputy.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 11.5.1882 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot May 11. 1882.
Some angora rabbits came this evening; one has been given to me. They are to be kept in the new place

ns0:div.ns0:head: 8.8.1880 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: London Monday the 8th August

This Morning aunt Rose had her horse brought to ride him She got up once, Satanella through her off she got on a second time this time he got up sat on his haunches and bent back like an acrobate forming a regular C When she had thrown aunt Rose off she began to kick as hard as she could so as to dash aunt Roses brains out But aunt Rose was quicker than she and was up in a minute The mare broke the reins turned the saddle and lifted the coachman and the groom up in the air.Es folgt der Eintrag vom 24. August. Ein großes X markiert hier und vor dem Eintrag vom 16. einen Einschub. Die Transkription benutzt die chronologische Reihenfolge

ns0:div.ns0:head: 12.5.1882 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot May 12. 1882

When I went down, after my music lesson, to look after my rabbit, I was told that I had not got one. At first I would not believe it but it afterwards turned out that Jay and some other fellows had been abusing me to M r Kynnersley and saying that I never took care of my rabbit behind my back. This is nothing to be astonished at as Jay is always doing things like this and I ought to have expected it in this case as he had not got a rabbit. I only tell this story to give an example of Jay’s meanness as I don’t particularly care about having a rabbit. I have been learning my part in the „Νεφελαι“Wolken Hier ist Aristophanes, Die Wolken gemeint. during the rest of the playtime this morning

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 14.5.1882 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot 14. May. 1882.

M r Kynnersley is keeping up a lively correspondence with a collection of Bishops and deans. asking them to come and preach on the 24 of June. He began by writing to the Dean of Westminster Bradley who answered that he could not come on account of some schoolchildren. He next wrote to the Bishop of Exeter Temple who has not yet answered. If he cannot get him to come he will try to get the Bishop of Truro Benson . Oxford
Mackarness is next on the list; in case these three do not come there are 26 more Bishops to be asked besides their Deans; so that a Bishop we shall have. there is a collection for the Organ on the 24 of June so that the evident object of all this bustle is a large collection. The Head Sneyd-Kynnersley reminds me of M rs Clutterbuck in „S t Antolins“ who got the Duchess to come down to the Bazaar so that all the people, who had never before seen a Duchess, should come and buy. And of the other scene: M rs Clutterbuck has an Orchestra established in the Church of St Antolin’s, on the opening day, to play at every pause in the service

ns0:div.ns0:head: 16.5.1882 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot May 16. 1882.

There was a half holiday for us to be able to go to the review at Aldershot. We saw the Queen very well. I must say she looked very grumpy and did not seem to like the driving about business at all. I could not get to sleep for some time this evening thinking of poor Baby Brion, Wilma who is not well.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 18.5.1882 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot May 18. 1882. Ascension-Day

We had a whole holiday. We went to Woking by the 11.10 train and from Woking walked to Chertsey. At Chertsey there was an Italian with a monkey; he seemed very pleased at my speaking a few words of Italian to him. After tea I fenced with Palk and went down to the pond railings to help M r Kynnersley to make the fountain.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 23.5.1882 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot May 23. 1882
My Birthday. Got a large coin box. And also a coin from Papa

ns0:div.ns0:head: 24.5.1882 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot. May 24. 1882

Curious sounds were heard last night. They were supposed to be burglars; but I do not see anything very alarming in an old woman waking up the stable boy at dead of night and asking where „Joseph was.“

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 27.5.1882 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot May 27. 1882.

M r Wood came and gave a lecture on Life under water. It was most interesting. He told us that the whale had small eyes and ears but that artists often gave them enormously long pointed ears and big eyes. I afterwards found an illustration of this ignorance in his own „Fishes“.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 3.6.1882 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot. June 3. 1882

We walked to Windsor. The whole of Eton is decorated with flags, and garlands, and hangings which were rather spoilt by the torrents of rain which came down at about 5 o’clock. We had Strawberry ices and Strawberry messes and spunge cakes at Layton’s. We thought we had better drive back as it might rain but as soon as we got in to Windsor Park it was perfectly fine.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 7.6.1882 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot June 7. Wednesday 1882.

We went round to look out for tramps this evening. We first went and burnt some magnesium wire before the different luminous paint pictures; after this we went on the heath and there watched some Gipsies undressing and going to bed. I heard one of the women say „I was all a-shiverin’ and a’shiverin’ with the cold today; and I was so uncomfortable ’cause I ’adn’t washed today; but Lizzie was all right ’cause she ’ad“. We burnt some Magnesium wire before them and they directly extinguished their fire. After this we went up the bog road and as we were throwing detonators someone hit an old man who was sitting on a fence; it did not go off nevertheless the old man got into a tremendous rage, and ran after us; thereupon there was a scramble to get over the garden gate which was locked. We all got over safely as the old man is supposed to have fallen; but I did not see him do so.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 8.6.1882 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot June 8. 1882.
Went to the races to see the cup run; Foxhall won. The Pilcher hoax is getting on splendidly; he has had a letter from the necropolis and an avalanche of parcels

ns0:div.ns0:head: 16.8.1880 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: London 16 August 188
today we receive news of Mis Nelsons Death who died in the night from the 14 to 15 of spasmes of the heart.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 14.6.1882 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot June 14. 1882 Wednesday

We went up to London by the 9.21 train. We had orders for the Bank of England so we directly drove to it in a Roadway ’Bus’. From there we went to S t Paul’s meaning to go up into the ball; but as service was going on we were not able to. At two o’clock we had lunch at M rs Cowan’s and soon after dinner went to hear the debate on the „Prevention of crime bill“ in the House of Commons. Healy spoke best; he spoke against the bill. Gladstone was there but did not speak. We had tea at Grange’s the place which Waterhouse so inappropriately described as a „hole“ in the Gazette St. George´ Gazette. We then walked to the Strand theater Royal Strand Theatre where we saw the „Mascotte“ Audran . I liked the music better this time than when I saw it in Paris although the acting in London cannot be compared to the acting in Paris. We took cabs to Paddington from where we went to Windsor. It was a little past one o’clock when we got there. Two cabs were at the station waiting for us; the horses did not seem to like going out so late at night at all. When we got home we had supper consisting of broth, biscuits and wine. It was now half past two in the morning; we were rather alarmed at supper by finding Whittaker missing; but he soon came in looking very cold: he had gone to sleep in the cab; the cabman had not noticed him and had driven a good way from here when Whittaker woke up. I found a letter from Grandmamma Lynch, Caroline on the kitchen table. It was about a quarter past three when I got into bed. „Sis“ died.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 15.6.1882 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot June 15. 1882. Thursday.

Sis’ funeral took place. The order of the procession was as follows: first came the hearse, (the hearse was a whealbarrow on which was placed a hutch on top of the hutch was placed the coffin, both hutch and coffin being entirely covered by a large black shawl, strewn with white pinks), with Schuster tolling the bell on one side of it and Jay carrying the spade on the other; next came the two mourning coaches with rabbits inside, next came I vainly smelling an onion, and last of all M r
and M rs Kynnersley, M rs Macdonald and Miss Macdonald. We went the most round about way we could, the little rabbits enjoying themselves prodigiously and munching away at some ferns all the time then „Sis“ was let into the family vault: but at that moment the smell was so overpowering that the coffin was quickly let down, tilted over and covered with earth. A square headstone has been ordered with the inscription: HERE LIES „SIS“ A FAITHFUL RABBIT. BORN APRIL 3 1878, DIED JUNE 14 1882.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 16.6.1882 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot June 16. 1882
I have now kept my diary two years. We had a very big game of cricket in the second game as all the fellows not in the eleven played in it so as to let the 11 practice in the 1st game

ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot June 17. 1882
Played Ascot Heath School. We won by 7 wickets; the following are the scores

ns0:div.ns0:head: 23.6.1882 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot. June 23. 1882

We went to Bagshot by train and from there walked to Camberley tunnel and there had dinner. consisting of meat sandwiches with yorkshire relish, ginger beer, buns, biscuits and oranges. We afterwards lit up the tunnel and went to the tower where an old man (I believe he was an impostor) told us we were trespassing. We got back to Bagshot early and gave the grocer back his ginger beer bottles. We were back at Ascot at about half past six. The eleven went to see the Australians play.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 24.6.1882 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot. June 24 1882. Saturday
Whole holiday. I Helped decorating the chapel and cleaning the rabbits the whole morning. Grandmamma Lynch, Caroline and aunt Rose came to lunch and chapel. M r West preached; he preached very well.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 26.6.1882 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot June 26. 1882
The whooping cough has broken out. Menzie has got it. Circulars have been sent round to the parents.

ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot July 1. 1882.
Rev. J. G. Wood gave his 2nd lecture on life under. Water.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 6.7.1882 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot July 6. 1882. Thursday.

Choir expedition. We started for Portsmouth by the 8.57 train. At Woking we had to change. We got to Portsmouth at about 1 o’clock and immediately went on board. It was raining hard all the time we were on the boat and from time to time we shipped some heavy seas; We saw the „Victory“, the frigate Nelson was killed on, in Portsmouth harbour. As soon as we got to Ryde we went to the station and went to Shanklyn. At Shanklyn we immediately took a ’buss and drove to the Chine Hotel where we unpacked our hampers and had dinner as it was too wet to picnic on the beach. After dinner we went down to the beach and up the cliffs to the Chine which is very beautiful; there is a high cascade and on each side of this cascade are huge rocks overgrown with green. When we got down on to the beach again we were attacked by a photographer who would insist upon photographing us; the group was pretty good and I ordered two copies. After being photographed we bathed. The sea was rather rough and we were frightfully knocked about; after my bath I had some trouble in getting the sand out of my feet. After this we immediately had tea; then I went down town and got some photographs and by this time it was so late that we nearly missed the train, especially as the coachman suddenly stopped and asked whether Mortimer mi. was inside the carriage. At the station we bought a large basket of strawberries for 3 shillings. On our way back we saw a great many soldiers at all the stations we passed evidently going to the war. At London we got the Evening Standard which had nothing but that a Rising was expected in Ireland, and that the English ships at Alexandria were being cleared for action, while the French government had ordered its ships to withdraw. We got home at about half past eleven.

ns0:p.ns0:note: Auf einer Seite sind zwei Fotografien eingeklebt. Die erste ist beschriftet mit „Shanklin beach“, die zweite mit „Shanklin Chine“.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 9.7.1882 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot July 9. 1882.

This evening after tea we walked to fort Belvedere, at Virginia Waters. I carried a bulls eye to attract the moths. But the moths would not be attracted and at last we almost gave up trying to catch them in despair. When we got to the fort, which has about 47 guns which would be utterly useless in case of an attack as they are turned against an unoffending orchard, we hollowed out to the old man who came running out in a great state of excitement and was by no means calmed when we only said „Good night“. We at first were afraid we were lost in the wood but we at last got home safely.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 24.8.1880 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: London 24th August

Today is Baby’s Brion, Wilma birthday. She has had lovely present grandmama Lynch, Caroline gave her a teaset and aunt Rose a frog and I some reins Mamma a house with animals Cicie Connoughltor is coming to tea today.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 13.7.1882 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot July 13. 1882
The eleven went to play the Sainsbury’s. We lost.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 19.7.1882 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot July 19. 1882. Wednesday.
The eleven played the Price’s. We lost by 20 runs.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 20.7.1882 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot July 20. 1882. Thursday.

General expedition. We started for Frimley at 11.15 a.m. As soon as we got there we walked towards the woods to look out for a nice place for picknicking; and we discovered a place which looked all right although there was no wasps or ants nest nice and handy whose inhabitants might come and help us at our dinner. There was about an hour before dinner so I and Pearse had a stroll in some very nice woods and some very nasty thorns. As soon as we saw the dinner cart we went to help to lay the table. And as soon as this was done we began dinner. After dinner M r Kynnersley and some other fellows went a long walk and did not come back in time for tea. I and those fellows who did not go with the Head Sneyd-Kynnersley made a bonfire and played rounders. It was at this stage of the proceedings that we were innocently trespassing. At about 5½ the alarm was given that we had no time to spare if we wanted to catch the train. So we ran and bustled, and I left the Head’s stick behind and got a fly into my eye and breathlessly rushed into the station and discovered that we were just half an hour early. We spent the time in laying pennies and pins on the line. As soon as we got home I ran up to the playroom and saw the drop scene which is now finished and looks very well. Further massacers expected in Egypt at Cairo.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 21.7.1882 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot July 21. 1881. Friday

We were photographed this afternoon in our parts We had three scenes photographed; The scene in which Strepsiades and Pheidippides are in bed; the scene in which I, the Mathetes, come rushing out of the house in a rage and the scene in which I am showing Strepsiades over the house.

ns0:p.ns0:note: Strepsiades, Pheidippides und Mathetes sind Figuren aus Aristophanes, Die Wolken.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 24.7.1882 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot. July 24. 1882.
Trials began. Had the Scripture Paper in the morning, and then Latin Grammar, Euclid and History.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 27.7.1882 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot. July 27. 1882

I received about the worst news I could have received today. The Head Sneyd-Kynnersley has received a letter from Papa saying that I must leave this school this term and go to some Gymnasium or something like it in Baden. I wish I could stop here for at least another term, or any time, because I can by no means relish the prospect before me. I am very sorry at having to leave this place. We had a dress rehearsal tonight. It went off pretty well, all but the last scene, which we do not know properly and which does not end up the piece nicely. So we are going to get some redlights, and are going to act the part where Strepsiades sets the house on fire.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 28.7.1882 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot . July 28. 1882.

Dictation and Vivâ voce this morning. Schuster, Mackenzie Jay and I did not change this afternoon; and instead of playing cricket we rehearsed our parts. We afterwards went down to see the swimming competition. After some hesitation I made up my mind to have a last bathe in the pond. (How I wish it was not been the last.) Tottenham won M r Bray’s medal easily and Bald ma. won the Head’s Sneyd-Kynnersly prize for the boy’s who knew how to swim before they came here.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 31.7.1882 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot July 31. 1882. Monday
Reading over and acting. I got two prizes though at reading over Schuster got one of mine and was printed as having it. the acting went off fairly though the fire scene was a failure.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 5.8.1882 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: London August 5 th 1882 Saturday.

Went out with uncle Stephen Lynch on his launch; we started from Henley and nearly got as far as Reading, which we saw in the distance. I am reading the Life of Macauley
Trevelyan for the second time. I like it better than the first time I read it.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 6.8.1882 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris. August 6 th . 1882.
We arrived here this evening after having been jolted a good deal in England and in France.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 19.6.1880 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ems 19 June 1880 Sun rises 3,44 minutes sets 8,18

The whole of Ems is in mirth today for the emperor is coming The Bahnhofstrasse"Bahnhofstrasse" ist in deutscher Schrift geschrieben. and the Bridge by which he must pass are decorated with flaggs, flowers and shields. The emperor is to arrive at a quarter past five and at five after a most awfull bustle, for the flowers mamma and Baby Brion, Wilma want to give him have not arrived, we are all ready to go and meet him. Presently I see the carriage with, mamma, papa and baby Brion, Wilma come back,: the emperor is only coming at half past six. At six deputations of school children, masters and men pass our dore, the men and boys with flaggs and drums the girls with bouquets and corn flowers Soon we also go nurse, Sophie and I in the mobb and mama, papa and Baby Brion, Wilma to the station. We place ourselves behind the schoolchildren who have made „la haie“ all down the way the emperor must pass. As the festive hour approaches the crowd gets greater and an old policeman taking his airs and graces as if he was the emperor himself making himself everybody’s laughing stock, stalks along, pushing one, shoving the other and making himself generally disagreeable. Soon a screach as if everybody was at least being murdered reaches our ears but it presently appears to be the emperor’s train that has arrived and that the screach was a mere friendly welcome All at once the old policeman begins to run about quicker, wich action is naturally accompanied by making himself more disagreeable, the emperors carriage is coming and the policemen clearing the way; now the emperors carriage comes and a hail of bouquets come down on it probably ment to put out his eyes, next to the emperor sits count Lehndorff. Behind him come all his suite in other carriages.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 25.8.1880 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: London August 25 1880

Today aunt Rose and I went to the Alexandra Palace where we saw the circus and skating the theatre of Howard Paul and the Hanlon VoltasDie "Hanlon Midgets"-Artisten Patrick Carmody, William O'Mara und John Charles Ryan waren ursprünglich Teil der aus Manchester stammenden Hanlon-Compagny und Schüler der Brüder William, George, Edward, Frederick, Alfred und Thomas Hanlon. Sie waren nicht mit diesen verwandt, führten aber dennoch den Namen Hanlon und nannten sich Robert (alias Little Bob), William und John Hanlon. Nach ihrem Ausschluss aus der Kompagnie schlossen sie sich den Brüdern Ajax und Edouin Volta an, mit denen sie gemeinsam die Artistengruppe "Hanlon-Volta" bildeten. which are very good gymnasts.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 7.8.1882 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Etretat August 7th. 1882

Arrived here this afternoon; finished the Life of Macauley
Trevelyan and began Boswell

ns0:div.ns0:head: 10.8.1882 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Etretat August 10. 1882
Went to Havre to meet aunt Carrie Craigie . They were almost all sick

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 12.8.1882 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Etretat August 12. 1882.
Papa and Mamma arrived. Gee has not been very well; poor little thing!

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 24.8.1882 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Etretat August 24. 1882. Thursday

Gee’s Birthday. She had a great many things with which she was very pleased. She is five years old; what adventurous years they have been for us. In 1877 when she was born she was just a simple Miss. In 1879 she was Baroness at her birthday and last birthday she was Countess. Went to the childrens ball, I could not get rid of Rosie Smith she stuck to me like a leech. When we came home we played at blindmans buff and poor Gee had a fall and hurt herself.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 25.8.1882 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Etretat. August 25. 1882.
Rainy morning. Staid at home. Read Boswell and also looked over some old letters of 1875 written to me, by Mamma and Papa in which Bobby Scuffler and his adventures played a very conspicuous part.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 4.9.1882 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Etretat September 4 1882 Monday

Mamma and were walking on the road to les Ifs today, when we saw some smoke coming out of a chump of trees; we walked up to them and there saw a good sized house one mass of flames; the poor people who lived in it were crying, while the people of Bordeaux were standing about gossiping and telling those whose house was burning that of course everything would be burnt but that they ought to be thankful that it did not happen in the night. The fire-engine had been sent for to les Loges and Etretat. The Loges engines arrived at about 6.30 and the bags with the folding canvas pails were immediately opened and each of us got a pail and fetched water amidst the screams of „de l’eau, allons de l’eau,“; but everything was very disorganized till we were told to make „la chaine“ that is to stand in two rows: one to pass the filled buckets to the engine, the other to pass back the empty ones. At a little past seven Mamma went away and at about half past the Etretat engine arrived but could not do much good as almost all the water in the place was exhausted, the little that was left being more or less monopolized by the Loges people. I went away at about 8.15. and met François, who took me home on the road.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 5.9.1882 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Etretat. September 5. 1882. Tuesday

Went to see the house that was burnt yesterday. Coming home we met an old pedlar who was selling baskets and who told us long stories in French and German „Ja bei Grosmotta daß war schön, ja, ja, ja, da haben wir uns amüsiert. Ja wohl mein Sohn ist Officier. Ja, ja, ja. Ich bin in der ganzen Welt gewesen. Ja, ja.. Als mein Mutter am sterben lag (with a grin) hat sie Adam gerufen und hat ihren Finger auf ihre Nase gelegt, so (putting his finger on his nose as if he wanted to flatten it) ja, ja.“ He told us his name was Adam Schmidt. He was very amusing and seemed very pleased to see his cart.

ns0:p.ns0:note: Das deutsche Zitat ist in Deutscher Schrift geschrieben.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 10.9.1882 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Etretat September 10. 1882.

Took Papa to Fécamp. I walked a good part of the way. We drove home. Mamma made me sad telling how Gee, when she was so ill in Schwalbach used to say „Oh! Mamma, write to Papa and tell him poor Tutti-putti’s going to die.“ Mab had to have a doctor to see her. He first said it was enlargement of the liver then intermittent fever.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 11.9.1882 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Etretat September 11. 1882.

Poor Mabel has got Typhoid. I am going to take some castor oil this afternoon. It never rains but it pours; how true this is. This evening at the beginning of dinner Mamma did not feel well. And just at the end aunt Carry said she felt funny: she put her hand up to her head and just had time to make two steps out of the door when I heard her fall. I rushed into the kitchen after water, and she was soon all right again.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 13.9.1882 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Etretat September 13. 1882.

Went for a walk in the afternoon. When she was undressed Gee danced a dance which she called a „Punch dance“. It was very amusing. She lurched and rolled as if she was drunk and danced like a ballet-dancer; but when she was taken downstairs to dance before everybody else she cried and would not.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 29.8.1880 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: London Sunday 29 August 1880

Today we went to Richmond with Marie, Sophie and aunt Rose on the boat. We left old Swan pier and London Bridge at three in the afternoon and after passing by Cleopatra’s Needle, the houses of Parliament and Westminster Abbey, Millbank prison, Kannella club and the castle of the Percy’s dukes of Northumberland and having been stuck in the sands six times infront of Kew gardens we arrived at Richmond where we were due at 5 at ¼ 7. One of the partys on board composed of two women and one man drank before we started, drank when we started and drank when we stopped The long nosed lady who was disgusted at everything and swamped down everything got over the „passerelle“ had to come back over the bride Yes, she prefered stopping in the boat, coming home at midnight sticking in the sands, being tortured; to risking being drowned in water her hated element had it been claret, port, gin, brandy she would have gone willingly, willingly, have been drowned But alas the fat one was first of all hoisted by one man on to the bench but on the passerelle four had to lift her and a fifth hold her and then even she fell back, like a cask of wine which has been lifted by a patent crane and whose cord has broken, and began to eject water instead of wine like a cask would have done if broken, for wine was too precious for her. We came back by trainViele Streichungen und Sofortverbesserungen.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 14.9.1882 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Etretat September 14. Thursday 1882
Went to the childrens ball this afternoon. Gee would hardly dance with anybody but me because: „You are going away tomorrow Bow.“

ns0:p.ns0:note: Der Eintrag ist mit Kopierstift geschrieben - nicht wie sonst mit schwarzer Tinte.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 15.9.1882 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris September 15. 1882

Started from Etretat at 10. Mamma, Gee, aunt Rose and Grandmamma went with me in the carriage to Les Ifs, and François on the box. The train started at 11.49 and I was very sad at parting from Mamma and dear little Gee, and Grandmamma and aunt Rose. Poor little Gee cried. I met with M rs Roberts. In the train I wrote to dear Mamma but the letter was so dirty when I was finished that I felt ashamed to send it. However Papa said he would forward it. In the evenin we dined at Lecloyens and then went to the Cirque d’été

ns0:p.ns0:note: Eintrag mit Kopierstift.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 16.9.1882 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris September 16. 1882.
Went to Cranes this morning who provoked me so, that I could have knocked him down when he said he was glad to see me. He stuffed three teeth. Started for Hamburg

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 17.9.1882 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg September 17. 1882

Arrived here tonight after having stopped 2 hours at Bremen where we saw the Rathauskeller, the Roland and the stock exchange over which M r Lorenz our guide and Papa’s friend was in raptures. M r Lorenz is a very funny man with a red nose and poems of which Papa told me the following story: one day at table d’hôte he got up and said Gentlemen I will now recite one of my poems and he began but he was hissed down, so he goes out of the room and when the guests have calmed themselves down he comes back takes up a chair and threatens to kill everybody who interrupts him, and goes through the poem; this is the counterpart of what happened when we were with him when he was hissed while trying to translate some latin: in fact he is a noted bore on account of his sententious way of pronouncing.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 19.9.1882 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg September 19. 1882

Papa gave a dinner in the Zoological gardens. It was very amusing. And after dinner we played Kümmel blättchen at 5 pfennigs each with a knife for which we could all have been imprisoned. I like the Johanneum very much.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 21.9.1882 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg September 21 1882
Got fireworks and let them off; then tried to put out the lamps which we could not do as the policeman came; he saw my trying to put out one

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 8.10.1882 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg October 8. 1882

Went to Haspbergs Amanda und Heinrich . Heine Hasperg, Wilhelm and I and aunt Jenny and Belle Hasperg, Jenny went to the Panorama
Faber du Faur and to the Zoo where we saw the young lions who are only a few days old. Began Trevelyans life of Macaulay again today. so that this is the third time I am reading it.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 15.10.1882 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg October 15. 1882

Again went to Haspergs Amanda und Heinrich . I am hardly ever able to write my diary now on account of an Englishman, a M r Ward who lives here who always takes away my inkstand. After dinner we played roulette. Before going to Haspbergs aunt Lulu took took me to the conjuror with Robert Blümer and Martin
Blümer, Friedrich Martin . I spoiled one of his tricks by looking into a plate which he had given me to hold, and into which he pretended he had put a two mark piece which had been marked. It is beginning to get cold here.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 29.10.1882 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg October 29. 1882

Really my diary is getting more of a Sunday chronicle than anything else, as I never have time to write except on Sundays. This afternoon I have been watching the children of the „Waisenhaus“ dancing about on their lawn; but it is raining now so they have gone in. I do not know how it is but every day makes my antipathy to Martin get greater. I am really getting not to be able to bear him: he seems to me to be a molycoddle, and a nervous, fawning half-proud boy and perfectly crackt. And I can not combat this antipathy. I wonder why it is? I this week again sent an article on the daily life in german schools to the S. Georges Gazette. I think it the best article I have ever written and certainly is the one I have taken most trouble about. The last one was dreadfully bad and I wonder M r Kynnersley took it. Aunt Lulu fetched me at two and we called upon M ad. Dellenburger and aunt Auffm’ordt
Augusta who was, in spite of her eighty five years very lively and pleasant. At 4.30 we went to the v. Sternfels’es Manuela und Walter
who are very nice people. After dinner some more people came and those I remarked most were two fat, jolly, rosy girls who were very simple. We played Stop and one of the girls always lost although she had the best cards because she could not understand the game. But we amused ourselves very well playing and all kinds of things.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 31.10.1882 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg October 31. 1882. Tuesday
Uncle George’s Kempff Birthday. Aunt Lulu fetched me from School at 2.30 and I went to have my new suit tried on for the ball on Saturday. Called at uncle G. afterwards.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 10.9.1880 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: London Friday 10 September 1880

Today we went to Gravesend by boat. The way there is very pretty. All along the docks, and passing by Somerset House, the Tower and Greenwich hospital. Woolwich and Shooterhill. Just before Gravesend there is a sort of a lac by which the Thames passes In Gravesend itself there is little to be seen except the mouth of the Thames and we soon went away after having taken some Appolinaris and hock at the Clarendon hôtel. In coming to Gravesend one passes the place where the Bywell Castle ran into the princess Alice, just opposte the Gasworks and near the the powder Magazine.Am 3. September 1878 kollidierten an dieser Stelle die Schiffe „Bywell Castle“ und „Princess Alice“. 640 Passagiere kamen ums Leben. We had diner at the Critirion where we had a dozen of Oyster each, kidneys and a tomatoe with Wilhelmsquelle and hock in the grill room

ns0:div.ns0:head: 1.11.1882 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg November 1. 1882.

Pastor Blümer
Johann and his wife Auguste being out Ward and I made a ghost to frighten the three boys. I got on his shoulders and made phosphoreschent eyes on my cheeks; but it was rather a failure as Paul
Blümer had enough presence of mind to draw back the curtain so that the light fell on us.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 2.11.1882 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. November 2. 1882.

Rainy day. No drill in consequence. After school some of us went down into some subterranean passages, running under the Johanneum. We were rather frightened two or three times by noises, as we thought some body was coming down to chase us.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 4.11.1882 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. November. 4. 1882

Ball at the Schröders. Went to the hairdresser to have my hair arranged a little. He pomatomed, and washed, and cosmetiqued it till I might have used it instead of an umbrella, and then rubbed it with a very ill looking and smelling towel. Aunt Lulu came to fetch me when I was dressed and off I went to the Schröders. As soon as I got there I was introduced to and asked to dance with a whole row of girls, with awful names, in the right sense of the word, who were sitting around the room bolt upright not saying a word, and I was very glad to find some old aquaintances. Asher was there, looking rather more skeletonly, if such a thing is possible, than ever, did not know a soul, did not want to know a soul, didn’t want to dance (because he was afraid of breaking his shirt front); the truth is that he could not find anybody to dance with him on account of his looks: everybody called him the bat, and one of his most marvellous feats was his serving of the cream with his fingers. I danced a good deal with Belle Haspberg, who is very nice; but the prettiest girls there were the Busse’s Alice, Berta, Frieda, Lilly und Mary who looked sweet. I took Belle to dinner and after dinner, as the piano player had gone away, one of us began playing; but it was impossible to dance to this music, and so little idea had the boy of how a waltz ought to be played that he went off into a polka; in trying to dance to this beautiful potpoury I distinguished myself by sprawling down with the little Schröder. And after this feat I went away after a very pleasant evening. I drove to aunt Lulu’s, to sleep there, so as not to keep the Blümers Auguste u. Wilhelm up the whole night. Aunt Lulu was still up; and I went to bed in her stranger’s-room.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 5.11.1882 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. November 5. 1882. Sunday

Got up pretty early and spent a good part of the morning in looking over old mexican prints and chromolithographs; some of them very pretty. At eleven Aunt Lulu Uncle Fritz Meyer and I started off to town to go and buy a pair of high boots for me. After we have done shopping aunt Lulu and myself went to have lunch at the English hotel. We had some mockturtle stew which was very fair. We then went to see de Neuville’s picture at the Victoria hôtel. After this we went to the Uhlenhorst on the steamer. here I worked all the afternoon before dinner, and after dinner we played with the magic lantern and made shadows and other things. The smallest child was very frightened, and was taken away howling.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 10.11.1882 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. November 10. 1882. Friday

Martin’s birthday. I gave him a little glass bonbonière. He did not get very many presents. We played tivoli for chocolate in the evening. I won twice. Aunt Lulu came and brought me some toothpowder. She told me that the typhus was very bad in Paris and that our servant Gustave had got it, and as the hospitals were overfilled had to stop in our house in the 6 th story. I hope none of my family will get it. Frommell preached at the Petri Kirche.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 12.11.1882 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. November 12. 1882. Sunday.
Although I was invited, I could not go to aunt Lulu’s today, as I had too much to do. I worked from 1.30 to 8.30 without stopping except for dinner, besides having worked two hours yesterday evening.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 14.11.1882 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. November 14. 1882.
Finished the embankment around the part of the garden we are going to flood, and went out in the evening with a pipe and flooded it. Freezing hard.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 15.11.1882 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. November. 15. 1882

Got up early. The ice on the piece of ground we flooded last night is quite useless and bad, so I smashed it up. When I came home from school I saw the M. Andriez and Ward had flooded the ground anew. The water froze almost as soon as it got to a standstill. A Candidate was to come today as pastor Blümer was out to superintend us as P. Blümer was out, so Andriez and I were making plans with Robert Blümer how to tease him a little and as Ward came into the room we told Robert to go away as we did not want his father to notice that we were all in the same room, and as he would not go, Andriez told him we were going to speak French; he went away in a rage swore he would tell his father who would beat Ward, Andriez and me and at last went and streaked to his mother Auguste . Ward in trying to show off his skill in balancing bottles, after nearly breaking his nose, broke a beer bottle. Among other things that happened at tea to night there was a dearth of bread in which Robert tried to be very important, and bustled about with a face as long as the pastors umbrella, which is a woollen one and of a pretty good size.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 16.11.1882 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. November. 16. 1882. Thursday.

Went out before breakfast. The ice on the flooded piece of ground is bad again. The cold has been intense in the night and much snow fell. Missed the tramway, or rather it was too full this morning, so I had to go in a steamer with Jost which did not get to Hamburg till nine. Went on the ice in the afternoon, and Martin skated a little, but the ice was spoilt by one of the Schultzes going and tumbling about upon it. Pastor Blümer and his wife out again; About 4 degrees Réaumur under nought tonight.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 17.11.1882 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. November 17. 1882 Friday.

Skated before breakfast. Ice pretty safe. Heavy fall of snow. We made a great many slides this morning at school. The ice not good in the afternoon. At about 5.45 there was a grand aurora torealis; and the snow was perfectly red with the glare. But it was cloudy so that we only saw the glare and at first thought it was a fire. Drove Henny to a party in the evening, on the sledge and was driven part of the way home by Robert and Martin beide Blümer.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 13.09.1880 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: London Monday 13 September 1880

Today Uncle Tom took me to see his yacht being built at Forrestt the boatbuilders. Little of it is yet done only just the mere Carcasse and as far as I can judge by the beams this is its plan. A forecastle room for the sailor 6 feet, a bedroom for passengers, 6 feet, an engine room 20 feet, a back room for passengers 7 1/2 feet, a pantry and a W. C. running into the engine room. It is all mahogany and is to have two masts and one chimney. Uncle Tom and the boatbuilder fought a good deal about it and Uncle Tom and Harry Lynch his son are going to see it tomorrow again
HarryH de Kessler

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 19.11.1882 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. November 19. Sunday.

To Busse’s Auguste und Friedrich in the afternoon. Drove there with the Pastor Blümer , who happened to be out christening and marying. Alfred Busse made me laugh by calling one of the Blümers Robert, Martin oder Paul übergescheut, it being his own nickname After dinner, for which we had nut pie by the bye, we played cards, and later on danced. I managed to dance all the girls round the room till they dropped. I also played my Gavotte. Snow very high.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 23.11.1882 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg November 23. 1882. Thursday.
Feet bad, sore. They are covered with chilblains, and in the middle of the one of my chilblains is an inflamed corn. Could not go to Ballheimers in consequence

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 24.11.1882 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. November 24. 1882 Friday.
Had to drive to school in a cab this morning. Aunt Lulu came after school and we drove to Kronenwerth for my new suit which will be finished on next Friday.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 25.11.1882 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. November 25. 1882. Saturday
Foot so bad that I had to stop at home today. Read and chatted the whole day; worked in the evening.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 26.11.1882 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. November 26 1882. Sunday.

Nita’s birthday. Went and dined with her in the evening. Gave her a 5 m. Jardinière. Willy Kempff was there at dinner, and the Sternfels, the Meyers Augusta und Friedrich the Kempffs Auguste und Georg , and a brother of Düring came after dinner. We played cards, and acted charades after dinner, but on the whole I bored myself tremendously.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 3.12.1882 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. December. 3, 1882.

Went to the Heiligengeistfeld in the afternoon, where I skated. I did not get on very well. Afterwards walked to the Kirchenalleé to Kempffs Auguste und Georg where I arrived rather early. Dined at five and after dinner we all acted, and played the piano and played cards.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 6.12.1882 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. December 6. 1882. Wednesday.

Went to the Dom at the Dammthor with Pastor Blümer, Paul, Martin, Robert, Henny; saw the theater Morieux a kind of doll theater, something like a Diorama. It was very pretty. We lost Paul as we came out of this place, and he had to walk home alone. We went to a café and had some dinner there. Saw a mane ear frozen this morning.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 10.12.1882 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. December 10. 1882. Sunday.

Went to Haspergs Amanda und Heinrich at two and skated with them till five, and then went home with them and a M r Behrens, an English Jew, who paid court to Helen Hasperg, and dined there. After dinner we went to the Thalia-theater, where we saw a kind of Pantomime called the „Hexe vom Süllenberg“. It was rather pretty though rather unnatural.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 17.12.1882 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg December 17. 1882.
Went to Haspergs Amanda und Heinrich and dined there. After dinner went to Sagebiels

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 24.12.1882 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris. December 24. 1882
Arrived here this morning. Gee was delighted to see me and shrieked with pleasure. Mamma met me at the station.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 23.9.1880 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot. S t George’s School. 23 September 1880 Thursday
I came to school here today and I am allready friends with some boys

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 25.12.1882 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris. December 25. 1882.

Had our Christmas tree. Little Siefert came. I got Stackes History of Germany, Gibbon, Coppée, and a pin (lock) and a travelling bag from Papa and Mamma a lovely photograph from Mamma seven pins from Prince Reuss etc. Gee was very delighted at her toys. Fanny Fettridge and Pauline came.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 26.12.1882 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris. December 26. 1882
M r Moll came and worked with me. He seemed pleased to see me.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 27.12.1882 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris. December 27. 1882.
Gee, Marie and I went to the Jardin des Plantes. Gee was very delighted at the bears, which were really very amusing and was sorry to come away.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 30.12.1882 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris. December 30 1882

This evening while we were sitting at dinner a reporter came and insisted on seeing Mamma. In being told be could not he gone Gustave a letter to give Mamma. On opening it Mamma found Count Wimppffen the Austrian Ambassador had committed suicide. She first would not believe it and told the reporter she had no renseignements to give about him.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 31.12.1882 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris. December 31. 1882.

It is true that Wimppffen had committed suicide. It is in all the papers. He killed himself in a vespasienne in the avenue Marceau, between Blowitze’s house and the Japanese embassy. Gustave was very impertinent tonight. Went to the theatre with Gee. It was the first time Gee went to the theatre and she was delighted, though rather frightened at the shooting. The piece was the Voyage à travers l’impossible
Verne at the Porte S t Martin Théâtre de la Porte Saint-Martin . Poor Gee has got a cold

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 1.1.1883 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris. January 1. 1883. Monday.
Gambetta died at 5 minutes to twelve last night. The bourse has gone up. Poor Mamma is not well and cannot receive.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 3.1.1883 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris. January 3. 1883

Went to Wimppffen’s funeral. Stood at the grille in front of S t Clotildes. The ambassadors arrived at twelve; among these the Chinese ambassadorvermutlich Chen Jitong was conspicuous as well as the Japanese ambassador Hachisuka . During church time a „Catafalque“ was made infront of the church, and at the end of the service the coffin was borne out of church by six men and placed on it; flowers were put on the sides, and a man held all the stars and decorations Wimppffen had on a cushion next to it. Then 5 or six hundred foot soldiers and, some cavalery and artillery marched past, and after that I and M r Moll marched home. The inside of the church was decorated quite black, and very prettily they say.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 4.1.1883 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris January 4. 1883. Thursday.

Went to the Palais Bourbon with M r Moll at 12. But It was not open yet so I went there again with Henri after dinner. The crowd was enormous, and the queue went to the rue de Grenelle. We got into it somewhere about the middle at about half past two and at half past four got to the Palace. We were first taken through about six or seven rooms hung with black, and then got to the room in which was the catafallque. It consisted of a high kind of black stand over which was a dais supported by four black and gold columns. Under this dais rested the coffin wrapped in a tricolore flag. The whole stand was covered with flowers, but we could take but a short look at it as we were hurried on by a garde de Paris.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 6.1.1883 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris. January 6. 1883. Saturday.

Drove to the rue de Rivoli where we arrived at 9. Papa and I stopped downstairs in the arcades where we bought sundry photographies of Gambetta. It was really amazing to see where the crowd had got to. One man had got on to one of the flower pots which form part of the railings of the Tuileries. How he got up is a mystery. But how he got down is not as he did that pretty precipitately owing to being nearly suffocated by the smoke of a chimney which opened just under him. At about a quarter to ten we went up to Misses Keogh’s, and at the same time some „cantonniers“ began pelting the people with sand, by way of clearing the road. And they really did hit some people on the head with it. At about 10.30 the Garde de Paris turned the corner of the Rue de Rivoli, followed by some policemen to clear the way, a by no means easy operation. Then followed the deputations of Alsace-Lorraine with some very fine flowers, after them came some pompes funèbres à cheval, then three carriages each drawn by four horses covered with flowers. On each side of these carriages walked sixteen men, in black knee breeches and with a silver chain around their necks, two and two each pair carrying two huge wreathes on sticks; and behind came a single man carrying an enormous wreath too. After this came some soldiers, and then the hearse. The hearse was made of a low kind of truck with enormous silver wheels. On this truck stood the lower part of the catafalque of the rue de Bourbon without the columns and dais; at each corner of the catafalque were antique incense burners covered over with crape. On the catafalque stood the coffin in a tricolore flag, with an enormous piece of velvet, half covering it and falling down nearly to the ground at the back of it. Then came some more Alsace Lorraine people, and a lot of freemaçons; there was also a deputation from Martinique with about twenty niggers, and a deputation from Algeria with some splendid flowers. At the sight of anything prettier than the rest the people cried "bis, bis". Among other things a large triangle of violets was conspicuous as well as a flag bearing an English inscription, something about french brethren, and liberty, equality fraternity. The flowers were magnificent. After all these deputations, among almost every one of which were women and among some like the freemasons children, came the garrison of Paris and Versailles which closed the procession. In the afternoon I drove to the Palais Bourbon to see the decorations. A large piece of crape, 150 meters long they say, was draped across the whole front and the background was formed by black woollen stuff draped on the wall behind the columns, decorated with flags and palms. Between the columns stood large silver candlesticks and the whole staircase was covered with wreathes and flowers. The statue of Strasburg
Pradier was draped in black but not the lanterns. The steps were covered with wreathes. Played with Gee the rest of the afternoon, and went away tonight.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 8.1.1883 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. January 8. 1883
Ballheimer gave me a lecture on going away before the holidays.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 24.9.1880 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot September 24 Friday
