Papa and Mamma came to see me today and it is also papa’s birthday. They are going away tomorrow. Wee-wee Brion, Wilma is not quite well. Harry v. Kessler

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 14.1.1883 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. January 14. 1883.

Dined at aunt Gusch’s with the Haspbergs Amanda und Heinrich and Alfred and Lily Busse. Had some atrocious sweet hot milk, which nearly turned all our stomacks, at least the smell of it did as none of us drank it but we all inflicted it on Lily Busse.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 21.1.1883 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg January 21. 1883.
Went to Gura the actor and played and had dinner there. Among other games we played hide and seek at which I nearly lost my cock, who fell out of my cravat

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 28.1.1883 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg January 28. 1883.
Stopped at home. Played cards, and snap-dragon, etc. etc. Had rather good fun.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 4.2.1883 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. February. 4. 1883.

Went to aunt Lulu’s. After dinner we played Haydens „Kindersymphonie“Das Stück wird seit 1996 Angerer zugeschrieben.. I had the drum, which I managed to smash after a time. A little Jew boy, Israel played violoncello afterwards.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 11.2.1883 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. February 11 1883. Sunday.
My diary is getting more of a Sunday chronicle than ever. Stopped at home except going to the Kunsthalle with aunt Lulu.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 12.2.1883 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. February 12. 1883
Trials began. Had the Latin prose paper; pretty difficult.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 17.2.1883 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg February 17. 1883. Saturday

Went to the Egger’s ball. When I first arrived I could not manage to get myself introduced to anybody. In fact it was dreadfully managed, and awfully dull. Belle Haspberg first asked me to dance with her and to take her to dinner, but suddenly just before dinner she changed her mind and coolly told me to look for another partner. I could not get my carriage till 11.30 as the coachman kept on asking for Blümer Wilhelm. Slept at aunt Lulu’s; had some lemonade on getting home.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 22.2.1883 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg February 22 1883. Thursday.
Sat up till 11. preparing for the examination. I am writing this with ink which is as dry as a chip with the greatest trouble as all ink seems to evaporate here in a most wonderful way

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 23.2.1883 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg February 23. 1883. Friday.

Today was the great day. Got up at a quarter to five and worked at my Greek till eight, then went to school. The Director Hoche came in at nine, and Ballheimer began by asking Asher, who was trembling awfully, some Latin questions. He then asked me Latin which I knew very well as Ballheimer kept on making signs to me because the Director is half blind; he then asked Asher Greek of which he did not know a word. Then I was asked Greek; pretty easy questions which I managed to answer. I was glad when the examination was over, I am sure.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 25.2.1883 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg February 25. 1883 Sunday.

Went to the Kunsthalle after church, where I tired and bored myself to death. There are with but few exceptions, no pretty pictures. The Alster was pretty rough, so I went back in one of the steamers. It was awful fun. Went to Haspberg’s Amanda und Heinrich to dinner; played cards after dinner.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 13.10.1880 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot S t Georges School Oct. 13

Went to Eton today and had ourselves Photographed. After that we went up to the castle and heard service in S t Georges Chapel. I sat in Waldegrave’s seat Next to M r Cooke. We had breakfast at Layton’s the Confectioners upon real patés. After Chapel we went up on the round tower from where there is a beautiful view. After that went down to Eton by the hundred steps and went to see Eton college where we were to have tea with a certain Miss Hackett but she had gone out for the day. We drove home through Windsor forest. I bought a pretty little vase in Eton. v. Kessler

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 28.2.1883 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. February 28. 1883. Wednesday

Went to town at six o’clock to see the torch procession. It was very pretty. The prima and secunda had got on students hats and carried torches. I was at our class window and saw them beautifully as Eisenhardt lives next door. They had a band too. I afterwards went into the court and saw the torch bearers fencing and doing other things. They also sang some Anthems. The procession was very pretty.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 4.3.1883 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg March 4. 1883. Sunday

Went to a concert at the Convent-Garten with aunt Lulu. Some very good singers sang and there was an amusing piece called „ Die vollkommene Frau “ at the end of it. I could not help thinking of our house when a key is lost.

ns0:p.ns0:note: Der Titel „Die vollkommene Frau“ ist in deutscher Schrift geschrieben.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 11.3.1883 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg March 11. 1883. Sunday.

Went to Gura’s bénéfice. He sang very well, especially in the 3d act of Tell
Rossini which he acted very well too, but the house was almost empty.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 13.3.1883 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. March 13. 1883. Tuesday.
Went to Wilhelm Tell this evening. Sonnenthal acted Tell. He acted beautifully the old Attinghausen acted well too.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 16.3.1883 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. March. 16. 1883. Friday.
Reports today. I am the 17 in my class. I got a pretty good report.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 17.3.1883 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Berlin. March 17 1883. Saturday

Started from Hamburg this morning at 11 o’clock with aunt Lulu. Arrived here at five. Directly went to the Central Hotel, and took rooms there Then had dinner. In the evening went to the Opera. Heard „Gudrun“ Vermutl. Klughardt. . The Crown prince Friedrich III. and prince Wilhelm were there. Princess Victoria his sister was there too, and the Grand duchess of of Oldenburg and princess Friedrich Karl
Maria Anna, Prinzessin von Preußen were there too. Princess Victoria is dreadfully ugly. In the first entracte the Emperor came but went away again soon. Prince Reuss was there too. The town illuminated. Walked home

ns0:p.ns0:note: Der Name "Friedrich Heinrich" ist in deutscher Kurrentschrift geschrieben.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 18.3.1883 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Berlin. March 18. 1883. Sunday.

Went to the Dom at 10, but could not get any places. So we went out again and looked at the Schloss at 11. Our Guide was A.1. In showing us a picture of Solyman he told us he was the great man who besieged Vienna and was afterwards czar. Afterwards went to Montijou which was very interesting In the Schloss dodged Prince Reuss. Went to Fédora
Sardou in the evening.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 19.3.1883 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Berlin March 19. 1883 Monday.

Went to Potsdam. We first went to Babelsberg where we were first shown Babelsberg the emperors palace. His bedroom is simple, with cretonne curtains the walls covered with prints. His writing-room is pretty but simple. After this we went to Sanssouci or Sans, souci as it is written over the door It was most interesting. We were first shewn Frederic the Great’s dining room and then the room in which he died and his library. After some more rooms Voltaire’s room, the walls of which are covered with animals, such as parrots, and squirrels which Frederic had put there when Voltaire was travelling and he wanted to get rid of him, to personnify his character. After Sanssouci we had ourselves driven to the new Palais. We saw the shellroom and the theater etc. etc and then came home. Went to the Registrator auf Reisen
L’Arronge a very stupid piece in the evening

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 20.3.1883 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Berlin. March 20 1883. Tuesday.

Went shopping and stood before the Emperor’s palace and saw the emperor. In the evening went to the Bettelstudent
Millröcker which was very pretty.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 21.3.1883 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Berlin March 21. 1883. Wednesday.

Went to the Museum by myself the whole morning. It was very interesting. Went to the Panoptikum then which can not hold a candle to Madame Tussauds. Dined at the Hotel du Nord. Saw „Tannhäuser“ Wagner at the Opera tonight with Niemann and Lily Lehmann.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 17.10.1880 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot 17 October 1880 S t Georges School

This evening Heber-Percy in coming up to bed began to tell us he was a sleep walker. Then he shewed us a place in his room where a funny noise goes on from time to time, and after having put himself and us (Palk and me) in a sort of nervous excitement he retired to his room. The strange noise began again and did not contribute to our quietness as Percy persisted in saying it was a ghost. After about a quarter of an hour a most terrific shreek followed by several others sent the air proceeding from Percy’s room. I fell back on my bed in a violent fit of trembling and Palk began to bite his knee but the screeming went on The head (M r Kynnersley) M rs Moss The three housemaids came to the rescue thinking somebody was being murdered M r Kynnersley was in a frightful fright we all thought Percy had been taken by a screeming fit and had died in his bed. It turned out to have been nothing but Emely having walked quietly into the room and having stooped over Percy who was dosing. He seeing a figure, connected with the noise thought it was the ghost come out of his plank and come to take or murder him.
He was severely punished for it and is no more alowed to talk in his room Harry v Kessler

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 22.3.1883 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Berlin March 22. 1883. Thursday
Went to the Aquarium where we saw the Gorilla in the morning. Stopped at home and heard the concert in the Wintergarten in the evening. To Charlottenburg and thought the Mausoleum very fine.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 23.3.1883 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Berlin March 23. 1883. Good Friday.
Went to the Dom where there was a most awful crush in the morning and then tried to get into the Zeughaus but could not. In the evening went to the Dom again and heard Pastor Bauer preach.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 24.3.1883 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Berlin March 23. 1883. Saturday.Hier vertut sich Kessler mit dem Datum. Geht man die Wochentage und die dazugehörige Daten vom Anfang des Monats bis zum Ende durch, merkt man die Abweichung. Der Fehler schreibt sich bis zum 27. fort.

Went to the Tiergarten in the morning and saw the monument of Queen Louise
Encke . Also went to the Synagogue. In the evening to the Dom where we heard a beautiful musical litany. Did not go to any theater. To the Panorama Werner, Sedan-Panorama and Siegessäule in the morning

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 25.3.1883 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Berlin March 24. 1883. Sunday.

Went to the Dom in the morning. The crush was worse than ever. One lady behind me was trying to make room for herself; and only made matters worse by treading on every bodies toes and breaking her shaybones. The whole royal family was there. Ladies were shrieking for want of air overhead. We managed to get out by much elbowing. Dined at an execrably bad Café in the Kaiser passage and submitted to a piece of impudence from Otto Glaue the Optician who wanted to take off my cap when I went into the Shop. Went away by the 3.35 train and were in Hamburg at 9. I saw a large fire in driving home.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 27.3.1883 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. March 26. 1883. Tuesday.
Went to aunt Lulu’s to dinner as it was uncle Fritze’s birthday. We were eighteen at dinner and ten more came after dinner. So we danced till about half past eleven.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 28.3.1883 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. March 28. 1883.

Papa came at two. He and I called on uncle Fritz. I nearly lost my cap there and could not find it for a considerable time. Dined at aunt Gusch and afterwards went to a férie called „Das gestohlene Herz“, at the Central Halle. Slept with Papa at the Hamburger Hof.

ns0:p.ns0:note: Der Titel „Das gestohlene Herz“ ist in deutscher Schrift geschrieben.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 30.3.1883 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. March 30. 1883.

Made a few calls with Papa and then went out to the Uhlenhorst with him to see the Pastor. Blümer, Wilhelm
Papa gave us a breakfast at the Hamburger Hof, which was very good. After breakfast we went to the cemetry and then to the Cairo panorama Eckenbrecher, Einzug der Mekkakarawane in Kairo which was really very fine. We then went to Wetzels and then home. We dined at Haspbergs. Amanda und Heinrich They had a barrel organ up after dinner to which we all danced madly. The most amusing part was a Quadrille in which we all got wrong.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 31.3.1883 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg March 31 1883. Saturday.
Papa went away. I was very sorry. But I am to go home at Pentecost.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 1.4.1883 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. April 1. 1883

Made beautiful April fool of Robert Blümer when I got up. I pretended I had the toothache and begged him to go and get some „Japanesisches wasser“ for me at the chemists. I also told him to run fast so as to get it as quickly as possible. He ran as fast as he could and came back with a despondent face and told me he could not get any of this stuff.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 16.6.1883 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. June 16. Saturday. 1883
I have kept this journal three years now pretty regularly except for the last two months and a half when I have not kept it at all. I have in them been to Paris and my birthday has been.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 18.10.1880 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot 18 October 1880Beginn des zweiten Heftes; der letzte Eintrag des ersten Heftes wurde hier nochmals umgeschrieben.

To day we went out for a walk and as Thompson minor was teasing me I began to beat him. In beating him my fist not being well clenched my little finger of my left hand struck back and caused it to be sprained It is now bound up but still hurts

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 17.6.1883 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. June 17. 1883. Sunday.

Went to Wandsbeck this morning. First went and heard the band, in the forest, with aunt Lulu. Then went to Nita’s. After that to the fair. I had myself photographed for one mark and was cheated out of 2 marks by a man who diced. He evidently cheated as when I diced for fun I always won but when for money always lost, but he did it so cleverly that it was impossible to see how he did it. We dined at the café on potage bisque, mockturtle, beef and omelette. In the evening I went and saw the illumination and got home at about 11 o’clock.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 18.6.1883 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. June 18. 1883. Monday.

At 1 o’clock I ran up against a window in school and made a hole in my head about the size of the nail of my little finger. It bled fearfully; in fact I thought it would never stop. It was still bleeding at four o’clock.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 22.6.1883 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. 22. June. 1883. Friday.

The house is in a delightful state. Up above me they are pulling down the roof and builduing, the W. C is take to pieces, the stairs are strewn with mortar, remains of cheese and bread and wood and straw, besides which my window is smashed and my blind will not go up, the well has got dried up or is dirty or something and we have to drink Elbwater which is anything but clean or the well water which is about as clean as if somebody had been washing himself in it, and it cannot even be filtered as there is no filter in the house. We have got a cook who is subject to tootache so that dinner is generally about half an hour too late.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 24.6.1883 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg 24. June 1883. Sunday

Went to Wandsbeck to Nita’s. In the train from Wandsbeck to Groß Juthorn there was an old Jew who had paid 25 Pfennigs for the one tram and was now told to pay 6 more. He kicked up as much row as if he was going to be hung. „Es ist eine Schinderei, eine Schinderei, ich werde es der Direktion melden, Ich kenne die Direktion, es is ja eine Schinderei.“ he howled at the top of his voice through the whole carriage. Willy Kempff, and the Hartmeyer’s were at Nita’s. In the evening we saw a very curious scene in the forest: a drunken lover and his bride. He had got her around the waist and reeled about with her in a most comical way. This morning I went to the English Church, into Pearson’s pew. I had not been in long before another man stalked in; I was of course very uncomfortable, as I know nobody but Dickens, thinking it was his brother. But it turned out to be a German who was just as frightened of me as I was of him.

ns0:p.ns0:note: Die Rede des Juden ist in deutscher Schrift geschrieben.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 19.7.1883 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ems July 19. 1883. Thursday
Arrived here this morning. Papa and Baby Brion, Wilma at the station to meet me. After breakfast I went to the the music at 4 o’clock with Gee and sate down there with her. Poor dear Mamma not well.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 20.7.1883 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ems. July 20. 1883. Friday.

Went up the Mahlberg with Papa and came back by the Langensteiner Forsthaus. Went to the music again in the afternoon. Met the Rhangabé girlsTöchter vermutlich von Alexandros Rizos Rankabēs, griechischer Botschafter in Berlin. at the top.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 23.7.1883 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ems. July 23. 1883. Monday.
Went to the Concordiathurm with Papa. Back by the ferry and Dausenau.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 24.7.1883 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Spa. July 24. 1883. Tuesday.

Arrived here this evening. Excited the curiousity of the townspeople by the amount of trunks we had on top of the bus’ with the Hotel de Flandre man sitting on the top. Living at the Hotel de Flandre. Poor Gee fell or was knocked down at Nerviers so say all the people here are very rough. Dined at the Hotel des Bains.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 25.7.1883 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Spa. July 25. 1883. Wednesday
Walked about the town looking for apartments with Papa in the morning. Found one at last and took Mamma there. Déménageaid in the afternoon.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 26.7.1883 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Spa. July 26. 1883. Thursday.
Children’s ball. Went there with Papa and darling little Gee. Poor little thing looked rather plainly dressed.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot 18 October 1880 S t Georges School Dieser Eintrag ist auf der Rückseite des letzten Blattes im Heft notiert. Teilweise ist das Blatt verklebt.

This morning we all went out for a walk with M r Chapman and as they all began teasing me I began to beat Thomson minor the consequence of which was that I sprained my finger. It is now bound but hurts very much. It is half holiday.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 29.7.1883 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Spa. July 29. 1883. Sunday.
My master came for the first time: a M r Reuter. A very meek-looking person.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 30.7.1883 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Spa. July 30. 1883. Monday.
Fête at Barisart Source de Barisart . Went there with dear little Gee and Marie. Was not very gay. I won something at the tombola. Dear little Gee won a singing top.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 2.8.1883 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Spa. August 2. 1883. Thursday.

Childrensball at the Casino. Gee went in her cream dress with cornflowers. It was not very amusing. Dear Mamma who is better came too but had an attack of puffing out. I can not quite make out what it was, but it certainly is the first and I hope the last.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 5.8.1883 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Spa. August 5. 1883 Sunday.
Went to the grotto of Remouchamps with Papa. Stayed at the hotel des Etrangers. The palmier is very fine in the second grotto. Dear little Gee and poor Mamma did not go in with us.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 6.8.1883 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Spa. August 6. 1883. Monday.
Made the tour des Fontaines: dear Mamma and Papa in a carriage and I and a guide on horseback. Afterwards went shopping with Papa and had an ice. Papa went away this evening.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 7.8.1883 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Spa August 7. 1883. Tuesday.

I rode out in the afternoon to the chateau of Franchimont with a guide, a 2 hours ride. In the evening Mamma and I began our old way of reading again. Poor Mamma lying on a sofa her back to the light and I sitting rather to the back of her between the sofa and the table.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 8.8.1883 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Spa. August 8. 1883. Wednesday.
Rode to Creppe and back by the promenade Raikem, with the guide. Galloped well on the road in a few places. Guide nearly broke his neck.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 9.8.1883 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Spa. August 9. 1883. Thursday.
Went to the ball with Gee in the Pouhon today. Danced the Ostendayse and other dances with her. Dear Mamma was there too.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 11.8.1883 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Spa. August 11. Saturday.
Drove out with dear Mamma and sweetlittle Gee to Franchimont in the afternoon. Was sorry I had taken poor Mamma such away on foot up a Mountain afterwards.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 25.9.1883 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Amsterdam. September 25 1883.
Arrived here this evening. Papa at station to meet me and aunt Lulu. We are living at the Kras napolsky hotel.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 20.6.1880 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ems 20 June 1880 Sun rises 3,44 sets 8,18

This morning the emperor comes on the promenade and speaks to mamma, the weather was lovely but is bad. An awfull storm is on which papa and I have narrowly escaped, the rain is coming down in torrents the thunder is rolling incessantly, it is very dark, only from time to time a lightening lights up my paper, the Lahn looks like a sive for the rain is making little round holes in it but anyways this storm will cool the air wich is suffocating. This afternoon I go out with Baby Brion, Wilma and leave my window open, I have the pleasure in coming back to find my room completely inondated by the rain This weather is really comical when you shut your window you suffocate and when you open it you are inondated We have had two storms today and this afternoon Bee Brion, Wilma and I where caught in storm N o 2 This evening storm N o 3 took place it beat the two others in to canters earth and sky seemed to be on fire and the thunder was like a bombardement

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 20.10.1880 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot 20 October (1880) Sun rises 6,34 a.m

Today the first snow has fallen and it is very pretty to see from my window the valley and the mountains, the trees and the cottages wrapt up in their white shawl of snow. This afternoon we went snowballing and came back sopping wet. We snowballed on Ascot racecourse

ns0:p.ns0:note: Mehrere Kreuze in schwarzer Tinte markieren Umstellungen, die aber semantisch nicht eindeutig sind.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 26.9.1883 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Amsterdam. September 26. 1883.

Went to see a church in the morning and afterwards drove to the exhibition. Saw the Batavians and the Almées. On the whole exhibition not as fine as that in Paris. Went to top of American Hotel. Very fine view. Afterwards went to the Panorama of Constantinopel .

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 27.9.1883 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Amsterdam September 27. 1883.

Went to the Hague. First of all drove to Scheveningen. Was rather disappointed. Then told the choachman to drive us about. Saw the picture gallery and Potter’s Bull and Rembrandt’s lesson of anatomy. Had breakfast at a very nice restaurant and then drove to the Railway. Back to Amsterdam. Saw the Treppenhuis picture gallery. It is a perfect shame to exhibit valuable pictures in such a way. One has to run about and screw ones neck to see them as the light is abominable.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 28.9.1883 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris. September 28. 1883

Aunt Lulu forgot her trunk at Hotel yesterday and when she went and fetched it the stupid (?) porter put it into the wagon lit so she had to come to Paris. At Rotterdam there were some people who made a fearful noise dancing and shrieking and seeing a newly married couple off. Train very late

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 29.9.1883 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris. September 29. 1883 Saturday.

Went to gare du nord to see the King of Spain Alfons XII. arrive. Took our place at a window of a Restaurant in which we took some Beer. When the King passed the hissing and the shouting was perfectly deafening. The greater part of the people had brought penny whistles and used them very vigorously. The great cry was „A bas le Rehlen.“ In the evening, when driving to the Elysée, he was thrown at with stones and sticks.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 30.9.1883 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris September 30. 1883.
Went to the matinée of Peau d’ane. Poor Gee did not like it as they shot so. Afterwards drove to the café Napolitain.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 1.10.1883 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris October 1 1883.

Got up early and drove to the Gare d’Orleans to see the king Alfons XII. off. No crowd and no hissing so we saw him very well. To the Jardin d'acclimatation in the afternoon. Grandmamma arrived this evening.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 2.10.1883 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris October 2. 1883.
Spent the day at the avenue Friedland. Went to Louvre in morning

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 15.1.1884 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg January 15. 1883
Very bad stomach ache and sickness in the evening do not know what is the matter

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 16.1.1884 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg January 16. 1883
Stopped at home as I have been up all night in great pain and was very weak this morning

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 17.1.1884 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. January 17. 1883. Thursday.
Some pain again this evening. All those who breakfast with me at the restaurant are ill too; we must be poisened in some way.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 21.10.1880 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot 21 October 1880 sun rises 6.36 sets 4.54
Today allmost all the snow is gone for it is thawing. Three boys were swished to day: Sellon, S t John and Trelawny

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 24.2.1884 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. February 24. 1884. Sunday.

Went to aunt Lulu’s at 11½ o’clock this morning. Eat „Heisswege“ a kind of mash of bread, melted butter, milk, sugar and cinnamon. Don’t care for them much. After breakfast went to the concert of von Bülow. He played very well. Afterwards went to the Panorama of Gastein
Hertel . a great many little stories came into my head about the time when we were in Gastein in 1876. I remember when the Emperor was going away I went and stood in the passage of the house in which he lived to wish him Good-bye. I was standing next to Papa, Mamma was in one of the drawing rooms in which the Emperor was. Presently he came out. I believe he was in uniform, but am not quite sure. He first went up to Papa to shake hands with him. Then he came to me and stretched out his hand. I was very frightened and kept on going backwards till I came to the wall of the passage without giving the Emperor my hand. In fact I have generally been unlucky with the Emperor. In Ems once I was standing with Papa and Mamma in the Wandelbahn. The Emperor came up and began talking with Mamma and Papa. We of course all took off our hats, but on the Emperors putting up his stick Papa put on his hat again. I not noticing this did not put on mine; so the Emperor kept on lifting up his stick till I at last put on my hat. It was also in Gastein that when we had ordered different kinds of wine in a Restaurant Mamma noticing that the „etiquette“ on the dearer bottle of wine was still wet, and that there was no difference in the tastes of the two wines asked a little boy who was serving us how it was that the „etiquette“ was still wet; he answered with perfect composure: „Natürlich, die ist ja auch erst eben aufgebacht.“ I am now reading Las Case’s „Mémorial de S t Héléne“. The man’s vanity and boasting about his disinterestedness is really nauseous in some places. If it was not for this it would be an uncommonly amusing and interesting book.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 28.2.1884 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. 28 February. 1884

Mutzenbecher carried on in a way today that was perfectly astounding. He went out in lesson time while Stoffert was out too. Presently Stoffert came in and said he did not know what was the matter and that Mutzenbecher was fainting. Rhode rushed out and believed it. Of course it was not true.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 29.2.1884 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. Friday. 29. February. 1884.
Came out of school at 12 today because there was abiturientenexamination.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 2.3.1884 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. March 2. 1884. Sunday.

Robert Blümer has got a pleurésie and is very ill. I stopped at home the whole day. In the evening I went to Schwere’s and had tea there. Before tea Gustav Schwere , Martin Blümer and I played 66. I was very unlucky. After tea Gustav and Susanne Schwere played a sonate of Beethoven. I worked a great deal at my piece today, which I mean to be a kind of prayer. At the end of the first verse a choir of priests is supposed to be singing the requiem. I have just begun this latter part. I was rather puzzled how to tack it on to the first part; but now I think I will not make any transition and let the second part come in on itself, which is certainly the most natural. There is a long article about Mackays in the paper today. Their law suit with Meissonnier seems to be making great noise. Mamma writes that her picture Portrait von Alice Kessler by Kirchbach is getting something awful although se sits 3 hours every day.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 4.3.1884 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. March 4. 1884. Tuesday.

The Mackay-Meissonier scandal seems to be making great noise in Paris this is the report of the Hamburgscher Correspondent of the 2nd of March about it:Der folgende Zeitungsartikel ist an dieser Stelle in das Tagebuch eingeklebt. Breite 8,5 cm, Länge 33 cm.

ns0:p.ns0:quote: Mackay und Meissonier. Man schreibt der „V. Z.“ Vossische Zeitung aus Paris, 27. Februar. Ganz Paris – um den herkömmlichen Ausdruck zu gebrauchen – beschäftigt sich mit dem Streithandel zwischen den amerikanischen Silbergrubenbesitzer Mackay und dem Maler Meissonier. Für den Fernerstehenden wird die Sache erst ganz verständlich, wenn er die eigenthümlichen Pariser Zustände kennt, welche allein solche „Ereignisse“ möglich machen. Paris ist eine Fremdenstadt. Die Ausländer geben hier jährlich mindestens 6-700 Millionen aus und bezahlen den größten Theil des Glanzes und Aufwandes, der in Paris gemacht wird. Unzählige Haus- und Gasthofbesitzer, Geschäftsleute aller Art, besonders auch Künstler, sind auf sie angewiesen und leben nur durch sie. Deshalb herrscht in Paris ein System, welches man am besten durch Fremdencultus bezeichnen kann. Die Fremden müssen natürlich die Kosten dieses Cultus tragen, sich außerdem auch Alles gefallen lassen, was die Cultusdiener und Hierophanten mit ihnen vorzunehmen für gut finden, um sie auf die Höhe des Pariserthums zu bringen. Sobald dieselben einmal sich aufbäumen und Widerstand leisten, werden die Hierophanten ungemüthlich, der Zauber schwindet und der Ausländer steht vor der nackten Wahrheit, daß er nur seines Geldes und seiner Willfährigkeit halber verehrt und beweihräuchert wurde. Diese Erfahrung macht jetzt die Familie Mackay, deren Schicksal als Beispiel dienen mag. Als Mackay sich einige Jahre nach dem Frankfurter Frieden in Paris niederließ, war ihm der Ruf seiner reichen Silbergruben in Colorado, welche jährlich 20-60 Millionen einbringen oder einbrachten, schon vorausgegangen. Er wurde sofort in Behandlung genommen. Geschäftsleute aller Art, Händler und Künstler bestürmten ihn mit ihren Anträgen. Besonders legte sich auch die sogenannten Boulevardpresse darauf, das Haus Mackay anzuzapfen. Frau Mackay konnte sich nirgendwo blicken lassen, ohne daß sofort alle besagten Blätter sich mit ihr, ihren Toiletten und Diamanten, ihrer Familie und ihren Millionen beschäftigten. Als sie diese Huldigungen wenig oder nicht genügend beachtete, wurden anderen Saiten aufgezogen. Mehrfach wurde die Verlobung ihrer ältesten Tochter mit irgend einem Herzog oder Fürsten gemeldet, blos um „anzubohren“, blos um den Reportern einen Vorwand zu verschaffen, sich im Hause des Herrn Mackay einzustellen, um „Näheres“ zu erfahren, oder auch blos, um eine Berichtigung zu erzwingen und auf diese Weise mit der Familie anzubinden und in Beziehungen zu treten. Den Hierophanten war es besonders anstößig, daß Frau Mackay sich so kleinstädtisch benahm, das heißt in Abwesenheit ihres Gemahls, – welcher meist nur 6 bis 8 Monate jährlich in Paris weilte und einige Male sogar über ein Jahr fernblieb – keine Feste gab, keinen Herrengesellschaft empfing und sich überall nur in Begleitung ihrer Mutter zeigte. Vor vier Jahren veranstaltete jedoch Herr Mackay ein ungemein prachtvolles Fest, welches Aufsehen erregte. Jedoch rächten sich eine Anzahl der bei den Einladungen nicht berücksichtigten Blätter durch Angriffe und hämische Bemerkungen. Seitdem haben Herr und Frau Mackay keine ähnlichen Feste mehr gegeben. Darob noch größere Verstimmung. Ebenso wurden die sich mehrenden Aufdringlichkeiten einige Male etwas nachdrücklich zurückgewiesen. Dies war natürlich Oel ins Feuer. Hierzu kam nun ein Zwist mit Meissonier, wegen dessen die gesammte Boulevardpresse über Mackay herfällt. Dieser hat sich (wie schon früher berichtet) unterstanden, an einem Bilde des „größten Malers der Welt“ etwas auszusetzen, anstatt anbetend niederzufallen und unbesehen zu bezahlen. Und doch ist es Thatsache, daß das von Meissonier gemalte und mit 70,000 Frcs. bezahlte Bildniß der Frau Mackay gar wenig ähnlich und überdies unbedingt ein schwächeres Werk des Meisters ist. Schreibt man doch Meissonier das Wort zu: „Gut genug für Amerikaner“. Dabei hat Meissonier, welcher seit Jahrzehnten nicht mehr ausstellt, die Tactlosigkeit begangen, das Bild ohne Vorwissen von Herrn und Frau Mackay im Salon auszustellen. Als Mackay verlangte, daß das Bild doch wenigstens seiner Frau ähnlich sehe, wurde Meissonier grob und bedeutete ihm, daß er von Kunst nichts verstehe. Als wenn man ein Kunstverständiger sein müsse, um zu unterscheiden, ob ein Bildniß ähnlich ist oder nicht! Anstatt das Bild zu überarbeiten, schickte Meissonier den Gerichtsvollzieher, um Zahlung zu erhalten. Man schickte ihm die verlangten 70,000 Francs; aber da man das Bild unmöglich als Portrait der Frau Mackay ausgeben kann, wurde es in die Rumpelkammer befördert, oder, wie Andere sagen, verbrannt. Darob nun allgemeines Halloh unter allen Denjenigen, welche aus den oben dargelegten Gründen Ursache zu haben glauben, mit Mackay unzufrieden zu sein. „Figaro“ und seine Sippe ergehen sich in pöbelhaften Angriffen auf den „Amerikaner“, werfen ihm seinen Reichthum vor, bezeichnen ihn als Emporkömmling und Protzen, als Börsenjobber. Sie sollten doch wissen, daß Mackay seinen, jetzt auf eine halbe Milliarde geschätzten Reichthum einzig den Silbergruben verdankt, die er das Glück hatte, billig zu erwerben. Man weist ihm die Thür: „Wir haben die Millionäre haufenweise“, sagt der „Figaro“, „und für einen, der abgeht, gleich wieder zwei neue; aber wir besitzen nur einen Messonier“. Er ruft die französische Nation auf, die ihrem größten Künstler von einem gewöhnlichen Geldmenschen angethane Schmach zu rächen. Es soll ein Banket zu Ehren Messonier’s veranstaltet werden, um ihn zu verherrlichen und dem „Amerikaner“ zu zeigen, welch’ elender, ungeschliffener Bär er ist. Es wirkt in der That komisch, zu sehen, wie sich dieselben Leute, welche bisher den Macky’schen Goldhaufen so sehnsüchtig und tiefverehrend umkreisten, in lautere sittliche Entrüstung hineinzureden suchen. Andererseits nehmen die hier wohnenden Amerikaner entschieden Partei für Mackay. Sie wollen eine Demonstration gegen das Meissonier-Bankett veranstalten, wenn dieses zu Stande kommt. Das Ende vom Liede könnte sein, daß Mackay Paris den Rücken kehrt. Ihm hat es hier nie besonders gefallen, und nur Frau Mackay hielt die Familie in Paris, wo jetzt gerade sie von der Presse auf’s Korn genommen wird. Seitdem Herr Mackay mehrere andere europäische Hauptstädte besuchte, hat seine Abneigung gegen den hiesigen Aufenthalt zugenommen.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 7.5.1884 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. May 7. 1884. Wednesday

I am going to try and keep a continous diary again. Since I last wrote I have been to Paris in the Easter holidays, Where I met Mamma not very well but getting better. and dear little Gee thank God very well. Mamma’s picture by Kirchbach is a complete failure and as she wrote the other day he is going to paint a new one. Peix-Otto behaved very badly and wants to insist on painting Mamma. I ran with Martin Blümer, Dickens and Ward by moonlight, which was very exhilarating although fatiguing after my late illness. While I was ill I have written a poem „the Phantom ship.“

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 8.5.1884 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg May 8 th 1884. Thursday

This evening Martin, Miss Freise and I and Dickens went for a walk Martin and I with top hats, lorgnettes and long Overcoats. We went to Klauckes and to Miss Becks. At Becks’s I rang and asked whether miss Klaucke lived there, The servant seemed quite bewildered. At Schwere’s I rang but as soon as M r
Schwere came out Martin ran away; this was very unpleasant as I had to speak to M r
Schwere alone.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 12.5.1884 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. May 12th Monday 1884

Very warm to day: 22 degrees réaumur in the shade. Went to the Bathing place of Kuchelmann with Georg after school but did not bathe. Saw all the „bitjes“ bathing in the little place for notswimmers. The swimming place quite empty. There was storm with thunder and lightning, at which M rs Freise was very frightened, this evening, but it is just as hot now as it was before the storm. I have been reading Macaulays Reform speeches lately and think some of them especially the end of the first one very fine. The Socialist bill passed on Saturday in the Reichstag. Bismarck made two very fine speeches during the debate; but they say he has got very thin and looks ill. The Government won by 37 votes so the dissolution will not take place till August or July.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 14.5.1884 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg May 14. Wednesday 1884.

Bathed for the first time this year. The water was rather cold and I did not stop in very long. Robert Blümer is ill again. This is the third time and if it really is a „rechute“ and not only a passing thing there is not much hope. Please God he may get well again. But I am afraid that even if he gets over again this attack he will die of a new rechute or of consumption later on, as the pain in the lungs never seems to get any better, and he has often complained to me of it. This time I believe the rechute was brought on by his going to Rheinbeck yesterday and coming back in the night air. It would be fearful if anything was to happen to him.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 17.5.1884 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg May 17. 1884

We came away from school at 1 o’clock today. It was pouring, so I walked to Aunt Lulu’s so as not to have to stand waiting for her near the Johanneum. She shewed me a French paper, with a description of Mamma’s picture in it. Kirchbach is painting her in a blue dressing-gown lying on a havane sofa. The paper said it was a beautiful picture. I have never seen it, so I do not know what it is like; poor Mamma is ill again. We went to the Singhalese afterwards; it was very amusing. One of them wrote something for me, his name I believe.

ns0:p.ns0:note: Am Ende des Eintrags ist ein Stück Papier mit dem singalesischen Schriftzug eingeklebt, den Kessler erwähnt. Breite: 7,8 cm, Länge: 1,9 cm; Zwischen die Seiten sind zwei kleine Schnipsel eingeklebt mit den Überschriften „Menus Propos“ und „Les incidents“.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 22.10.1880 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot Friday 22 October 1880
All the snow is gone. This evening there was repetition of the concert after which for those who sang refreshments and another song. Those that had not sung did not have any refreshments

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 18.5.1884 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg May 18, 1884. Saturday.

Did not go to scholl till 10 today. M rs
and Miss Freise left for Göttingen today. They told me while they were here that they had got manuscript and unedited poems and letters of Schultz. I am still reading Macaulay’s life of Trevelyan . I admire his letters more than ever.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 19.5.1884 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg May 19. 1884.

Nenne and Belle Hasperg came at about four today and asked me to dinner. So I started at 5 o’clock. It was thundering and lightning a great deal. Puppe and his wife dined there with me. Alice was invited too but was of course left behind as she always is, whenever there is any inventable reason for doing so. Today it was on account of the thunderstorm. After dinner we drove away in the dog cart, Nenne driving, and Belle sitting next to her, I and Heine at the back. We drove right round the Alster. As we were getting near home the spring broke so that we were almost jolted out of our skins as we bumped over the stones. Soon the cover for our feet fell out too, so we had to get out and stop to get it. At last after many vicissitades we managed to get home.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 20.5.1884 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. May 20. 1884. Tuesday.

I went to aunt Lulu’s today. She read to me some letters she had received from Papa. General Grant he writes has swindled away over 100000 dollars just before the great money crisis in New York. Mamma has not written for a long time. Her last letter said that she was ill. I hope it is nothing dangerous. Rautenberg is ill too and has been away from school for sometime. Today we did not go there till 10 o’clock. He told us a very good story the other day about false metaphor. In the Landtag in Gotha a money question was being debated; the contention was hot and the parties could come to no conclusion. Presently one good burgher jumps up „Meine Herren“ says he „wenn wir so fortfahren so stehen wir bald auf dem Gipfel der Versunkenheit, so befinden wir uns bald am Rande des Bettelstabes.“ I am now reading Gibbon’s autobiography

ns0:p.ns0:note: Wörtliche Rede in deutscher Schrift.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 21.5.1884 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. May 21. 1884. Wednesday
I at last received a letter from Mamma this morning; she is better I am glad to see. Papa sails from New York today, the weather is fine so I hope he will have a fine crossing.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 22.5.1884 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. May 22. 1884. Ascenscionday. Thursday.

Received a letter from Bonnemamman this morning. She is better I am glad to see. Went to Teufelsbrück in the afternoon. Started from here at about three. Drove to the Georgsplatz and from there walked to the harbour, where we took a small steamer. Saw the „Paradox“ the ship Robert Blümer is to sail in on the way to Teufelsbrück. In Teufelsbrück we went to a restaurant and sat out on the terrace. Afterwards I walked a little with Robert and Martin Blümer. We started from Teufelsbrück at six and got out at the Landungsbrücke in S t Pauli; We walked home through the hafen. I in vain looked for the shop with the elegant inscription „Hospital for broken pipes“ which I saw last time I was there, with Paul Blümer. On the whole I spent a very pleasant day. I finished Gibbons Memoirs today, and very interstíng they are; but I think some of all that long writing and rewriting about the sale of his house at Beriton and about his money matters might have been omitted, as there really is no earthly interest in it for any living, breathing human being. I read Macaulay’s essay on history afterwards. Such an historian as he describes would indeed be a great historian. How I wish I could be such a one. The history of England so written would be the most intersting historical work in the world, I should think.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 23.5.1884 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. May 23. 1884. Friday

My birthday. When I came home from school today I found my birthdaytable spread. Papa and Mama gave me Koenig’s Litteraturgeschichte and a crocket game, and dear Mamma sent me 50 francs this morning. From Bonnemamman I got a check for 2 pounds. The Blümers Auguste und Wilhelm gave me a very pretty cover for my drawers, and a thermometer. Robert Blümer a book about flags and the children flowers. Aunt Lulu gave me a stand for my music and aunt Gusch Princess Beatrice’s birthday book and some flowers. The Übernatürlich Gescheite gave me some chocolate as well as Dickens. Dickens by the way has left this today. Aunt Lulu, aunt Gusch and the U. G. came to see me. I got a letter from poor Mamma this morning. Elise, the cook who can not see, hear or smell now as a new accomplishment pretends that she is mad and as soon as Mamma threatens to send for the police is quite well again. Gee wrote me a letter too this morning and really I do not believe there is a single present I got today that gave me such pleasure as that letter from the dear little thing. On the whole I spent a very pleasant day.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 24.5.1884 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. May 24. 1884. Saturday

Did not go to school till 10 today as Rautenberg and Ballheimer are still ill. I found out that Kohlmann is an atheist, and an atheist whose whole system of morals is based on monstrous egoïsm and selfworship. I never heard anything so preposterous as his theories, I really could not help laughing at them and his conceit. He told me he thought himself much better off than we Christians and than anybody who believed in a God for he felt certainty while we can not. Next to this conceit there was a vein of cowardliness which was revolting. He was frightened to death lest I should tell anybody he was an atheist; he denies everything better and higher than man, life after death, punishment for our sins in fact everything except what he can see and feel. The conversation interested me much as I had never talked with a real atheist before. I am glad to say he made no impression whatsoever on my mind. Got a letter from Papa.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 25.5.1884 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg May 25 1884.

Went to Haspergs Amanda und Heinrich . I started at halfpast ten a.m.. When I got there I found out that the races in Bahrenfeld were not to take place till four o’clock. So I stopped in the garden with Heine Hasperg till 2. Then we drove away in the dogcart. Paul Hasperg driving and Belle Hasperg sitting next to him, I and Heine on the other seat. The races were very nice. Ward and Dickens were beaten but Paul won two races. The prizes for them were a large horn and a champaign-icer. The dust was simply fearful on the way back and we drove at a fearful pace. We dined at 8. Totty Burke was there too and a woman with a huge red satin star on one side that looked like a decoration. We were twenty-three. M r Ehnett proposed Paul’s health.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 26.5.1884 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. May 26. Monday 84.
Was ill today. My stomach is deranged again today and My eyes bad. Stopped at home from school.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 31.5.1884 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. May 31. Saturday. 84

Did not go to school till 10. Came away at 12. Read Göthes Werther. Found it very middlingly interesting and very exaggerated, but can quite understand how it created the great sensation it did create.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 23.10.1880 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot 23, October 1880 S. rises 6.39 sets 4.50

We had a paperchase today. We went in the train to Virginia Waters and from there we were to run back to Sunningdale. but I, Tomlin, Mackenzie, Scott, Mortimer minor and Webb lost our train so that we had to walk back the whole way to Ascot, on our way where we were followed by some ruffians one of which had a black eye.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 1.6.1884 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. June 1. Whitsunday. 84.

Went to church in the morning and played croquet. Began Goethes Wilhelm Meister. It pleases me exceedingly. I never liked anything German better. It is interesting and lively and not so oversentimental as Werther. Got a note from aunt Lulu that we are going to the Harz. I hope it will be fine. Gladstone seems to be in a worse mess than ever. The only thing that keeps him in, they say, is the Reform bill as four fifths of the Commons are against his Egyptian policy but will not vote against him on the vote of Censure on account of it. The fenians are at go again in London; they have been burning off a lot of dynamite with no effect but frightning a few old women and smashing Wynne M. P.’s windows. Their Trafalgar square attentate was stopped. Clifford Lloyd said „The English ascendancy in Egypt began July 11. 1882 and ended May 28. 1884. I learnt English, I am going to study French now.“

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 3.6.1884 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p:
Harzburg
Bad Harzburg . June 3. 1884. Wednesday

Started from Hamburg at 8.22 this morning. Arrived here at 2. Had table d’hote then went down to the promenade and got two horses. Aunt Lulu took two men and a stone to get her on. We went to the top of the Burgberg with the column Unbekannt, Canossa-Säule with „Nach Canossa gehen wir nicht“ on it and the two Walküren. From there we went through the most beautiful forest to the Rabenklippen from where we had a beautiful view of the Brocken. Then we rode on to the Sennhütte got off near the Philosophenweg and walked home by it. There is a fearful storm while I am writing this. It is pouring. I hope it will be finer tomorrow: It is thundering and lightning fearfully. We are living at the Actien-hotel. Very dear and not particularly good. The storm is fearful. The rolling of the thunder is almost uninterrupted. As we were very late in starting from Hamburg aunt Lulu’s hatbox chose the very minute when we were taring madly along the platform for letting it’s bottom come out so that we had to rush on one with the hat the ribbons streaming behind the other with the pieces of the hatbox to catch the train. Arrived here aunt Lulu found that her ink bottle which she had put into her trunk had broken and made everything black; so she tried to mop it up with the hotel towel which did not do any good and only blackened the towel so that she had to sit up half the night washing it and had a grand fight with the hotel people who wanted to charge her for it. Then her „réveil matin“ which she had set on 7.30 the next morning woke her at four at which time she got up and rung violently for the maid and abused her for not waking her as it was already nine. So we are living in violent strife with all the hotelpeople.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 4.6.1884 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p:
Harzburg
Bad Harzburg . June 4. 1884.

We started from here this morning at nine in a thick fog. Went up on horseback to the Elfenstein but had no view on account of the fearful fog. At one time it was so bad that I could hardly see aunt Lulu riding before me. From the Elfenstein we went by the Kästen Klippe, the Hexenküche and the Mausefalle to the Feigenbaum, from which there generally is a beautiful view but we could not see a thing, so we walked down to the Clausbruch, a kind of grotto. Hardly had we got down there, when the fog was almost perfectly gone so I rushed up again to the Feigenbaum and had a very nice view. From there we went by the Romkerfall down into the valley of the Oker, to the Romkerhalle where we had breakfast on veal and omelette aux confitures. From the Romkerhalle we rode by the highway to Goslar. It began to pour on the way so that we got rather wet. At Goslar we rode to the Kaisers-Warth a very old house built in 1492 and had a cup of coffee there. We then took a conductor and went right through the town. First to the Rathaus then by the Brusttuch to the Dom chapel and to the Kaiserhaus in which there is a beautiful hall with frescoes which are not finished. From there we went to see a very pretty clock and then home by train after having been on a high tower from which there was a very fine view.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 5.6.1884 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Wernigerode June 5. 1884

Started from Harzburg
Bad Harzburg this morning at 9.15. We rode through the wood down to the Radanthal and waterfall which was not very pretty as it was being repaired and very little water was coming down. We then rode past some large quarries and over the Radan and on through the wood over the mountain to the Molkenhaus and from there went to the Muxklippe, from which there is a very fine view on to the Brocken. We then walked down a very steep hill leading our horses as it was too steep to ride. As off we passed the Ecker my horses eyes had to be tied up as it would not have gone over had that not been done. On the other side we had go through the preserves of the count of Stolberg-Wernigerode till we got to Scharfenstein after which the little Brocken begins; and no wonder they thought it haunted. It is so covered with rocks and large stones that the horses could hardly get up it. The big Brocken which we got on after is not so bad. When we got to the top we went up the tower from which though the weather was not good we had a fine view. We then had a very good dinner in the Brockenhotel and after it rode down in 2 hours to Ilseburg by the Ilse falls which are very pretty. At Ilseburg we went to the Hotel zu den roten forellen and had beer and coffee there and from there went by the train to Wernigerode where we are living in the weisse Hirsch.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 6.6.1884 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p:
Rosstrappe Hotel
Wernigerode . June 6. 1884.

Walked up the Lindenberg this morning in Wernigerode, from where there is a very fine view on to the castle and town. We then went down the Burgstrasse where I bought a very nice little stick for 90 pf. We had already ordered our carriage, so when we came home after having breakfasted we drove away to Rübeland. The road went through Eltingerode, where we saw the Blaue Engel in which aunt Lulu was almost eaten up by fleas last time she was here. From there we drove to the hotel Grüne Tanne in 30 minutes. From the Grüne Tanne we had to go up a rather steep hill to the Bauman’s Höhle a large grotto but not so large as Remouchamps. We walked in a kind of procession. The guide first the aunt Lulu and last a young couple in their honeymoon They did nothing but call each other „Liebchen“ and „Mäuschen“ and „Engel“ etc. Each of us men had a lamp; the guide also lit some limelight in some places. From Rübeland we drove on to Treseburg. The way down to Treseburg is one of the most beautiful in the Harz. On both sides are high mountains covered with firtrees etc. which look like feathers in the distance, and down in the valley the Bode rushes through. On the way to Treseburg we went up to the Wilhelmsblick from which one can see the Bode for a long way. Down at Treseburg we had some very good sour milk at the Weisse Hirsch. From Treseburg we drove uphill to the Rosstrappe where we are staying this night. From the Hotel we directly walked on to the Rosstrappe with the horseshoe. From the Rassmannshöhe we had a beautiful view into the Bodethal on to the Teufels Brücke. The scenery was wild and grand beyond description. The Hexentanzplatz we could also see. From my window here I have got a very far view: Halberstadt, Quedlinburg, Thale etc and the hills in the distance, the whole now lit by the moon, and the thousand little lights of the towns and villages are very picturesque.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 7.6.1884 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Blankenburg. June 7. 1884.

This morning I was woke at half past three to see the sun rise and did not like it all. It was not worth ones while to get up so early to see so little. I went to bed again then and got up again at 8 o’clock had breakfast and packed my things. When all was ready I went down into the garden and looked through the telescope. When aunt Lulu came down we went up to the Bülow’s Höhe and from there to the Rosstrappe where we made the man shoot so that we might hear the echo and gave him 30 pf. for it. We then walked down the Schurre into the Bodethal, and from there walked on to the Teufelsbrücke. On both sides high rocks fall almost straight into the Bode which rushes on through the Kessel foaming and raging. On the other side of the Teufelsbrücke we walked on a little way and then turned and walked to the Waldkater by the Königsruhe and the Jungfernbrücke. From the Waldkater I walked up the Hexentreppe, 1120 high steps some of them loose, some high and some low, to the Hexentanzplatz. Aunt Lulu drove up. At the top I had a glass of milk and spent the time till the carriage came in walking to the Riesenschloss and looking at the scenery. We then drove down to Hotel Zehpfund in Thale and had dinner there looked at the shops and bought some things and went to the Waldkater where we had coffee. At half past four we drove away from Thale to the Regenstein near here which is very interesting. There is a ruin of a castle on it which was besieged and taken by Frederick the great by his bombarding the well and smashing it up so that the French who where in it could get no more water in 1756. We also saw the outhöhle in one of which a princess of Heimburg was shut up but bored her way through the thinnest part of the wall with her ring! Most of the remaining rooms are hewn out of the rock and there is still a tower in it built by Henry I the Birdcatcher in the 10th century. The Romans were here too, and in olden times it was a Raubburg one of the counts let himself out of a window was taken and put into a wooden box. From the Regenstein we drove to Blankenburg to the Weisse Adler where we have two very nice large rooms. In the evening we went to the Thie and heard the band.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 8.6.1884 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg June 8. 1884 Sunday.

Got up early. After breakfast walked with aunt Lulu to the Grossvater in company of an old gentleman who thought the Harzer people very lively! At the Grossvater aunt Lulu would not go up at first but I at last persuaded her. We then went down and had sour milk with peppermint before it at the Grossvaterhotel. Had breakfast when we came home and then drove to the station in the ’bus. Missed our correspondence at Magdeburg so we did not get to Hamburg till 11. On the whole this has been a very nice tour. Our guide’s name was Carl Casties and our coachman’s Friedrich Nordhausen; an old lifeguardsman.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 15.6.1884 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. June 15. 1884. Sunday

Papa arrived this morning at 8 o’clock. Went to the Hamburger Hof at 9.30 this morning and found Papa sitting at breakfast with Düring and aunt Lulu. After breakfast went out to Wandsbek with Papa, where the children have got the whooping cough and Curt looks rather ill. Papa gave them 20 marks at parting to buy something. Breakfasted at aunt Lulu’s and after breakfast took the train to Blankenese. From the station we walked through the most fearful rain to the Süllberg where each of us had to pay 40 pf. to go up. Down to the Elbe we went down a dreadful way, steep steps Aunts Gusch and Lulu could not get down without a deal of screaming and screeching. We went back by the steamer and dined at the zoological gardens in the evening. Alfred Busse was there. Papa told us about his Museum. He says it makes between 700 and 1200 dollars a day and that they have let the programs for 7800 dollars a year and that they get 17 per cent on the eatables that are sold there.
Roudolenz Schröder was there too. He shook everybody’s hand for half an hour by the clock while talking with a „croquemort“ sort of a face to quite some one else. Everybody burst out laughing, but he did not see the joke luckily. Slept at the Hamburger Hof with Papa in N o 90.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 16.6.1884 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. June 16. 1884.

Breakfasted with Papa this morning while Dietzel was sitting by us. Had dinner at aunt Gusch’s in the evening. Fritsch the „Unvermeidliche“ was not there. After dinner we went to the Panopticum and Willy played. Went to bed late. Kept diary 4 years.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 17.6.1884 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. June 17. 1884.

Got up at five so as to be able to see Papa off. His train went at 6.48. Dietzel came too. When we wanted to breakfast hardly a soul was up, so we had great difficulty in getting it. At last however we got it. Aunt Lulu came too. After seeing dear Papa off went with Dietzel the „Bare“ as he is called in the poem and aunt Lulu to 6. Grosse Allee and had some sour milk. Afterwards went to HöffertVermutl. ist das Berliner Fotostudio gemeint, das am Jungfernstieg 12 eine Filiale hatte. with aunt Lulu.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 28.10.1880 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot Thursday 28 October 1880
Today the concert came off It came off allright and it was great fun

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 20.6.1884 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. June 20. 1884, Friday.

Went with Robert Blümer and Pastor and Pastorin Auguste und Wilhelm to see the Paradox. Robert’s cabin is very small of course but the ship is very nice. R’s roomdoor opens on to the dining room from that you get into the saloon and from that into the captains cabin by one door and out on deck by another. My master was waiting when I came back.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 22.6.1884 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg June 22. 1884. Sunday.

Went to the races today with Hasperg’s Amanda und Heinrich . Paul Heine and I drove in the dog cart. It poured fearfully so we got drenched. Stronzian won the Derby. In the evening we were 60 at dinner. We dined in the large ballroom. Birchfeld played with his band during dinner. We marched in with the Tannhäuser march
Wagner .

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 23.6.1884 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. June. 23. Monday. 1884

Robert Blümer went away. Martin Blümer and I came out of school at 1 o’clock. Dined at 2. After dinner I and Martin drive by tram to the port. We first waited for the others to come but at last asked a man whether anybody had gone to the Paradox yet. On his telling us that they had we had ourselves taken over and just arrived in time to say Goodbye though the ship was already moving. It was 5 minutes to four.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 27.6.1884 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg June 27. 1884

Went to the „Fährhaus“ in the evening. Very large concert with coloured fires etc. Met Dickert, Hoffmeister, Röllchen etc. Braus held on to Martin Blümer like grim death. Cholera broken out in Toulon.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 29.6.1884 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg June 29. 1884
Went to Haspergs Amanda und Heinrich . A miss Schultz from Oldenburg, a fearful romp was there. Very amusing.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 1.7.1884 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg July 1. 1884.
Cholera spread to Marseilles. 6 people died there yesterday; It is almost certain that it is the cholera asiatica.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 2.7.1884 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg July 2. 1884 Wednesday.

Very hot in the morning came away at 12 o’clock from school. but at about half past four it began not to pour but to come down in buckets. This is no exaggeration. The wind kept on turning so that the water came in at every open window, and with the rain it hailed and lightened and thundered so fearfully that at times we were really afraid the windows would smash. It had hardly rained ten minutes when we heard a kind of rushing noise under the pantry floor and suddenly the water began to squirt out of a hole in the floor like a fountain; nothing could stop it. The water came higher and higher, it flooded the kitchen, the servants room, the pantry in fact the whole ground floor, till it went over our boots. And horrible dirty water it was too. And this did not happen in our house alone but in every other house on the Uhlenhorst too because they did not open the drain soon enough.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 6.7.1884 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg July 6th 1884

Went to Reinbek. Had dinner at schloss Reinbek. Dear and not very good. Afterwards walked in the woods. Went to Friedrichsruh by the 6 train and had some very watery coffee at the Landhaus. Afterwards looked through Bismark’s house. Very prettily furnished. There is a large bronze Niederwald DenkmalReplik des Niederwalddenkmals bei Rüdesheim. there with following letter in the Emperor’s Wilhelm I. own hand attached to it „Zu Weihnacht 1883. Der Schlußstein ihrer Politik, einer Feier, die hauptsächlich ihnen galt und der sie leider nicht beiwohnen konnten. W.“ Missed our train and did not come back till 10 o’clock.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 7.7.1884 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg July 7th. 1884
School expedition. Went to Buxtehude. Did not get anything to eat till very late. Not very amusing.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 12.7.1884 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Kreuznach Bad Kreuznach. July 12. 1884
Arrived at Cologne this morning and met Papa at 8. First case of cholera in Paris yesterday. Mamma and Gee at the station to meet me. Papa did not arrive till 4 having been to Larter’s.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 1.11.1880 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot 1 st November 1880 s. rises 6,55. s. sets 4.32
