We had a paper chase to day we ran all the way to Virginia Waters, where we saw the ruins and climbed down the Waterfall, and back

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 16.7.1884 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Kreuznach Bad Kreuznach July 16. 1884.
Went for a long walk with Papa today. By train to Münster am Stein Bad Münster am Stein and back from there over the mountains. We lost our way once and came home very hot.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 17.7.1884 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Kreuznach Bad Kreuznach July 17. 1884.

Mamma’s birthday. Gave her a vase. Went shooting at the Kaiserau. Great row in Paris on Monday. German flags torn down and burnt before the statue of Strasburg
Pradier , a revolution impending in England. Conflict between the houses over the Reform bill. German papers crying for war against France. Cholera bad in France. Altogether very gloomy prospects on all sides. Hotel Continental windows broken on account of German flags by the mob and Deroulède In the evening went on the water to the corso and fireworks. A man fell into the water and Gee got very excited about it. It rained very much

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 20.7.1884 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Kreuznach Bad Kreuznach July 20 1884.
Drove to Bingen in the afternoon. Had dinner in the Victoria Hotel near the Rhine with very fine view on the Niederwald denkmal. The lightning struck the house in the night.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 21.7.1884 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Kreuznach Bad Kreuznach July 21. 1884 Tuesday.
Shot in the morning with Papa.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 23.7.1884 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Kreuznach Bad Kreuznach July 23. 1884.

Went to the Niederwald Denkmal today. Started at three and crossed the Rhine at Bingen to Rüdesheim from where we went up to the monument by the Zahnradbahn. The view was very extensive but rather tame and the monument itself ought to be twice the size. Returned to here at eight.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 25.7.1884 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Kreuznach Bad Kreuznach July 25. 1884

Walked to the Altenbaumburg with Papa from Münster
Bad Münster am Stein where we went by train at 9.44. The old castle itself is completely ruined. Had some exceedingly sour wine there.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 28.7.1884 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Kreuznach Bad Kreuznach July 28. Monday 1884

Went shooting. Shot a 20 pfennig piece. To the Karlsschüler
Laube in the evening. When we arrived there our seats were taken. Papa made a fearful row so we got them. Bad theater

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 31.7.1884 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Kreuznach Bad Kreunzach. July 31. 1884
Papa started for Paris this evening. Had dinner at the Curhaus before. Gee not at all well.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 1.8.1884 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Kreuznach Bad Kreuznach August 1. 1884. Friday.

Payed a bill at Stöck’s in the morning. Drove with Mamma in the afternoon. Mamma read her new novel Roland de Kérgédérack to me in the evening. The part of the diary and Roland’s birth. I cried a great deal over the diary. Morianne under Georges Penial’s name is coming out end of this month at Calmann Levy’s. Madame Langer is editing it and corrigeing the fautes d’Ortographe. Mamma told me today that she got 100 pounds for Chelia. The story of Roland’s mother is that of Madame Hertel, Lansdorf is Lehndorff. Madame Hertel had 3 children by Lehndorff, taken away of which she got one back by Mamma. They say they are very like Lehndorff.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 3.8.1884 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Kreuznach Bad Kreuznach August 3. 1884 Sunday

Went in a barge on the Nahe in the evening after dinner. The air was beautiful and the scenery with the moon and the occasional lightnings with the clear sky was very peaceful. Mamma says the Madame d’Aubigné certainly wrote the société de Berlin
Vasili, eigentlich Radziwill, Catherine and that Madame Adam Juliette copied it so that not even the printer might see the handwriting

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 3.11.1880 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot Wednesday 3 d November s.r. 6.59 s. sets. 4.29.

I received nothing but bad news today. 1 o That poor grandmama Kessler, Henriette in Hamburg had fallen and hurt herself badly and had her brain shaken 2 o That Wee-wee’s
Brion, Wilma cough is no better. This evening we were all sitting listening to the head (M r Kynnersley when Caddie, the dog, began barking furiously; directly we all jumped up and asked if we might make a sally and see what was a’matter. But the Head sent two boys (Bowring ma. and Bell) alone to see what it was. It turned out to be a man who was stealing the wood of the Bonnfire for the fifth of November but he ran away so we were not allowed to go out allthough while we were singing in the drawing room some other boys that were not singing came in once or twice to give news of what was going on but the Head sent them back every time saying it was nonsense so we had chapel and are going to bed.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 7.8.1884 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Basel August 7. 1884
Started from Creuznach Bad Kreuznach this morning at 12.26 and arrived here this evening when we had dinner with M r Schatz. Stayed at the hotel Euler. Shot with Papa at Creuznach in the morning.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 8.8.1884 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Rigi-Kulm. August 8. 1884

Started from Basle at 7.30 this morning. The scenery in the Jura was very fine but afterwards it got rather foggy so that on the boat from Lucerne to Vitznau and going up the Rigi but afterwards it cleared up a little and we went down to the Kaltbad where we looked at some rooms; but they had not got any to let as they only have half their rooms at their disposition their furniture having been seized. We then walked to the Kanzli with beautiful view on to the lake of Lucerne und the Zuger lake, which is wonderfully blue. There was a curious blue stripe starting from the sun half across the sky as it went down

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 9.8.1884 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Rigi August 9.th. 1885
Got up at 4 to see the sunrise. Not very good. Went to Fluelen by the lake and afterwards to Lucerne by train from where I started for Hamburg.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 23.9.1884 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: London. September. 23. 84.
Arrived here this morning. Mamma at the station to meet me Poor dear Grandmamma Lynch, Caroline not at all well.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 6.10.1884 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. October. 6. 84

Arrived here yesterday evening from London. On the 4th in the afternoon drove to Battersea park with dear Grandmamma and dear Mamma. Talked about Hamburg and described all the people there to dear Grandmamma who seemed amused. In the morning went to Tussauds with Papa whose foot is much better. While in London corrected the proofsheets of Maurianne and read parts of Roland Beides Romane von Alice Kessler. . Grandmamma I am afraid I have seen for the last time poor little dear. She was looking very ill. She gave me 5 pounds and a new suit and overcoat.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 29.10.1884 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg October 29. 84. Friday.
Poor dear Grandmamma died this morning early. Aunt Lulu told me when I came out of school today at 2. Telegraphed to aunt Rose.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 28.11.1884 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. November 28. 1884 Sunday
Fell on the ice at Blümers Auguste und Wilhelm and hurt my knee a good deal it is quite stiff and I can only just hobble about a little

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 30.11.1884 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. November 30. 1884. Tuesday
Doctor came. Told me I must go to bed directly or else my knee might get much worse. Went to bed in the evening at 7.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 21.12.1884 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg December 21. 1884 Tuesday
Am going to start for Paris today. Georg is coming to meet me at Cologne as my knee is not yet quite cured.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 22.12.1884 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris December 22. 1884. Wednesday

Georg very intelectually went to Brussels instead of Cologne so that I had to manage for myself. Lange the station master at Cologne was exeedingly polite to me, saw that I did not hurt my leg, inquired everywhere after Georg and finally gave me a carriage to myself till Verviers where I had to change on account of the cholera; which by the way has completely stopped, in Paris at least, so that the changeing is merely an annoyance for passengers and has no earthly object as Lange himself acknowleged. At Jeumont as I got out Georg rushed up to me with a distracted face and told me all his adventures. He got a good scolding from Papa.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 4.11.1880 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot 4 th November 1880 Thursday.

Today Bonnemaman Lynch, Caroline came to see me and brought me a dreadful shock. Poor dear Grandmama Kessler, Henriette in Hamburg is dead from a fall which she had on Monday and which proved fatal. To think that an unfortunate step can bring death! Papa is in Hamburg because as soon as he heard of the accident he went there. I hope it will not shake him too greatly for he loved her so dearly! and she was so good. She died on the 2 d of November

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 24.12.1884 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris. December 24. 1884. Thursday

Went to Auffmordts Evelyn und William christmas tree this evening. They live in the avenue Marigny near the Champs-Elysées now. Uncle Clement gave me the Théatre of Edmond About Auffmordts silver pencil and penholder. Very amusing at dinner. I took in Miss Fettridge, the little one who was very amusing. Went home at 11 with Mamma.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 25.12.1884 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris December 25. 1884 Friday

Our Christmas tree which I had helped to make this time. Edmond Siefert of course again came half an hour too early. He wailed and complained about his back side the whole evening except when he lamented over Madame Hugues. Gee had Clément, Pauline and the Baby. Boswell and Overbeck were given me by Papa and a lot of other presents. Again sat next to Flossy Fettridge and Edmond Siefert at dinner.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 1.1.1885 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris. January 1. 1885. Friday

Paid visits in the afternoon with Papa in the carriage. I went up to Auffmordts Evelyn und William
but nowhere else on account of my knee.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 7.1.1885 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris. January. Thursday. 1885.
Went to Romeo and Juliet by Gounod at the Opéra Comique; with Heilbronn. She looks very jewish but sings well.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 8.1.1885 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris January Friday. 85.

Stopped at home and read and corrected Roland
Kessler . Was not at all well in the evening so that I could not travel. Fever and violent shivering fits.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 9.1.1885 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris January. Saturday 1885.
Am going to start for Hamburg this evening as I am much better.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 28.3.1885 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. March 28. 1885. Saturday.
Papa arrived this evening. Mamma is ill and cannot come Papas’ tongue is bad too. He lives at the Hamburger Hof.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 29.3.1885 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. March 29. 1885 Sunday.

My confirmation. From home I first drove with the pastorin Blümer, Auguste to aunt Lulu’s and took her and uncle Fritz to the church. Fearful row in the carriage; aunt Lulu and uncle Fritz fighting like cat and dog. At last uncle Fritz’s top hat fell into a puddle as he got out of the carriage. Then drove to Hotel to fetch Papa and from there back to church. Papa went into the Church, I into the so called Sacristei, where we all were assembled. Then Spörri came in and led the way into Church, we following in single file. Papa and aunt Lulu sat in the first row; We sat down around the altar. after Spörri had said a prayer. Then after a hymn we all had to get up and answer some formal questions in a kind of litany, after which we had to go forward two and two and Spörri said a few words to each of us and then gave us both together a sentence out of the Bibel. Me „Kämpfet den guten Kampf des Glaubens und ergreifet das ewige Leben“. We had to stand the whole time about an hour and a half. I was quite dead at the end. Then he blessed us and after some music we went back into the vestry where our friends came and congratulated us. I then drove to the Hotel with Papa and from there to Meyers Auguste und Friedrich where we breakfasted and I saw my presents. Papa and Mamma gave me a magnificent gold watch and chain and a large atlas, Gee a pair of studs, Meyers a locket which is at the same time a seal with Mamma and Papas portrait in it and the Frithjofssage, Kempffs Auguste und Georg golden cuffstuds and Willy Kempffa golden pencil, Hasperg Amanda und Heinrich
Niebelungen, Busses Auguste und Friedrich a leather pocket book, Nita a serviette ring and the children three golden studs. After breakfast all came to congratulate first Busses, Alice Busse who was confirmed on the 27 too. There was chocolate for the ladies, sherry for the gentlemen. Julius Gabe came too. Papa went to Wandsbek with Willy during that time. At half past five went to the hotel and from there to Haspergs to dinner. Saw Belles presents. I gave her „Das Buch der Königin Luise.“
Horn
Papa and Mamma flowers. Great many healths at dinner. Old M r Ehnett toasted Belle, Spörri me in a very pretty speech, Papa Haspergs, old M r Ehnett Paul Hasperg etc. etc. After dinner it was rather stupid. Nothing to be done. Walked home with Papa at about 11. Telegram with many happy returns of the day from Mamma and Gee and letters from both too and from Marie also a sweet little card and picture from dear little Gee. At table sat between Belle and Heine
Hasperg, Heinrich , Alice Busse between Heine and Willy K. very bad place.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 30.3.1885 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. March 30. 1885. Monday

Pastor Blümer came to the Hamburger Hof, where I had slept to see Papa. A little later aunt Lulu. Breakfasted with Papa at the Hotel after which uncle Kempff came. I drove to his Fabrique with him while Papa was at the Exchange. Afterwards went to Papas office with him and saw old M r Schultz. In the evening dined at Kempffs Auguste Wilhelmine und Georg . Very good dinner. Sat next to Alice Busse. The Hasperg girls Helene und Jenny did not come. M r Scheuchle brought out three toasts and was very proud of himself. Papa travelled away after dinner.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 31.3.1885 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Berlin March 31. 1885.

Arrived here this afternoon. Directly went out from the Continental Hotel, where we had reserved some very good rooms by telegraph from Hamburg, to secure places for the torchlight procession in honour of Bismarck. Got very good place „Unter den Linden“ We dined at a Café Unter den Linden and afterwards went to our windows on the third story of a house. We could see everything very well. The procession lasted over an hour, and was very amusing especially the Cameroon niggers who were in one part of the procession. After the procession had passed aunt Lulu and I went down into the street and tried to get to the Wilhelm Strasse where Bismarcks Palace Reichskanzlerpalais is situated; But directly we got down we saw what a fearful crowd there was, and when we got as far as the Friedrichs Strasse another crowd was coming down from that street and trying to cross ours. It was stronger than the crowd we were in and the crash that followed can not be described: we were jolted and knocked and trod on so that it is a wonder we were not squeezed to a jelly. Aunt Lulu clung to me and from time to time gave a feeble squeak, till at last we managed to get into an apothecary’s shop where we bought something some Natron and were let out by the back door. From here we courageously again pushed forward to the Wilhelm Strasse and this time managed to get there by a back street. The smell there, occasioned by the burning torches which were lying about on the pavement, was dreadful. There was an electric light playing on to the Reichskanzleramt but nothing else much worth seeing afterwards home.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 5.11.1880 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot Friday. 5 th November 1880
M. Today the bonnfire is to be lit and the fireworks let off
Evening: The fireworks went off splendidly one of them fell down and going off burnt one of the cad’s trousers

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 1.4.1885 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Berlin. April 1. 1885.

This morning the first thing we did was again to go to the Wilhelm Strasse where we saw a huge pyramid of fruit and flowers and vegetables being carried in to Bismarcks on a stretcher. Afterwards went to see the beginning of the Reichstags building. Not much to be seen, as it is hardly begun. From there we went to the Hotel de Russie or some such name near the Spree and had breakfast. From there to the Rathaus. Very fine and worth seeing. After that aunt Lulu went to the National Gallery and I to the Museum Altes und Neues Museum. Was very tired so that I could hardly enjoy it. Saw the really magnificent picture of Holzschuher Bildnis des Hieronymus Holzschuher by Dürer. I have never in my life seen anything so lifelike. He looks as if he was going to come out of his frame, without any exageration. Afterwards spent a good deal of time looking at the sculptures of Pergamum Pergamonaltar (Berlin) which are also splendid; I could hardly enjoy them though properly today as I was so dead tired. Had to go away at five as the museum shuts then. Went to Table d’Hôte at the Hotel. After that to the Deutsche Theather, where we saw Prinz Friedrich von Homburg
Kleist . Not very interesting.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 2.4.1885 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Berlin. April 2. 1885

Went to the Kaiser Panorama. Photographs of America and Italy Australia etc. Very interesting. Afterwards I again went to the Museum Altes und Neues Museum and enjoyed the Pergamum sculptures very much this time. Was struck by the beauty of the head of the woman who throws the vase with the serpent and of the head broken off a statue. I could sit hours and look at this last one. Also went to the National Gallery and saw and bought a photograph of my favorite little sheperd by Schlüter. Breakfasted at the same café Café Unter den Linden we dined at the first day and then rushed so as to get the train for Hamburg where we arrived this evening.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 26.4.1885 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. April 26. 1885.

Went to the races with Haspergs Amanda und Heinrich . Paul Hasperg came from Braunschweig and rode too but fell with his horse. Dined at Haspergs afterwards. Rather amusing, but very long. Music played during dinner; but very little.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 27.4.1885 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. April 27. 1885 Monday.

Went to the Götterdämmerung
Wagner with aunt Lulu. I liked it very much. Not too loud. Sucher sang very well.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 3.5.1885 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. May 3. 1885.
Dined at Busses Augusta und Friedrich with Gabes Baronin und Baron etc. Very nice. Danced afterwards. Sat between Miss Luce and Alice Busse at dinner. Got rather a soar throat.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 5.5.1885 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg May 5. 1885. Tuesday.
Quite hoarse. Regular extinction de voix. Uncle Clement came but I could not speak with him properly.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 17.5.1885 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. May 17. 1885. Sunday
Poor Gee is very ill. Inflamation of the brain. Please God she will get better again but it is very dangerous. Had a telegram saying she is better.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 20.5.1885 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg May 20. 1885.

Gee has been very, very ill so that the doctors had almost given her up but according to a letter from Papa to aunt Lulu she is a little better and has again eaten a little milk and bread without vomiting it. It has again given me a little hope. I am almost well again, Papas tongue is still bad Mamma very exhausted. If only my darling Gee could get better. Poor little thing she has such dreadful pain Mamma writes, such terrific headaches, she lies away complaining. And she is already so exhausted by the measles. Poor little thing, what a cross she has to bear. The ice has constantly to be changed. I start every time the bell goes for fear of a telegramm or a letter with bad news. Whenever I see aunt Lulu coming it frightens me for fear that something dreadful has happened. How thankful I shall be when, please God, my dear, dear little sister really begins to get better again. I never till now thought one could expect a letter so longingly and yet with such trembling as I do. Everything that happens seems an omen for good or bad. This incertainty is really dreadful. I really tremble ever to be without a book or something to occupy me for fear of the dreadful, dreadful thoughts that arise. Oh how fervently I pray that all may end well; and yet I always feel a kind of oppressing, uncomfortable uncertain feeling, even when reading or working. Everything I read palls upon me and yet I cannot be without a book, I wish for company and when I have it I do not like to talk. Yet how small is my burden compared to that of poor Mamma and Papa and my poor, poor dear little Gee. I do not wonder Mamma can only keep up with Quinine. It is a regular relief to be able to put on paper, what one can tell nobody, write to noone.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 21.5.1885 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. May 21. 1885

Postcard from Mamma. Gee a little better; the doctors now hope to save her. While I think of it I shall make some notes about Roland
Kessler . He came out on the 15th of April and 6 éditions of five thousand (5000) numbers each were sold in the first week. The success was enormous. All the papers full of who Ary Ecilaw is; even English papers write about it. It is going to be translated into English and Swedish. Countess Fürstenberg vermutl. Dolly who is one of the persons meant in it came to Paris on purpose to find out who Ary Ecilaw is. Lemerre pays A. E. 500 francs for every edition, 10 centimes for every copy that is sold. Not much, but toujours quelquechose. Despatch saying that dear little Gee is getting slowly better (successive besser.)

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 22.5.1885 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg May 22. 1885.

Aunt Lulu and uncle Fritz came out and brought me a paperstand and penwiper for my birthday, aunt Gusch Lübkes Kunstgeschichte, Blümers Auguste und Wilhelm
Bismarcks Geflügelte Worte. When we wanted to travel away in the evening we could not as aunt Lulu got such nosebleeding. Dear little Gee, thank God, out of danger.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 10.11.1880 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot. Wednesday 10 th November 1880
I went in to the drawing room to day and spoke with a german lady:, lady Gordons governess.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 23.5.1885 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Copenhagen. May 23. 1885 Saturday

Started at 8.43. at Neumünster aunt Lulu went to the W. C and locked herself in so that she could not get out. With a desperate effort she opened the door and with her hatbands flying managed to get into a III Class carriage while the train was already moving. At Kiel we took the boat to Korsör. Very pretty passage. Langeland lies to ones left all covered with forests and fields; very pretty. Arrived at Korsör at 6. Supper there. Not at all bud. In Copenhagen at 10.30. I managed to get a porter by a pantomime as nobody understands one. Living at the Hotel d’Angleterre on the Kongens Nytorv. Letters from Papa Mamma and dear little Gee who is quite shaved and thank God better. My birthday. I am 17.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 24.5.1885 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Copenhagen May 24. 1885

Got up early and breakfasted. Horrible Coffee. Changed rooms as aunt Lulu insisted upon it; are now on the 4th story; de Charybde en Scylla. Went to Rosenborg. The streets are dreadful here. No pavement. Only stones. Rosenborg is pretty; fine trees but nothing very extraordinary. Saw the ruins of Christiansborg. Went to the Frauenkirche. Thorwaldssens Christ is splendid. The Church is fine too. From there up the runde Turm. Beautiful view. From here to french Restaurant; very good breakfast. Then to Thorwaldsen Museum. His little fischer pleased me particularly. From here to the Lange Linie. Magnificent view all over the sund as far as Klampenborg. All the large Ships passing. The sea azure blue. From here to the Steamers bureau which was shut, and to Amalienborg and the Marmorkirche. Then took cab to station and from there to Klampenborg, where we dined at Gillerups in the Tiergarten; also good. Afterwards walked in the Tiergarten. All the houses are built in the forest which is simply magnificent. One of the finest I have ever seen. Back by Steam tram to Tivoli which was shut. Before Klampenborg also went to Panorama. I have been disappointed in Kopenhagen by the town and mans work except Thorwaldsens, but the scenery is finer than I expected, indeed very beautiful. The forests and fields reaching right down to the sea, with its magnificent colouring.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 25.5.1885 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Copenhagen May 25. 1885

Started for Helsingör at 9. Rather bad weather at first. Ship crammed; met Goebel my master. Sat on deck whole time. Beautiful scenery. The whole coast of Denmark is wooded and green. The coast of Sweden came nearer and nearer. Much more rugged. Breakfasted on board; good. Knackebró with butter very good. Arrived at Helsingör at 12. Very polite old gentleman took us to Hotel and acted as an interpreter when we wanted to get our carriage. Drove to Kronborg. Saw Hamlets
Shakespeare Terrace and the whole castle, picture gallery, tower, from which magnificent view and chapel. Then to Marienlyst. Saw Hamlets grave. Does not look very old. Ophelias’ source is very pretty and has got delicious water. Very polite Swedish girls shewed us the way. Then drove to Hilleback and Odinshöe. Lovely drive along the Sund and beautiful view from Odinshöi as far as Kullen in Sweden. Then drove back to Helsingör and had delicious cakes, ice, and coffee at Pastry cooks. From there by train to Fredensborg. Magnificent park on the border of Esrom See; Normansdalen and italian garden very interesting. From There by carriage to Frederiksborg; very pretty drive through Forest. Frederiksborg very fine. Beautiful paintings by Bloch especially in chapel. Dined at Ludersdorffs Hotel; not very good. Back to Copenhagen by train. Fearfully full; 8 people in one carriage. In the evening at Tivoli, Russische rutschbahn. Dreadful sensation. Very good fireworks.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 26.5.1885 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Copenhagen. May 26. 1885.

Bought photographs after breakfast at Nuermann’s. Then to Prindsens Palais. Very interesting. From there to Nuermanns where we breakfasted. Then strolled about in town and to Oerstedts Park; rather pretty. Then went to Göteborg steamship Uffo and took cabin for this evening. Beautiful evening. looked at the moon through my telescope. The sea was like a lake, the moon shining in silvery ripples on it.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 27.5.1885 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Gothenburg. May 27. 1885

Arrived here this morning after a dreadful passage. When I awoke I noticed the ship was rolling very suspiciously; but I quickly got up threw on my clothes and went on deck where sat down. The motion of the machine was so dreadful though that I began to feel very funny. So I counted everything I could, trees, windmills, mountains to keep my attention occupied. At last I had to rush to the side and was dreadfully sick. I lay down then in the cabin and was alright till aunt Lulu called me to tell me we were in Göteborg. I was then again dreadfully ill and was glad to get on land where we drove to the Hotel Göta Källare (sp. Chaéllare). It was the first time I set my foot on Swedish ground. Very nice hotel. When we had washed we went down to breakfast. After breakfast wrote postcard, then jumped into a cab and drove as quickly as possible to the Station to go to the Trollhättan. Just as we came into the station the train whistled. I rushed onto the platform aunt Lulu after me. I caught hold of a door and had already opened it when a most impertinent man caught hold of it and shut it before our very noses and the train steamed out of the station. Aunt Lulu was dreadfully excited, began to cry, shrieked at me and every body else, so that It was quite fearful. At last I managed to quiet her and we went back to the Hotel. From there to Photograph Shop and by tram to the Slottkogen a very pretty park near here. We walked in it a little and then went back by tram and dined middlingly at the Hotel. After dinner took a drive in a very nice little victoria. The man first drove us to a kind of bellevue The way went through forests and rocks. The whole country here is covered with colossal boulders two or three hundred feet high, with here and there a patch of grass or a hardy tree hanging on to it. These boulders rise abruptly out of the valley as if some giant had strewn them about at random. Sometimes out of fruitful fields, sometimes out of a forest. Some of them are smaller, some regular mountains, but all equally desolate and jugged and contrasting strangely with the fruitful fields and the green forests which grow about their base. They are not single but rise in regular chains from the sea on one side up to the mountain on the other; From one of these boulders we had the view the coachman had driven us to see, and a fine one indeed. On one side the sea cutting right into the land, the steep rocks falling into it and the little red roofed houses strewn like nests around it, on the other the desert and desolate mountains with hardly a tree or a bit of grass on them and the fruitful valleys spreading around them. From here we drove through the town, which is really very fine, to another point de vue. Not so fine as the first. On the way saw lots of children. Remarkably pretty; large blue eyes, fair hair; almost all go barelegged and bare footed, and it is a pleasure to see them their legs and feet are so well made. In fact all Swedes are more or less handsome. I have never in my life seen such a handsome set of people. Slim, tall, beautiful skin. One can see they are the descendants of the Vikings of olden days. Almost all have got remarkably pleasant faces. From here we drove home through the Slottkogen. At Home I first wrote some postcards and then went out to change my photographs but did not do it as the others were too large. After this we went to a kind of musical garden, if one can call the place so, and there eat some ice-kagen. From there to Lorentzberg another such kind of garden. After having heard some music I went in search of a nightshirt as I have forgotten all mine in Copenhagen; but all th shops were shut. Afterwards dined and eat some Knackebrö which is delicious at dinner. In the morning we also went to the museum.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 28.5.1885 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Gothenburg. May 28. 1885.

Started for the Trollhätta at 7.10 this morning. The whole way there thought about Kristiania. Very nice gentleman in carriage with us. scenery very pretty on the way (there). At Station Trollhätta at 10. First eat some execrably bad ragout at Hotel Trollhättan, then took a little boy to lead us to the Cataracts. First he took us to the Locks. All one above the other. Then along the Göta Elfe which here winds though rocks covered with pines. Very soon we heard the noise of the first cataract. The whole rapids are over a mile long. The first is the smallest, but very fine. The boy took us to a tower from which we had a view over the whole rapids, then down to the old lock which is now a very pretty waterfall. From there to the large cataract. The Göta Elf is here about twice as broad as the Seine. We went over a bridge, the fall nearly deafening me, on to a little island in the middle of the cataracts. On both sides the water surges and boils up as if it was lushed by a gigantic whip. It is impossible to describe the roar with with this enormous mass of water bounds down over the rocks, nor the beauty of the scenery. One could sit there hours and look at it and always find new beauties. Especially on the bridges the scene is indescribably grand: the bare rocks with here and there a pine, rising out of the foam which splashes and bounds around them as though it would swallow them up in its seething bosom. After a while we went up one of the colossal boulders which stud the country but lost our way and had to go down and get the boy to lead us, This he did and we had a magnificent view of the whole falls, but not to be compared to the indescribably grand scene from the bridge below. From here he led us back to the Hotel, where we had some beer and coffee and aunt Lulu bought some Knackebrö. At 3 we got into the carriage and drove to the station where we had to wait some time before the train started. As we came into Gothenburg we saw a large fire and when we got out the whole town was running that way. The only cab in the place was taken away from us before our very noses by another man so that we had with the really dreadful shawlpacket to walk to the Uffo. The captain promised to wait a quarter of an hour for us. But with our general luck here again the one cab was taken by a family with a lot of trunks before we could get it, so that we again had to walk. Aunt Lulu gave the shawlpacket a boy to carry and he of course lost her waterproof over which she lamented dreadfully and began to cry. We at last got a cab and drove to the Hotel where we packed everything in a dreadful hurry, but of course missed the Uffo over which aunt Lulu again began to cry. However I managed to calm her and we had dinner, an abominable beefsteak at the Göta Källare. From here we went to the same garden we had been at the day before and heard the music. At 9.35 after tea and two eggs we started for Malmö in a very nice Coupé. I broke my stick though in getting into the train.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 29.5.1885 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Copenhagen. May 29. 1885. Friday.

Arrived back here at three. I slept pretty well in the train. The train from Göteborg to Malmö passes by numberless lakes and the journey is rather interesting. At 5 we arrived at the Wettern lake. It really is enormous at Jönköping one can not see across and might think it was the sea. We arrived at Malmö at 1.30. and directly went down to the Copenhagen boat in the most dreadful heat. The crossing was very good and took about one hour and twenty five minutes. We first drove to the Hotel d’Angleterre where we took rooms and dined at Table d’Hôte and then went to the Poste Restante where there was a letter from Papa for me. Then we went to Frederiksberg a large garden near Copenhagen and from here to the Tivoli where we went in the underground railway, carrousel swing etc. and listened to the Music, which was very fair.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 30.5.1885 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Copenhagen. May 30. 1885.

Went to the Sammlung Nordischer Altertümer but could not get in. So I walked home by Christiansborg slowly. Breakfasted at Niemeyers again. Boat started at 3. Very pretty going out of port. Passed Möen in the evening. Fine Chalk rocks but nothing like England. Passage good.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 31.5.1885 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. May 31. Sunday 1885.
Arrived back here this morning at 10. Aunt Lulu of course forgot all our trunks in Lübeck.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 24.6.1885 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. Wednesday June 24. 1885.

Bugenhagen Festival. At school at 9 and from there to church in procession. Kraeusler preached in the Petri Kirche. Made a great many mistakes. After Church the Statue
Pfeiffer was unveiled. One Senator Hachmann made a speech rather good. The statue is really very nice, better than I thought. In the afternoon after having breakfasted at Kempffs Auguste und Georg went to Blankenese by boat and then to Thierrys park. Very amusing. During dinner acting. Home late after having supped in town.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 23.6.1880 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ems 23 of June 1880 Sun rises 3,45 set 8,19

This morning papa and I go up to the Concordiathurm and on the way up we see the Heinzelmännchenlöcher which are holes that go so far into the mountain that one has sent dogs in and they have never come out again This afternoon M r Maxheimer my teacher comes at 6 o’clock. Today there are fireworks, they are very pretty especially those on the water. Bee Brion, Wilma slept all through the noise and all and did not even wake at the bombardade.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 13.11.1880 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot Saturday 13 th November.
The head Sneyd-Kynnersley has just begun this evening to read Holmby house by White Melville after having finished the Maid of Sker by Blackmore.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 27.6.1885 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg June 27. 1885. Saturday.

The large Kneipe or Commers for Bugenhagen my first. Of course fuchs. First supped a Johsts. Then met rest of friends at school Johanneum and from there to Borgert in a body. Rumours of death of Emperor. Of course not true. Schrader president. Great deal of speechyfying. The best was the Directors. Bugenhagen and the marriage in Cana, history of Bugenhagen festival. After the director was gone it got more and more boisterous. Great deal of singing, „Fuchs, Fuchs“ in between, „Einen steigen“, Silentium from the top of the tables and the rapier comes down on the tabel with a fearful bang. Of course somebody is speaking but nobody listening, much too occupied with drinking. Then at the end of the speech the inevitable „Ad exercitium Salamanderis, Eins, Zwei, Drei etc.“ and then again „Fuchs, Fuchs“ etc. At 11.30 Leithäuser no longer quite sober. Speaks with fearful screaming and gesticulating. At 12 a cat (Kater) comes in but is expelled by the president for disturbance, while the most uproarious laughter breaks out. At 12.30 Fruhstücks Pause. Another Beefsteak. Breakfast with Schrader, Röthiger and Leithäuser. At 1 the Kneipe begins again. At 2 I walk home with Gudenrill, certainly not quite so sober as I was when I came.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 28.6.1885 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg June 28 1885
Fearful Katzenjammer. Feel very bad. Can not eat or drink anything except Sodawater.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 12.7.1885 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. July 12. 1885. Sunday.

Dined at Busses Augusta und Friedrich . Met Gompel, young man from Leipzig. Puppe lent Roland
Kessler to Baronin Garbe. Lost 5 Marks on „Leben und leben lassen“ with Gompel.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 18.7.1885 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: S t Germain July 18. 1885. Saturday
Arrived here this evening. Papa and Kündig met me at Station in Paris. Dined at Café near Gare S t Lazare. Afterwards came out here where Mamma at Station. Papa’s tongue bad. Lily Davet’s marriage.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 19.7.1885 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: S t Germain. July 19. 1885.

Lusks, Davets, Jenkins’s dined. Before dinner drove out with Lusks to the forest in vis à vis. Not very pretty drive. Davets of course arrived at 8 instead of 6; they had missed and lost everything. Alice Davet not well.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 22.7.1885 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: S t Germain. July 22 1885. Wednesday.
Went to D r De la Marre. Said I was very anémique. To be in the air much.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 23.7.1885 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: S t Germain July 23. 85. Thursday
Boated with Papa and Mamma at Bou gival. Papa and I rowed. Went as far as bridge. 2 hours on the water. Hands rather hurt.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 24.7.1885 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: S t Germain July 24. 85. Friday.

Again went to Chatou to fetch Papa to row. After rowing went to the Café Rocher, where we dined very well. Very neat little monkey at Restaurant. Beautiful drive home by moonlight. Low spirited on account of Papa’s tongue.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 25.7.1885 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: S t Germain July 25. 1885.

Took Gee boating with us in the afternoon. She did not like it as she was very frightened. Bathed at the Pecq in the morning. Very primitive. Bathing establishment on an island. Baby and Marie went with me.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 26.7.1885 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: S t Germain July 26. 1885.

Drove to Poissy with Papa in the morning to bathe. Had to take a boat to row us out as the bathing establishment is very bad. Boat hat curtains to make two cabins etc. just like a bathing cabin and was much nicer than the Pecq bathing place. Very hot. Drove in the forest in the afternoon; past the Mare aux Cannis, a pretty little pond in the forest. Dined very well at the Henri IV.. Turbot Sauce hollandaise, Chicken aux tomates, ice. Baby Brion, Wilma would not come.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 15.11.1880 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot. Monday. 15 th November
Today I took my 1 rst german lesson with M rs Kynnersley we are reading „Wilhelm Tell“ by Schiller M rs Kynnersley takes one part I the other

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 27.7.1885 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: S t Germain. July 27 Monday. 1885.

Drove to Poissy with Mamma to fetch Papa for boating. Could not get a man to steer us so Mamma had to. Of course directly ran into an island. Afterwards got on very well. River lovely. Innumerable green islands, the willows drooping into the water. One might have thought one was in a virgin forest so wild and solitary was the scene. As we rowed back the red rays of the sinking sun piercing through the feathery tufts of willows and other trees and glittering like liquid fire in the water were quite farylike I thought of Goethes „Auf allen Gipfeln ist Ruh“ Wanderers Nachtlied , and of ther Erlkönig.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 28.7.1885 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: S t Germain July 28 1885. Tuesday

Worked hard at the English translation of Roland
Kessler , which I am correcting. Finished 50 pages. Drove on the terrace in the moonlight after dinner. Lovely view. Mamma went to Paris in the morning. I went to Vésinet in the afternoon to Rue Thiers 2. to have the translation copied by a Miss Hodgeson.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 29.7.1885 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: S t Germain. July 29. 1885. Wednesday.

Went to Paris in the morning to see Johnston. First went to Déclat where Papa was pulveriséd, then to Printemps and Johnston. Wrote to aunt Lulu and Pastor Blümer at bureau then breakfasted very well at Noël’s in the Passage des Princes I think. In the afternoon came home just in time for the horrible Blood drinking and read Madame de Mineleko Mamma’s new novel. Afterwards drove to Station with Mamma to meet Papa, had to wait a long time till half past 8. Talked about her novels to Mamma.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 30.7.1885 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: S t Germain July 30 1885.
Mamma went to Paris in the morning. Took inventaire of wine, read and played piano. Drove on the Terrace and through the forest to Maisons-Laffitte in the afternoon with Mamma and Papa

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 31.7.1885 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: S t Germain July 31. 1885. Friday

Worked at the translation of Roland
Kessler and lay in the hammoc in the Garden reading in the Morning. Gee pretended to put me to sleep and rocked Thérèse her young goat in the hammock. The animal liked it very much. Drank blood for the last time. Went away by the 5.35 train. Papa met us at the Station in Paris. Drove with two Omnibusses to the Gare de l’Est. Dined at Restaurant near that Station. Poor Papa can not travel with us on account of his tongue.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 1.8.1885 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Rigi Kaltbad August 1. 1885. Saturday

Arrived here at 1. We had started from Paris last evening and went to Bâle by sleeping-car. Saw Belfort at 5 which interested me very much. At Bâle could not breakfast as train was late and went on directly. Gee travelled the whole way with Noirot her black doll in her arms and a lot of stones, a shell etc as Handgepäck. She was very preoccuppied because Roland her smallest and prettiest „Lapin“ as she calls her rabbits was forgotten by her in the garden. At Lucerne managed to get all the luggage on board in time and so arrived safely. Marie very sick but better in the evening. Had dinner at 11 and Supper at 7.30. Met Herr Kusenberg a Francfort Bank director. Weather not very fine.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 2.8.1885 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Rigi Kaltbad. August 2. 1885 Sunday.

Got up at 7.45. and after breakfast read the papers and listened to the music on the Terrace till 10.30 when I had my bath. Afterwards walked with Gee to the First and up a hill near it. We got caught in the rain though in coming home, and had to take shelter in the First station. After Table d’hôte again listened to the music and read and then walked to the Känzli with Mamma, Gee and Lina who was very frightened at some cows; en plus the fog suddenly came down so we had to turn back. Drank milk at 5 and supped at 7. In between I numbered the english Roland
Kessler . After Supper there were very fine fireworks which Gee came out to see in her nightgown. Afterwards a house was carried about with pictures of judges, priests etc. in a court of justice and some thing about a „heiliges Strumpfband“ and „3 Tage Arrest“ and Reporters.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 3.8.1885 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Rigi Kaltbad. August 3 1885 Monday.

Took my bath before breakfast and after breakfast sat by the music and read. Then started for First with Gee. But she declared she was dead tired as soon as we had gone a few steps; so I went home and took a walk to the Känzeli and a little further down with Mamma. At dinner made acquaintance of young Swabach Paul. His parents are the Swabachers Leonie und Julius of the société de Berlin . He told me Gerard the sécrétaire of the Empress Augusta and Madame Novikoff had written it. His brother is a professor or is going to be one; that I could not make out. They live 7 Wilhelmsplatz in the Palais Radziwill Reichskanzlerpalais ; so they must be very rich. They are Jews as Mamma says. In the afternoon played cards and billards with Swabach and an American. After Dinner I numérohéd Roland
Kessler and read the disclosure scene in the piece, which Mamma has very much improved. S. says Gérard wrote the whole information containedined in the Société de Berlin to Gambetta in private letters and that when Gambetta died Madame Adam bought the letters and out of the information fabriquéd the book. Enfin, so many people; so many versions, like about Rol. which Mad. de Kolemine, Princess Ratzwill; Princess Serge Lydie Puschkoff and dozens of others were said in the papers to have written. Although this book has had such success Lemarre will not pay anything and always evades the question when asked.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 4.8.1885 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Rigi Kaltbad. August 4. 1885. Tuesday

After breakfast walked with Schwabach Paul at the music; Then with him Mamma and Gee to Känzeli and with him a good way further down on a very bad road. After that sat and read on the Terrace till dinner. After the music, Mamma, Gee, Schwabach and I went up to the Kulm from where we had a beautiful view, much better than last year. We missed the 4.50 down train and so had to wait till 6.30. During this time we read papers and I played chess with Schwabach. In the evening dined at Table d’Hote and walked at the music. S. assured me Princess C. Radziwill had written Roland
Kessler as her name was contained in Ary Ecilaw.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 5.8.1885 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Rigi Kaltbad August 5 1885 Wednesday.

Walked or rather tried to walk up the Rigi Rothstock with Schwabach Paul. I tried to take a short cut, which are proverbially the longest. Soon we got to a place when we could neither get up nor down, so we had to go back. Schwabachs Leonie, Julius und Paul travelled away at 1.45. In the afternoon I took a long walk with Valentin. First to Unterstetten from there to the Klösterli and then back home. He of course told me all about his ailments etc. and how the eating in Spain made him sick. Came home about 7 and dined at Table d’Hôte.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 22.11.1880 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot Monday 22 November
It is freezing hard to day as it has been yesterday

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 6.8.1885 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Rigi Kaltbad August 6. 1885. Thursday.

Worked at the Känzli in the morning and began my direction West to the Scheideck by rail in the afternoon. Got caught in a fearful shower so that we did not see much. Valentin told his unavoidable Bonaparte story and proposed himself as the Chirany Chatanoj in Noahs ark when the carriage was darkened. When we came home found traité from Lemerre and his accounts. He gives Mamma 2195 francs but says he is going to give her more. He pays her 40 centimes a volume for the first 2000, 50 c. for numbers 2000 to 10000 and 60 c. for all over 10000. Read Madame de Mineleko in the evening.. Cholera came to Marseilles. Over 40.000 people have died and 10000 been attacked in Spain already. Much worse than last year when only 20,000 died in Spain (500), France and Italy together. Political horizon rather black. England and Russia again rather quarrelsome. France and Germany not on best terms. I am reading the Société de Londres by a „Diplomate Etranger“ Vasili well written and interesting.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 7.8.1885 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Rigi Kaltbad. August 7. 1885.

Walked with the Dubos girls and the Delboses to the Klösterli after the morning music. Monsieur Delbos the „Marquis“ very amusing. Saw the exvotos in the Klösterli chapel Maria zum Schnee ; little wax legs, arms, hearts etc. and pictures. Rack for breakfast. In the afternoon walked to First with the party as in the morning and Mamma and Valentin besides. He declared the Leavenworth case
Green had had twelve thousand editions which I maintained was impossible. After Supper read Madame de Mineleko
Kessler . Some parts are really very good. The conversation between Mineleko and the King especially. The people in the ball scene are real people such as the Countess Langweilig and her three daughters. Fearful Wolkenbruch this evening, in fact I have never seen anything so unconstant as the weather up here. They say all the old parties are braeking up in England and that the Election will make a demarque

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 8.8.1885 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Rigi Kaltbad. August 8. 185. Saturday.

First worked a little in Mamma’s room. Then we had to déménagé to upstarirs 48 and 49. I have got 78. Afterwards walked with Dubos’s to the Känzli and down on the road to Zug. In coming back I found quite a young little bird dying of hunger by the wayside. So I walked quickly home with it on my pocket handkerchief. It all the time looked at me so piteously and opened its poor little mouth quite wide to have something to eat. When I came home I directly gave it some bread crumb and milk which it took to very well and devoured. In the afternoon it hopped about quite happily. After the music at about 3.45 we Mamma Valentin and Dubos started for the Rothstotz which we got up allright and then came home by the First. I then sat on the balcony and read Madame de Minelko and the Roman d’une Sensitive while Mamma wrote the last chapter of Mad. de. M. of which she had also greatly improved the first this morning. Had beautiful Alpenglühen in the evening of which Mamma also wrote a description for the Lys. In the evening after Supper went with Dubos’s to the Känzli to see the illumination of the lake, which was not very beautiful

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 9.8.1885 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Rigi Kaltbad August 9. 1885 Sunday

Slept late, so did not take my douche. Directly after breakfast which I had alone walked up to the Kulm with Mamma and Gee. Poor Mamma cut her finger badly at breakfast. We took 1 ¼ to walk up and had a magnificent view from the top. The finest I have ever had from the Rigi. I went up to the top, Mamma and Baby stopped down at the Hotel. Back we took the train as Mamma and Baby were very tired. In the afternoon after early dinner at 12.30. Wrestling match. Very stupid. Then read in Mammas room and at 6 went to Känzli where we saw the sun set. A slight attempt at Alpenglühen. After Supper read the Roman d’une Sensitive and before going to bed fed the bird. Germany has annexed the Kilimandjaro. Very glad. Unfortunately row with Sansibar impending. Fleet collecting in Mauritius. No doubt for me of good end. for Germany, as the Elections are coming on in England.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 10.8.1885 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Rigi Kaltbad. August 10. 1885 Monday

Worked at the Känzli in the morning. In the afternoon walked down to Romiti Felsenthor with Mamma and Valentin. Very nice walk. The Felsenthor very interesting. The people at the Felsenthor Hotel were horrified at our asking for two lemons for lemonade, so Valentin and I had beer and only Mamma lemonade. At the station met mother Goose (Miss Ricardo) as Valentin calls her. When we wanted to get in a fat old man came pushing up, and with a good tang in the ribs asked me „Ob ich dächte dass ich allein da wäre“ „Oh nein! sie sind jedenfalls dick genug dass man sie sieht“ About this all the Swiss people in the carriage were horrorstricken and made remarks and when V. gave it them one man nearly got a stroke. Beautiful Alpenglühen, the Jungfrau magnificent. After dinner spoke with Valentine about the Göschenen tour. He did not seem to approve of it. Over 1500 people died in Spain the day before yesterday.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 11.8.1885 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Rigi Kaltbad. August 11. 1885. Tuesday.

Again worked in the same place in the morning. In the afternoon read the papers and walked up to Staffelhöhe with Mamma and Baby. As it began to lighten and thunder we walked back very soon though and I wrote and read in Mamma’s room. Mamma read the last two chapters of Mad. de Mineleko to me, which she has shortly written. She is now working at Wilma de Lashas. which she began in April while Lemerre was reading Roland. Danced in the evening. This morning at five the Steamwashapparatus began to go and woke everyone up. It sounds like a battery of cannons. Du reste we are not spared noise here. There was an individual on my landing who began grating his violin and producing the most heartwrending sound every morning before six. Thank goodness he is gone now. There is also a female who begins to thump the piano at five in the morning and pierces the temples and nerves of the house inmates with the most terrifying shrieks. In fact if one was to describe all the inhabitants of the Kaltbad one could get together a good lot of cures. There is that Roumanian with a craze on Sarah Bernhardt, with frizzly hair, a cadaverous looking face and wild eyes. À propos of her, the other day when her bathing woman did not dry her properly she went to her dressing table, pulled out a dagger and. told the terrified woman that if she did not dry her on the spot she would kill her. There is old baron Oppenheim whose whig nearly flew away the other day and who always walks as if he had got the stomack ache, there is the „femme au panache“ with the white feathers towering high above her, there is Mother Goose Ricardo with her rouge and cosmetics and yellow dresses and red and pink hats and juvenile look and 90 years, then old Ibrahim who is in love with prince George and last but not least old Mariassi with her brown veil and dust cloak, who always sits with her back to the mountains: The charlatan is represented by D r Hermann. 4500 cases and 1663 deaths of the cholera in Spain yesterday. German demonstration before Zanzibar and General Grant’s funeral are the great topics now.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 12.8.1885 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Rigi Kaltbad. August 12. 1885 Wednesday.

Walked up to Staffel with Mamma and Baby Brion, Wilma this morning. Mamma said she was going to try and publish her next book herself as she had found out Lemerre made over 50,000 francs by R. She thinks Wilma de Lashas her best book. She also told me Hachette was the greatest buyer of her book and that he often buys 100 exemplares. We sat on a bench above Staffel. In the afternoon read newspapers and again looked at chalet which Mamma thinks of taking near Bellevue; 4 rooms on each floor and also two balconies. Afterwards walked to a bench on the Känzeli road and read or rather began reading FrepiersDer Autor ist Figuier. „Lendemain de la mort.“ When we came home Lina nearly trod on the bird; but it luckily was not hurt. Poor Babys abcess bad also but much better through the figs. In the evening after supper there was an acrobat Sidi Ben Caliphak who doubled himself up etc. an Arab with his wife whose tricks we saw with the ungetriddable of M rs Langley from our balcony.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 13.8.1885 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Rigi Kaltbad. August 13. 1885. Thursday

Worked at the Kanzli in the morning and Mamma took the Chalet. In the afternoon saw M rs Ware’s sister and walked to Unterstetten with Mamma M rs Langley and Valentin after having had tea at First. Read the Lendemain de la mort
Figuier in Mamma’s room after supper which was simply horrible today.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 14.8.1885 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Rigi Kaltbad. August 14. 1885 Friday

Played with Baby Brion, Wilma and read at the music in the morning. Afterwards I walked to the Känzli and wrote to young Schwabach Paul. Then I played ball with Gee. She laughed a good deal and was very amused. Mamma sat writing. After dinner sat with Gee down at the music and read the Lendemain de la Mort
Figuier . Also talked with M r Delfosse about Auvergne and Auvergnat. He said the country was most interesting and the language very soft. After this walked out with Mamma. First saw the châlet which seems very nice and has 8 rooms. Then went on the way to First. We were not very far when we saw dear little Baby running after us and Marie behind her. As she stood admiring the painting bear with the spectacles Kuseberg came up and after long marchendeing he bought it for her and gave it her afterwards in the hôtel. Unfortunately he walked with us the whole time so that we were glad to get home. We had not been home long when M rs Langley came up to see the Alpenglühen from the balcony. Of course she stuck till 7.20. At supper she almost had a row with old Langley because she very tactlessly asked Mamma to get her half a pound of bonbons at Lucerne in the short time she had there. Old Langley got furious and said he had never seen such a tactless woman. After dinner sat a little with Mamma and Gee while they were going to bed, and Gee lay a little in Mammas bed afterwards and I talked to her. She showed me her foot and was very amusing. Bought presents for Blümers Auguste und Wilhelm in the afternoon and got Gee a Schweizerhaus with which she was very pleased. 1525 people died in Spain of cholera.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 15.8.1885 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Zürich. August 15. 1885

Started from Kaltbad with Mamma and Gee for Zürich at 8. Gee told me a story about goats etc. the whole way down to the Lake. Old M r Potter was at the Station to see me off. In the boat had a beautiful but windy journey to Lucerne where I lunched with Mamma and Gee in the S t Gotthard Hôtel. Afterwards got into the train and went to Zürich alone. Mamma and Gee saw me off. Read the Lendemain de la Mort
Figuier . At Zurich Papa was at the station with another old gentleman, and we drove about the town with Wehrli. First to the Webeschule, then to the Lake. Afterwards we went up the tower of the Cathedral Grossmünster and then drove to the station, whence I started for Hamburg. Papa went as far as Bâle with me. In Bâle I got a waggon lit to Frankfort.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 24.11.1880 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot Wednesday. 24 November 1880

We went for a long walk to day for about 10 miles. On our walk lots of chaps tried to hurt me but the big chaps were on my side so that Hill was hurled into a ditch Powell and Schuster when they were charged begged pardon and said to Tomlin „I thought you wanted to have him (me) prisoner“ Wormald got a licking from M r Chapman so I came home all right

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 16.8.1885 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. August 16. 1885 Sunday.

Arrived this evening. Aunt Lulu at the station. Blümers Auguste und Wilhelm gone. Only Freises and M rs Wensthoff, the Pastorins sister in the house. In Hannover some officers got in, one of whom read R. Roland von Alice Kessler

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 24.8.1885 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. August 24. 1885.
Dear little Gee’s birthday. She is eight years old now and is getting quite big.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 30.8.1885 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg August 30 1885.
Freises went to America by the Wieland this morning. They had to go as far as Stade in a tender.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 5.9.1885 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. September 5. 1885. Saturday.

Dined at Kempffs Auguste und Georg , where I played and afterwards looked at the spanish pictures which are very pretty. The German Embassy has been attacked, the windows broken in and the German coat of arms burnt in Madrid at the Puerta del Sol. Socialist demonstration in Saragossa. Outlook black. Alphonso will probably be turned out on account of this Caroline affair.Streit um die Karolineninseln zwischen dem Dt. Reich u. Spanien. They say Germany has annected Yap. Wissmann has traced the Cassai to its mouth and found its mouth the same as that of the Cuango.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 8.9.1885 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Heligoland. September 8 1885. Tuesday

Started from Hamburg with aunt Lulu this morning at 8 by the the Freia. The voyage on the Elbe was very interesting and the crossing good afterwards. When we arrived we of course had to pass the Läster allee. We were then beset by people offering us lodgings. We at last found some in the „Princess Royal“. We then dined in the Princess Alexandra Restaurant and afterwards had ourselves drawn up to the Oberland by lift. We from there saw the sun go down and then walked to the end of the island along the cliffs. The island is strongly indented everywhere, and one need not be a geologist, to see that it is slowly crumbling away. The decay seems to have got hold of the officials here too. The solitary policeman and the coastguards looked quite forlorn amongst this german population. The only defence of the place are five diminutive cannons, ranged behind a battlement 1 foot hight, which looks as if it had sunk into the ground, awstruck by the dreadful weapons of defence planted on it. I had expected to find a fortress, a stronghold of England in the North Sea and I found nothing but a watering place, a second Margate, where the Hamburgers go for a trip. I firmly believe that in its present state one small man of war might take place in half an hour and hold it. By nature it is a second Gibraltar, and if well defended would be imprennable but now - it is not worth the purchase money England wants Germany to pay for it. The Caroline Question looks blacker. They say Alfonso is doomed, and then – war is inevitable.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 9.9.1885 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Heligoland. September 9. 1885. Wednesday.

Went over to the Düne directly after breakfast. The weather was fearful, the rain coming down in buckets. At the Düne aunt Lulu and I bathed The waves were beautiful, but very strong. While we were bathing the wind got worse and worse so that we were afraid we would not be able to get back. But we got into the boat. When we were about midway we seemed to be in a regular whirlpool. The waves rushed into the boat from all sides, it rose and fell like a cockleshell and added to this the sheets of rain that came down drenched us all to the skin. It went through my waterproof and all, so that, when I came home, I had to change everything. We breakfasted at „Princess Alexandra“. Afterwards we again sailed out with four gentlemen. Again the sea came into our boat, but we did not get so wet, as the rain had stopped. We tried to get to the wreck, but could not. After our return I went to the reading room. Affairs look better. The war danger is diminished. We then dined in the Deutsche Hof at Bufes; very good. After dinner we again sailed for an hour with Ludwig Krüss. This time the sea was pretty quiet. We supped at home; very fair.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 10.9.1885 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Heligoland. September 10. 1885.

Got up early, but found weather too bad to go over to the Düne; the waves are too large there. So we took a sailing boat at 8.30 and sailed out. It was beautiful, the waves being longer than yesterday and much higher, so that we could often not see the masts of the ships before us. We again had Krüss, and bargained to keep him till 12 for 4 Thalers. His boat belongs to Professor Oppholtz of Vienna. We first came back at 10 and had a warm breakfast, and when we went out on the pier met the two Loppmanns, whom we offered to sail with us, which the accepted very willingly. We again went right out and got a good view of the German man of war. There are two english cutters, the Mermaid and Rose, in the Habour too. After dinner, which we again had at Bufes we wanted to go away by the Cuxhafen, but the weather was so bad it could not go. Aunt Lulu was in a dreadful way about it. And it is very unpleasant. However we marched home again with all our luggage and then again sailed with Peter Friedrichs this time, and two other gentlemen. He went out much further than any of the others, and the waves were dilightful. But we soon had to come back on account of the wind, and I then went upstairs, read the papers in the Conversations Haus and had dinner there afterwards. Aunt Lulu kept on going to sleep. Bismarck seems to be retreating before Spain. Please God not.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 11.9.1885 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Heligoland September 11. 1885.

Sailed in the morning nearly as far as the wreck, after having bathed. Then went home nad got ready to start. At 12 we went off with the Cuxhafen. Passage middling. Had breakfast on board and dinner at the Restaurant in the Train. Arrived home at about 10.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 21.9.1885 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Hamburg. September. 21. 1885. Monday

Spanish difficulty more or less stationery. There is a revolution in East-Rumelia since Thursday or Frieday. Alexander of Bulgaria has accepted the crown of Rumelia. Turky concentrating her troops in Adrianopel. Cholera bad in Palermo. 200 cases yesterday. Also cases in Parma and Italy.

ns0:p.ns0:note: Zu den Vorfällen in der Türkei sind zwei Zeitungsausschnitte eingeklebt, einer beigelegt. Vom 19.9. und 26.9. Der dritte, ohne Datum, ist überschrieben mit "Die ... des Staatsstreichs".

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 26.11.1880 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot Friday the 26 th November 1880

We began digging today. We are digging away part of the hill so as to make a lawn tennis field. We are to level the ground by building a wall and filling it up with earth which is to be covered with gravel.
