M rs Kynnersley is very ill and the doctor is frightened that her cold will turn into rheumatic feaver. D r Fragg comes very often.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 27.11.1880 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot Saturday 27 th November 1880

This afternoon in coming in from digging Hill and Thompson (minor) harassed me by not letting me into the lobby. I got into a terriffic rage I jumped up flew at Thomson (minor) jumped on to him pale with fury, caught hold on him by the scruff of his neck, pulled his hair and ears till he screamed, hacked, kicked bit like an infuriated bull - then I let go my grip rushed upstairs banged my door and poured forth on him every name I could possibly think of said that I would like to throw him out of the window that he would murder me; Percy Heber-Percy tried to interfere I encounterd his remonstrances with a hoarse laugh at last M r Cook came up attracted by the row and told me not to make such a noise. At last I dropped on to my bed exhausted, panting breathless my head reeling with all the guilty conscience of having badly hurt somebody as I thought. To my rage succeeded tears to my bad language prayer. My excitement had been too much for me I was half mad, pale and hardly able to stand I left my room and went down into the lybrary. If only my passion does not bring me to a bad end one day!

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 28.11.1880 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot Sunday. 28 November
There is a new altar cloth in chapel today purplish blue and silver it is very pretty and looks very well with the new curtains

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 2.12.1880 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot 2: December. Thursday

This morning I put down Uffington a peg, at breakfeast. We were talking together when Uffington says:
„Who is that blunderbuss, that fat female who came to see you.
-. I never knew I had any blunderbusses or fat females in my family“
I answer with the greatest calm. This only shews too well how I and all my family are hated here by allmost everybody.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 7.12.1880 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot December 7 1880
Today the spring which we discovered yester day has allready filled up a lot of holes and is running fast

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 9.12.1880 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot December 9

Percy Heber-Percy says he knows more about geology than the head
Sneyd-Kynnersley

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 24.6.1880 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ems 24 of June 1880

This morning papa and I walked to the Lindenbach which is a little café on the mountain from there we took a somewhat vertical road but we very soon had to leave this and go on a small path which we confidentially followed and which brought us, after having made the round of the mountain back to the very same place of the road we had left it however we went in to the forest and came home safe after having been swamped for the rain was coming down in torrents as usually it does here in fact I believe rain is the speciallity of Ems.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 10.12.1880 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Dec 10

Today they formed a meeting at football calling it .F.K.O.S. = funky Kessler of scrimmages. In the evening in coming home I tried to chloroform myself; but Palk saved me by looking into my room with his glass, for smelling the chloroform he thought there was something up; at last he managed to calm me down and I walked into my schoolroom but having been, what I deemed insulted, by Wormald I jumped up and collared him nailing him down onto the form trembling with rage but he jumped up and knocked me in the eye. At tea the head Sneyd-Kynnersley said that if there was any fighting we would be severely punished. In the evening in M r Samson’s schoolroom Thomson (minor) attacked me and told Mason to hold „He wont hurt you“ said he but I in my rage sent Mason flying against the bookcase and knocked a hole into his head then I with fury attacked Thomson (mi.) who gave me a hack then all at once M r
Cook and M rs Kynnersley came in and we went down to the concert

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 11.12.1880 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot Dec 11.

I very nearly got into a row this morning the head Sneyd-Kynnersley
told me to come up to his room after chapel But I think Hall ma. and Bowring ma. said that the others also teased me so he lectured us all and let us go.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 13.12.1880 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot Dec 13 Monday

Today is the distribution of Prizez At 3 o’clock Aunt Rose and aunt Lulu arrive At 2 ½ there is a great scuffle inthe passages; we have been told to go down into the library we all take our seats and presently the ladys and gentlemen take their seats. The head Sneyd-Kynnersley gets up and makes a short report of the third set and 4 th division. The head sits down and says „I leave the other reports to M r Macdonald, upon which M r Macdonald gets up and gives the following reportHier war ein beidseitig bedrucktes Blatt eingeklebt, das wohl einem yearbook o. ä. der Schule entnommen und mit "Kessler" unterzeichnet ist. Jetzt ist das Blatt lose in die Seiten des Tagebuches gelegt. Breite: 11,1 cm, Länge: 18,1 cm. Der Text lautet wie folgt (Nicht alle Formatierungen wurden übernommen):
St. George School, Ascot
TRIALS, CHRISTMAS, 1880.
Report of the Examiner, Rev. F. W. Macdonald, M. A, Queen’s College, Oxon.

After I had set the papers for these trials, I felt afraid that they would be too hard for the boys, but as soon as I began to look over the answers, I found that, though the standard was much higher than that of last trials, the boys were generally up to it. I have been much struck with the great neatness displayed throughout, and the even character of the work in the school, which shews that in this school the dull boy is not sacrificed to the clever one as is so often the case, but all pains are taken with each individual.

In „Arithmetic,“ the work is very good and above the average, the Practice sums being particularly well done, while the Proportion and Algebra are rather weak: Fry, Tomlin, and Jay are deserving of great praise, while I notice the accuracy of Waterhouse, and the reverse with respect to Hall, ma. and Heysham.
In the „French“ which is generally good, Fry, Ferguson, and Bowring, mi, are preeminent.

The Scripture astonished me; it was excellent throughout, but Fry and Tomlin, who both got full marks, Olliver, Whittaker, Bell, Palk, Scott and Kessler, are particularly deserving of praise; Bald must pay more attention to this subject.
The „History and Geography“ were well done, Fry, Mackenzie, and Kessler shewing most proficiency.

The „English“ paper was answered as well as I expected, and I should imagine that essay writing was practised a good deal, as nearly every boy gave me his opinion as to the advantages and the reverse of either Old age, Peace, or Pride.

In the Classical subjects, the „Grammar“ in all divisions was good: the papers were difficult, but still in Division I. there was no boy who did not obtain half marks, while Fry, Heysham, and Ferguson were within 100 of full marks: in Division II., Mackenzie and Bowring, ma, were preeminent, but Thomson, mi., and Hall, mi., some way behind the rest.
In Division III. the Latin Grammar was particularly good; Bald heads the list, and Trelawny who is worst, has obtained nearly half marks.
In Latin Prose, there is little fault to find, but Division I. must be careful about the use of the Subjunctive: Fry and Ferguson, did excellent papers.

In Division II. Powell and Bell shewed that they had taken great pains, while Jay and Schuster lost marks through carelessness, and Hall, mi. and Watson evidently consider Latin Prose beneath their attention.
In Division III. Kessler is far above the rest.

In the Translations, Division I. all did well except Hall, ma., who I fancy lacked perseverance; in Greek Translation they were weak, but this is accounted for by the fact that they have not attempted idiomatic Greek.
Division II. Bell did well, but Watson, Hall, mi., and Thomson, mi. were weak. The papers of this division on this subject, shew that they are well grounded and carefully taught.

Division III. had too difficult a paper, but Kessler and Blundell did so well that they led me to think that some of the others might have done better; this division evidently knew more than they could express on paper.
In Latin Verses, the standard is not high, Division II. did better than those above them.

To sum up, the work appears to be thorough - there is great uniformity. Where all branches of education are attended to equally, it is difficult to mention any one point in which the boys particularly excel, but, if anything, I am inclined to think that the French has been the most satisfactory work in an examination which has been decidedly above the average of attainments amongst boys of this age.
(Signed), F. W. MACDONALD, M.A., Oxon.

Vicar of Stapleford and Berwick, Wilts.Ende der Abschrift. Sie ist mit dem Prägestempel von Kessler versehen und mit „Kessler“ unterschrieben. Ein weiteres Blatt ist eingelegt: Ein Zeitungsausschnitt „Moderne Pariser Soiréen“ von Kaufmann; Breite: 29 cm, Länge 17,6 cm, der Artikel wird auf der Rückseite fortgeführt. Keine Abschrift.

After this M r Macdonald sat down again and the head gets up and says
„Now I will proceed with the prizes“ „Fry first division Prize.“ Fry walks up amidst thunders of applause.

„Bell second division Prize,“ more applause After some time he says „Kessler french prize“ I go up trembling after some time he again calls my name for Geography this time there is a good deal of applauds soon the prizegiving is finished

We all go upstairs and at 3 ½ the concert begins. We all that sing have to sit on the staircase. Aunt Rose and aunt Lulu go away before the end of the first part. The concert lasts 3 hours: from 3½ to 6½. Then we have tea to which we have turkey and buns but in the evening after chapel I am very sick.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 14.12.1880 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot Dec, 14.

This morning we all go away Fry who is going for good gives me a little porcelain turtle as present d’adieux and promises to send me his photograph. In the afternoon aunt Lulu, aunt Rose, Mademoiselle Hohé and I go to the Aquarium where we see D r Carver who shoots wonderfully well. I also buy a microscope

ns0:div.ns0:head: 15.12.1880 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: London. Dec 15
This evening we all dine at 7 o'c at uncle Stephen’s Lynch . We also go to the Soho Bazaar

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 16.12.1880 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: London Dec 16 Thursday
Today I take aunt Lulu to see Westminster abbey in the afternoon aunt Rose and aunt Lulu go to the Crystal palace but I stop at home

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 17.12.1880 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: London Dec 17 Friday

This morning aunt Rose aunt Lulu and I go to the Tower and S t Paul’s where aunt Rose and I go up to the whispering gallery and the library and clockworks and to the first outer gallery. In the afternoon we go and see the Midgets who are little people 22 inches high and the girl weighs 4¾ pounds and the boy 9 pound the girl is 18 and the boy 16. with them are also Jennie Imgly and Commodore Foot who are also dwarfs they are in Piccadilly hall

ns0:div.ns0:head: 18.12.1880 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris Dec 18 Saturday
Today we came from London the sea was pretty rough We live 89 Boulevard Malesherbes in the premier sans entresol

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 22.12.1880 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris Dec 22 Wednesday

Today in coming from the Bonmarché we took a cab and I being very tired leaned back; and just as I was going to sleep I heard a loud crash: I started up and to my horror beheld a horses head just infront of me and the glass coming in, the carriage leaning most frightfully on one side and the coachman flying head over heels off the box. I throw myself on aunt Lulu so as not to get my face cut by the glass; at last the other carriage goes away and we jump out but aunt Lulu forgets her parcels in the cab and has to go in again; I in my fright run over the place de la Concorde and we get into another carriage and drive home but this one asks aunt Lulu 2 francs to drive home being a club carriage and aunt Lulu not giving him any pourboire he gets very angry and says „ce n’est pas avec vous que je m’enrichirai“Ein Teil dieses Eintrages steht auf einem fest eingeklebten Streifen Papier. Breite: 14,9 cm, Länge: 2,5-3 cm.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 24.12.1880 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris Dec 24 Friday 1880

This evening aunt Lulu and I go on the Boulevards to see the little shops. Afterwards I and Papa go to see aunt Evvy’s Auffm'Ordt, Evelyn Christmastree. Uncle Clement Auffm'Ordt gives me a book called: „l’Amérique du Nord pittoresque“ Bryant
and uncle Willy Auffm'Ordt, William gives me a tort pistol

ns0:div.ns0:head: 25.6.1880 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ems 25 June 1880 Sun rises 3,46 sets 8,19
Bee Brion, Wilma went on the promenade this morning and shook hands with the emperor but she would not speak to him

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 27.12.1880 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris Dec 27 Monday 1880.

This afternoon aunt Lulu and I went to see the „Sainte Chapelle“. The windows are beautiful and represent the whole bible history. They also shew you a stéréoscope with a coloured view of the „Messe du S t
Esprit“ in it.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 28.12.1880 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris Dec 28 Tuesday
Aunt Lulu and I went to see the Louvre his afternoon; we saw the Venus de Milo and the picture gallery afterwards we go to the grands magasins du Louvre it was very full there

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 29.12.1880 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris 29 December 1880 Wednesday
This morning Prince Reuss arrived. I went to Crasse Crane the dentist (7 rue Scribe), accompanied by aunt Lulu, and had 2 teeth pulled out and my teeth cleaned Mamma gave me 10 francs as a reward

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 30.12.1880 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris 30 Decemb 1880 Thursday

Our tree took place to day it was very pretty I got a printing machine, „La maison à vapeur“ Verne „Les Recreations Scientifique“
Tissandier „Les grands voyageurs du XIX Siècle“ Verne and other lovely things Baby Brion, Wilma , Mamma and Papa also had lovely things and Papa too. aunt Lulu gave me a little thing to print my name. The little Siefert came and Madame George’s (the dressmakers) children these last were very naughty

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 31.12.1880 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris 31 December 1880 Friday

Prince Reuss XVIII came to breakfast and dine with us to day. I and aunt Lulu brought the printing press to the maker, because I broke, and to have the rouleau put in. It rained very hard and we took omnibusses and tramways there and back so as not to get wet.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 1.1.1881 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris 1 st January 1881 Saturday

This morning aunt Lulu and I went to church. We wanted to go to the german church but we could not find our way so we went to the French one and heard the celebrated Protestant preacher Delille preach This evening Prince Reuss Reuß j. L., Heinrich XVIII. came to diner. M r
and M rs Kynnersley came to see Mamma who had lovely bouquets today. At diner with prince Reuss the conversation turned on what the Bürgermeister Ockel did to us in Pyrmont this summer and which for various reasons I could not put into my diary then but I take this occasion of doing so: When Mamma told Ockel that we were going away in a few days he said that Papa had said he was going to stay 5 weeks, Mamma of course said it was not true so he said he would have Mamma taken up; Mamma got into a dreadful fright because Baby Brion, Wilma was very nearly dying she wrote to Papa to come derectly. Papa arrived with a recommendation letter from the german embassy Ockel said, to use his expression „He fichoid himself of the german embassy“Vermutlich von "se ficher de quelqu'un", ugs. "auf jemanden pfeifen". Mamma threatened with the emperor Wilhelm I. „I fichai myself of him“ said he; Papa told him to take his oath Papa had said he was going to live there 5 weeks „and if I have not said it“ said he and he shewed Papa an order not signed by anybody but himself that whosoever lives in his houses must live there five weeks. so Papa went to Mister v. L....... the Badekommissär who sent him to M r Möckel the lawyier who said he would take the matter in hands. The Bürgermeister wrote an impertinent letter to Papa which Papa gave to M r Möckel. But Baby being so ill Papa did not like going on with the law suit and so he paid Ockel 50 Marks and Möckel 30 Marks, hardly had he done this when Mr v. L....... comes in „à toute vitesse“ saying he hopes Papa has not given it up because the countess Feil had been played the same trick upon by Ockel Papa said he had payed so the countess Feil had (I suppose) to pay too The day before we left Pyrmont we drove to Hameln and when we came back the people were very quiteZwei durch große X gekennzeichnete Stellen markieren eine Umstellung. Die Transkription folgt der Umstellung. Der Name des Badekommissärs ist von Kessler nicht ausgeschrieben.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 2.1.1881 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris 2 nd January 1881 Sunday
This afternoon I went out with Papa and aunt Lulu and we walked in the Champs-Elysees and on the Boulevards.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 3.1.1881 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris 3d January Monday.

This morning I went out with aunt Lulu. This evening we had a dinner party M r
and M rs Kynnersley also came. Mamma did not go in to dinner

ns0:div.ns0:head: 5.1.1881 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris 5th January 1881
Aunt Lulu and I went to the Musée Cluny today where we saw the inferior jawbone of Moliere We again had an accident: our horse fell

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 8.1.1881 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris 8 th January 1881 Friday

I went to the little Sieferts today. After having twice taken the wrong omnibus tickets and great excitement (on aunt Lulu’s side) of which she allways accused me we arrived there. Two other gentlemen were invited: M r Elie a lawyer, and M r François one of the little Sieferts professeurs

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 26.6.1880 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ems 26 June 1880 Sun rises 3,46 sets 8,19

This morning as I do not go out with Papa I go out with Bee and nursevermutl. Sophie We go on the Nassau road as far as Dausenau village which quite merits its dowdy name for the grown up inhabitants look as if they had smoked opium the whole night. For the rest Dausenau at first view seems a very unhospitable village for in the streets you see nothing but dogs barking, hens chuckling and children screaming at you, one must here remark that as much the grownups seem sleepy and quiet, as much the children look awake and noisy. The village is composed of two towers of which one is as crookid as a rams horn, an old church four or five restaurants and about forty houses which seem to be as well ment for people as for cows probably they all sleep together cows, pigs, people hens and dogs The perfume in the streets coming from the cow sheds or rather cow houses may be healthy but certainly is not flattering to the nose and the streets, or rather the street does not seem ever to have seen water and they would allmost want a second Herkules to cleanse them. Today M r
Maxheimer sends word he cannot come

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 14.1.1881 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris 14 th January 1881 Friday

We breakfasted at 11 o’clock to day and afterwards went to the Bibliothèque Nationale and afterwards to Sèvres but we could not get into the fabrique and only saw the Museum. It is about 4 degrees cold today.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 15.1.1881 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Paris 15 January 1881 Saturday

We went to the catacombes today. Everybody has got a light and the descent begins, we go down 80 steps and penetrate into a long corridor chiselled out of the rock, everybody laughing and talking and joking but as we come in sight of an enormous black porch with bone on bone scull next to scull and an inscription of which I can only remember the beginning: „Ils furent ce que nous sommes, poussierre de la terre, jouet de vents .............“ everybody stops one feels that one is in the vestibule of death we go through the porch and on the other side nothing but bones and sculls in these six words one can explain all the catacombes. Here and there some very pretty inscriptions such as „Homme n’oublié pas que tu dois mourir“ and others here and there passages like ours branching off we pass by a small kind of a room where crosses are made out of scull and by pitt full of water at last we come out of this dreadfull passage by another black door and porch and go into another corridor under two natural „cloches“ or bells formed by the earth falling down after some time we come to a staircase and we got out at last after having mounted the same number of steps as before, „des cranes, des cranes et encore des cranes“ ought to be the inscription on it.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 19.1.1881 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: London 19 January 1881

We started from Paris at 7.15 and at 12.30 were at Arras here we took in workmen who walked before the train and cleared away the snow as we went we halted at every station: such as S t Omer, Lens at this last station the workmen got out and went away We also stopped ¾ of an hour on account of snow at 4.20 we were at the station Calais and at 5.30 we were at the end of the pier. We all got on board ship. The sky was very dark and as we got out of port the ship began to roll so that one could not stand without holding on as it grew darker it grew rougher all at once there is the command „Halte“ everybody rushes to one side of the ship and there we see a ship, a wreck with all its masts gone everything gone except its carcase and at its fron a red light darkly illuminating the people on board her. being towed by another ship very nearly equally bad Our sailors scream out for her name the answer is „252 Dunkerque“ At last we see the Dover lights come up on the horizont and at quarter to 9 the „Petrel“ is there. Part of the Pier is washed away and so we have to walk in the bitterest cold up the pier to the station carrying our hand luggage as there are no porters to be had and whats more the pier is dangerous and there is a place where it is hardly 2½ yards wide. At last at the end of the pier I got a porter. But I had lost my party and M r
and M rs Kamintsky. At 7½ we start from Dover from where I had previously sent a telegram to grandmama Lynch, Caroline saying I had arrived in Dover. At 9 minutes to ten we arrive in London after 15 hours journey. The Kamintzkys go on to their ship and I and one of our party M r Samuels got a cab or rather a greengrocers cart who agrees for 12 shillings to drive us home me 140 Westbourne terrace and M r Samuels 80 Lancaster road. I also met Rogers Grandmamma’s coachman at the station. London looks very curious in its white cloak of snow which has in some places drifted up to 6 feet high. We saw one poor girl being picked up frozen and another crowd probably on the same account. At last we arrive and I am glad to get home and go to bed

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 20.1.1881 Donnerstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: London 20 January 1881 Thursday
Today we get a letter that I need not go to school till Monday

ns0:div.ns0:head: 22.1.1881 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: London 22 January 1881

We went to see the Pantomime „Mother Goose and the Enchanted Beauty“
Blanchard to day.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 25.1.1881 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot 25 January 1881
I came back to school to day and am sleeping in the same room. Palk and lots of other boys have not come back yet

ns0:div.ns0:head: 4.2.1881 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot 4 February 1881
I took Pearse and Gordon out for a walk today we met the other boys

ns0:div.ns0:head: 16.2.1881 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot 16 February 1881
Aunt Carry Craigie, Caroline had a little girl to day she was born in the evening

ns0:div.ns0:head: 18.2.1881 Freitag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot 18 February 1881
Papa who gave me a watch and aunt Rose came to see me to day. Papa is going to America his ship starts tomorrow at 12 am

ns0:div.ns0:head: 19.2.1881 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot 19 February. Saturday

In playing football Watson was thrown against a tree by Ferguson who said he wished he had done it harder Watson was badly striking with that part of the fore head near the temple against the tree. In the evening having forgotten my prayerbook in chapel I went to fetch In undressing I found my watch gone so Kelforte (the butler) and I went out and found my watch with only the glass missing and broken but the watch had fallen out because the spring in my watch was broken

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 27.6.1880 Sonntag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ems Sunday 27 June 1880 Sun rises 3,46 sets 8,19

Today as I am better I go out with papa to go to
Kemmenau
The beginning of the road is very sunny but soon one has to turn to the left and then one is in the forest. Soon after we turned we met a donkey and a carriage then we turn to the right again and cut across a forest but out of the forest we came on a stone field after we have passed the stones my foot got cought in to the roots of a tree and I fell. I must before say that papa had lent me his „podomètre“. We soon find a path though and go on it on this path papa also fell over a stone but however we got to the top. Here papa asked me for his podomètre. I look in the pocket I had put it in, it is not there I look in my other pockets, in the lining of my west on the ground it is not there neither, : I had lost it where, when I do not know; when all at once I rememberd I had fallen, it must be there I had lost it. Then papa orders some ham and wine we have diner, look at the Rhine and scenery and follow the same road we had come so as to find the podomètre I look everywhere but we don’t find it. We then go down to the silverworks and mines and from there home To day is the first day since we have been here that it has been really fine. Marie’s mother arrived to day Marie went to two trains before she went at the right time for her mother missed Ems and went as far as Coblenz so of course she could not arrive at the right time; she came from Berlin

ns0:div.ns0:head: 1.3.1881 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot Shrove-tuesday. 1. March 1881

We had pancakes for dinner. M r
Clifford Harrison a very good reciter come today and recited the following program

ns0:p.ns0:note: Hier ist ein Blatt eingeklebt. Breite: 12,7 cm, Länge 20,3 cm. Es folgt eine Abschrift.

Part I The Pied Piper_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _Browning
The Building of S. Sophia (with music)_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _Gould Baring-Gould
An Incident from Vanity Fair_ _ _ _ _ _ Thackeray Jupiter and Io_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ Fields
The Lord of the Land (with music)_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ Tilton
The Wives of Brixham_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _Anon.
The White Squall_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ __ _ _Thackeray.
Part II
A Legend of Bregeny (with music)_ _ _ _ _ _ _ __ _ _Proctor
The Soldiers in the Snow_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ MS.
The Place where the old Horse died_ _ Whyte Melville
A Sea Dirge_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _Carol Carroll .
The Nemesis of Fun_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _Anon.
A Legend of the Monk Felix (with music)_ _ _ _ _ _ _Longfellow.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 2.3.1881 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot Ash-Wednesday 2 March 1881

We went for a walk to Windsor-forest and in it there was one tree which was quite hollow and into which 5 of us boys could easily get in I and all the others went in. M r
Atkinson did not go in. There is another tree which we saw which has one of its branches broken off and the stump is exactly like an elephant’s head. It is called „the elephant oak.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 12.3.1881 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot Saturday March 12 1881

We had athletic sports today such as jumping racing and hurdle races. We got off sets. M r
Cook caught Craven and me fighting over the partition in our rooms and said he would report us to the Head (M r Kynnersley) who has gone to London for the day

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 14.3.1881 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot Monday March 14 1881

Today the „Times“ saysArtikel der Times vom 14.3.1881: Assassination Of The Emperor Of Russia. the Czar Alexander II has been assassinated; he was shot at and missed and while arresting the shooter a bomb was thrown into his carriage. This bomb exploded and the Czar was blown up. Killed. 13 th of April Das Datum wurde nachträglich eingetragen.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 28.3.1881 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot March 28. 1881.
The heath cought fire to day while we were out at play; it burnt the whole time we were out at play; it very nearly lit the fir trees.

ns0:availability.ns0:p: Dieses Dokument ist ggf. rechtlich geschützt. Bitte informieren Sie sich in der Rubrik Rechte des Paratextes.

ns0:div.ns0:head: 4.4.1881 Montag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot Monday 4 th April
Today after Scripture lesson we all had our census taken (which only happens every ten years) by the head Sneyd-Kynnersley

ns0:div.ns0:head: 5.4.1881 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Ascot Tuesday 5 th April.

Ferguson, Heysham, Olliver, Hall ma., Bell were confirmed by the Bishop of Oxford Mackarness
who came to lunch with a lot of other people so its was a regular dinner party

ns0:div.ns0:head: 9.4.1881 Samstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Saturday Ascot 9 April 1881

Athletic sports today: and prizes. I got the French Prize. _ „Ismailia
Baker “

ns0:div.ns0:head: 12.4.1881 Dienstag
ns0:div.ns0:p: Tuesday London 12 April 1880
Came to London today and went to play with Violet and Mabel

ns0:div.ns0:head: 13.4.1881 Mittwoch
ns0:div.ns0:p: Wednesday London 13 April 1881
I went to Henglers circus to day with Harry Lynch
